content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												i played this game intensively for about a 2 week period in which time i spent over 300 dollars in hopes to become one of the dominate powers of the newly created server. i have no problem with a game being shamelessly "pay to win" which stronghold kingdoms is a textbook definition of, but i do have a serious problem with companies violating their own server rules and terms of service which firefly studios did in a major way. to make a long story short i was libeled against in the most severe way possible by another community member. i had documented proof of this in the form of chat logs and screenshots. this was clearly against the EULA and the server rules and was reported multiple times. firefly refused to take action becuase the person had spent some money on the service. since they violated their eula i demanded a refund which they also refused. since i used my steam wallet i submitted a steam ticket documenting my experience and firefly's failure to enforce their eula demanding a refund. steam also refused to refund me and threatened to terminate my entire steam account with over 1000 titles if i called my credit card company to report the fraud. after all this i stopped buying steam games for almost an entire year. to this day i still will not use the steam wallet nor will i ever buy or invest in another product remotely related to firefly studios. avoid this company at all cost, they do not care about the costumer they only care about how best to take your money from you and will never give it back. i believe they decided to port it to steam for this very reason, to make refunds more problematic for the customer.avoid this company at all costs. if i was an english subject and not an american citizen i would have taken legal action against the developers.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												This game is best played in conjunction with using TeamSpeak and Skype to coordinate strategy with your group of friends. This is a 24/7 game. You cannot just leave the game and come back to it days later and expect things to be as you left them.What I like best:  The social interaction. You meet people from all over the world and of different age groups. Enjoy leading a faction and/or being a house marshal, build villages, or work on leaderboard scores and quests. Trying to get your faction or house to be number one is very fun. If you are very social and enjoy spending a lot of time playing on the computer, you will love this game.What I like least:  It is a "pay to win" game and the customer support department doesn't really care about issues with the game function. The more crowns and cards you have, the better you can do in the game. If you don't play a premium token you won't do as well in the game. The Firefly support attitude comes across as, "I don't care." You cannot have other members of your household play the game (your account will be banned). When I argued a point with them, politely and with no swearing, after a temporary ban, they permanently banned my son's account. When I experienced what I thought was a bug in the game and sent in the report and explained what I did to resolve it, they sent me a generic message asking me to explain the issue more and explain what I did to resolve it. I had to remessage and explain I already did that (meaning ... they didn't even bother to read the first message).Update: I had another "bug" issue to contact support about. I received a generic reply and they said they could "discern no error," even after I submitted screen shots of the reports and pointed out what happened. All they did was politely tell me, "Oh well," and didn't do anything to resolve the problem. Not a satisfied customer right now.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												There's an unfair balance of power in this game. I created a new village since my first one couldn't be expanded anymore. The moment I make another village, the parish leader attacks me for no reason. This is a pay to win game and all the powerful jerks all payed just so they can kick all the little players around. I was attacked by the capital he owned, than he attacked me with a large army and destroyed my villages. Don't play this since there are just guys who do nothing but bully all the other players.This game has a very unique concept that I really like, build small village, watch it grow like a plant and be excited about your progress. You started with just a few peasents and a little bit of resources and you were able to make such an amazing settlement, you take a step back and look at how hard you've worked. Then all the players that sink a ton of money into the game come in and stomp all over it, even if you're playing it peacefully, not attacking others, only AI, and if someone attacks you and they explain that they have a perfectly good reason for it other than "just for the resources" or "for the fun of it", you just forgive them and never hold it against them. Well the Pay to Win players just attack for the fun of it, or to keep you from even getting up to where they are. The big dogs only see us small pups and the people that play this to have a good time and experience a new type of gameplay as a threat from the day we even drop into the server, and the game's PVP attack immunity doesn't even help, becuase the moment that goes away and they've had your eye on you from day 1, then nothing is stopping them from marching straight to your village, with 100+ troops, destroying the beautiful and incredible castle you worked so hard on. And once they destroy your castle, next thing you know, they already sent another army to clean up what the 1st one couldn't, then they kick you to the ground, spit on your face, and end your entire game there. Not even trying again will help you because then this entire process will start all over again.The only way to win is to give the devs money, that's it. Real world money is what drives this entire game, not skill, not tactics, not teamwork of other F2P players like you that actually want to see what this game has to offer. Without giving money, these devs just throw you to the wolves, that's it, they don't care about all the higher up breaking the rules, as long as they keep giving money to stay ahead, then anything goes. I hate to see that a game this unique is completely ruined by money and people who stay on for literally months, that's right, MONTHS, on end and never even shut down the game just so they can watch over the little guy and plan on how to end them the very second they get.This game would be great if the rich people and the higher ups didn't stomp on everyone who can't afford even the smallest in-game item like me. It would be better if it was better controlled, alt accounts are against game rules, but they don't have a way to enforce it, so you got 1 person, with a ton of money, creating 10+ accounts, ruling a huge chunk of land, sinking tons of money into those accounts, collecting all the resources they can get, just to hammer down all of the players that just want to explore the game.This game needs to be better moderated, give the F2P players a fighting chance, and even out the balance of power, becuase all those are the reason I do not recommend this game.

number of helpful: 29 of 48 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												"Stronghold Kingdoms" is an answer to strategy fans who want to play in an online living and breathing world.I wanted to wait a few monthes till I review it to give a better review as the game is massive and the amount of layers it has is enourmous.Some words about the game:- Takes place on a real map, one can choose to start in many maps such as : World, Europe, Germany, UK, USA, Poland, Turkey, France, Italy, Russia etc.- You play as a lord with a fuedal titel starting from  a "village idiot" up until "crown prince", those in essence are equivalent to "levels" in MMORPGs and provide you with more possibilities. You rank up by gaining "Honor" which is in essence "Experience" in MMORPGs. Honor can be collected in noumerous ways: Be it warefare, economy or pollitics.- The core of the game is building and developing yours villages castles, of course as being built villages can also be conquered.Economy:-Resources are gathered from natural deposits and are used to build buildings or craft weapons (wood, stone, pitch and iron).-Food is used to feed your population (apples, cheese, meat, bread, vegetables, fish and ale)-Goods are used to hold banquets increasing your honor (meat, clothes, metalwork, furniture, wine, spices, silk and salt)-Weapons are used to arm your people (Bows, Pikes, Swords, Catapults)- Every resource can be created, traded or foraged.- Everything is wraped under a large research tree.Warefare:- Scouts are used to gather reports about enemy castles.- Armies are used to both defend your villages and attack your enemies villages.Politics:- There is a beautiful fuedal system in place, lower ranks answer to their lieges in the following system: Village < Perish < County < Province < Country. The higher position you hold the more glory you bring to your house. Political positions are acquired through voting but of course can be pressured using warefare or religeon influence.- Lords fight under a banner of a faction (equivalent to guild in MMORPGs), and factions fight under a banner of a house.- At end game houses struggle over the map domination.Costs:- How much does this cost?Sadly a freemium bussiness model is in place which means that you can invest as much as you want.In my opinion in order to stay competitive an investment of a few euros per month will be necessary.- Will a player that invests more money that you have certain advantages? Yes, he will develop and progress faster. Is this a deal breaker? Absolutly not, some people play longer and some people pay longer... Up to each one.N.B:- Some people are unhappy about being razed, conquered and loosing all their hard worked on villages. I would like to say a few words about that:It is true that "Stronghold Kingdoms" is not for the weak hearted... Yes you may loose all your villages in a war but you will get a new village and will still keep your fuedal rank, your research, your gold, faith and honor. So rebuilding is not a big deal and it is faster every time, like in real life... Sometimes we fall, but the whole point is to raise up again, this time even stronger.To summerize:A brilliant massive online strategy game that allows one to play as he wants. You may concentrate on warefare, farming, pollitics, religeon or whatever suits your intrests best.Look me up on Europa 3 ;)

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2013
												I have played all the Stronghold Games, and this game is very addictive i've spent over 600 hours in this all together with this account, with my other steam account and out of steam. It's alot of fun but it is a PAY TO WIN game, and I've tried playing with and without paying in this game.Stronghold Kingdoms took the Original Stronghold idea and made it into an online game,it is divided into five main areas:Your Villages : Where you build up your economy, you make your population happy or angry by increasing the tax levels, the ammount of food they will receive and the ale they are allowed to the drink.These 4 factors will give you honor, which is used to conquer, pillage raze or plunder other player's villages. You can get more honor by making banquets. Your Castles: Castles have always been a huge part of Stronghold games. Using the resources you get from improving your village you will be able to build huge castles to protect your economy and productivity. These castles can then be garrisoned by the troops you create, Either pikemen, archers, swordsmen or catapults. The People Around you/ Houses: Having alot of players in the same game just pillaging each other until the last man standing wouldn't be much fun all the time, So the developers decided to create Houses, these are like Factions you join there are 20 houses in the game, Each house has a marshall that decides what the house should do next.These houses devide into factions in the House which are controlled by high ranking members. The best invasion I have ever seen was the Invasion of England which was controlled by House 1 in the Europe World, France(House 11), Spain(House 9) and Portugal(House 9) all decided to go against H1, in 1 day it was in shatters most of the players had been eliminated or just deserted they're House. It was truly an impressive feet. Armies and Vassals: As you grow in the game you can decide to have liege lords ( Someone who will protect you from other people, send you resources and armies to defend yourself) and have vassals, in which case you do the same thing to the people you decide, Each vassal allows a maximum of 500 troops to be garrisoned in the village allowing the liege lord to have thousands upon thousands of men ready for an attack. And Research: Research is a major factor in Stronghold Kingdoms because it allows the player to get a step ahead on other people, either in farming, military or industry.It takes alot of time and efford to become powerful in stronghold kingdoms without Paying money.Took me about 100 days to become powerfull and that's going to stronghold every day to check up on what's going on. And what made me angry as hell was seeing that in 5 days Using loads of money a player got to The max rank! 5 DAYS man!! What in the â¥â¥â¥â¥!!  It just made all my effords seem meaningless. Therefore I do not recommend this game, it is a time waster Do not play this unless you want to spend large ammounts of your time and money.

And what made me angry as hell was seeing that in 5 days Using loads of money a player got to The max rank! 5 DAYS man!! What in the â¥â¥â¥â¥!!  It just made all my effords seem meaningless. Therefore I do not recommend this game, it is a time waster Do not play this unless you want to spend large ammounts of your time and money.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Big NO to this game, not just because it's Pay 2 Win, but because there are so many abusive ways that players use to try to win the game and the developers do nothing about it although these actions are against their rules. (Why hurt cheaters as long as they pay?)No matter how you try to start the game, no matter how you choose your playstyle, someone destroys you with the help of his alt accounts (which is illegal according to the game rules, but who cares about cheating as long as they buy crowns?)Best case scenario, you start totally neutral in a newly opened server, you try to be nice to other people, you're not behind, everything is ok for now, you help other players, join the faction that is stronger, communicate with others. Some guy makes an alt account, spawns in your parish, starts to build up and after 5 days he starts ransacking you (which means with each attack you lose atleast 1 building), You're probably thinking "so what? defend!! build a castle", now here's the problem, after only 10 days of play, without paying hundrends of dollars you can't be that strong to build a great castle and rank up fast at the same time, you either choose to play the honour path which leaves your castle vulnerable, or you play turtle, which again leaves you with a small amount of resources which is not exactly enough to build a castle that can defend agianst a troll who attacks with 80 peasants, his 80 peasants just need to destroy your wall and stay in the white line for 5 seconds, Nothing at that level of play can prevent upgraded peasants from entering the white area of your castle. and you're done, atleast one of your buildings is destroyed, now imagine losing a building every hour, 24 buildings per day, you're absolutely done. You lose all your buildings and you don't even know what to do except to start over. The funny thing is the honour cost to attack trolls is so high that neither you nor your allies can attack them without losing 90% of your honour (obviously no one helps you because of the honour cost). And even if you attack! he will just wait a day or two and then starts attacking again, even if you raze and destroy him, he will just respwan again and starts building and attacking once again. And meanwhile his main account is dominating and you're wondering if it's better to move to another parish or continue here!!People use alt accounts to attack, trade, to vote, any form of cheat you can imagine, and after all this you realize you've wasted your time over a game that kicks you back to day 1 every time you feel great about yourself... And they still need your money! otherwise you're back to square one...No! Please Don't Play This Game...

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Rise of The Wolf update has damaged this game, especially if you are relatively new.I enjoyed the game when I first started, it was a very slow paced medieval city builder with custom designed castles and such. I spent my days gaining resources and slowly beefing up my stronghold and donating extra resources to my local parish capitol.Days of doing this was quite relaxing, and the occasional Ai attack spiced things up. Seeing how well my newly made fortifications held up against 30, then 60, then 100, then 130 enemies was quite fun.I also thought it was very cool getting to view battles between my parish and our enemy Ai, Pig. Large scale battles taking place every day while we fuel the parish with resources was amazing.Then Rise of The Wolf happened.All at once we had an enemy Siege camp, wolf dens, bandit camps, Pig and its castle of doom, and all of the associated negative morale. Pig for what ever reason appears to target my town exclusively, on top of daily sieges and bandit raids.Within 3 days my forces had been reduced to 3 archers and 2 morale resulting in a single peasant every 12 hours, my food consumption was set to max to boost morale with very little effect and my taxes were already starting to drain what little gold reserve I had. Then I realize that no one is attacking Pig, the siege camp, or the bandits.. and it appears most of their aggression is focused towards me. Our parish apparently had been innactive for several days prior so help from them was a long ways off.After speaking out in global chat, I found out that I am not the only one facing this scenario. The competent players are away or ignoring the enemies, while the weak and defenceless are destroyed by the new enemy spawn rate.So, unless you know a strong player and can get cozy with them and their army, stay away until Rise of The Wolf is put to rest.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Regarding Kingdoms....Update: This game and those who support it  (FireflyStudios) apparently didnt  like the fact that I had ANYTHING negative to say about this game. Shortly after my "mostly good" review of SHK was posted here, my (and my borther's) accounts were both banned without any explanation. I created several tickets trying to find out why but this same terrible Customer Service rep("Lord Efficient") kept pasting canned responses about not being able to respond to individual requests, and closing the ticket.Apparently, they can take the time to ban individual acocunts for whatever they feel like is a good reason but they are FAR TOO BUSY to tell the accused what they are being accused of, much less actually using the Ban Appeals section of the system for...you know... ban appeals (Id setlle for a coherent explanation). But, I guess f you never bother to tell someone what they are banned for, you dont have to worry about them attempting to appeal. Way to stay classy, Firefly.   So at this point my account, which I have spend a couple hundred dollars on over the course of a couple of years, is banned with no explanation and (what appears to be ) their only support rep has no skills beyond copy/paste and close ticket. And this was in the BAN APPEALS section of their ticketing system. I have emailed the Firefly Head of PR about how their customers are being treated, with no response, so I suppose the disregard for their customer's happiness appears to have infected the majority of Firefly employees. I am now taking steps to get my preorder (through STEAM) of Stronghold Crusader 2 refunded as Firefly is even worse than EA in their treatement of, or regard for their customers. I, personally, do not want another one of my dollars to benefit Firefly IN ANY WAY. I play many MMO games and have never been treated like this. Even when I was accused of a TOS violation (later proven not true), I was told what I was being accused of and give a chance to answer the accusations. You will not get this courtesy out of StrongholdKingdoms support.  So If you do decide to play this game, PLEASE do not pay them for premium as you will likely, at some point, regret every dollar spent (just as I do now). Fair Warning...Dustedpuppy

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												Stronghold Kingdoms is a very slow paced game that requires a lot of diplomacy with other players. It's a type of game that you leave on when you're browsing. I have played this game since early 2012 to late 2014. I really like the card system In Stronghold Kingdoms. The artwork is very nice, I really like it. Most of the content is reused from old Stronghold games but I still like it. The people I've met are very nice and friendly.However, It was very fun when I played the game at first, I played it every day, it was very addicting and I spent a lot of hours in this game before I downloaded the Steam version. I downloaded the steam version more than a year later. I started playing on World 4 when the server was still 30 days old. The game just gets boring after a some hundred days where everyone has a high rank and the world becomes dull. I tried to like it in my last few hundred days playing but it just didn't work. Then I stopped playing at about day 800. People say this game is pay to win, I kinda agree. Things like premium token will give you progress faster in the game.I have mixed feelings about this game. I like the Stronghold series. But I don't recommend this game. Because in long term playability, it kinda sucks. Stronghold Kingdoms might be enjoyable and fun at first, but in a year or several months, the World(server) will become dull. You'll need to play it every day or else you could lose all your progress, because if you have an enemy, they will try to wipe you out.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I'm only saying no, because I'm on the fence. If you've got the real-life money to support the in-game upgrades, then you're fine and you'll really enjoy the game, without, you're kinda â¥â¥â¥â¥ed. For a 'free' game, it's not so free.The whole game is in real-time, and that's ok. However, with every building you place, and every thing you research, it bumps up the time. No matter the type of building, or research option. Just adds minutes to the time. And that's not so bad, until it hits over 30 minutes and you haven't got the tokens to have a building and research queue. So with this, it takes a long time to build up a decent, protected base with enough peasants to train a competent army to defend your stronghold. Problem with that is, you're a new player, and this is an online world. A lot of players will ignore rule 7 - don't be aâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ and just attack you for the sake of attacking. For me, who is a slow learner, that just makes the game even harder and unfair. the 2 days worth of protection at the beginning is great, but I think that needs to be a week. In a week you an have a decent wooden defence line and a good-ish sized army (depending on how happy you keep the peasants) to protect your stronghold after the timer goes out. Other than that, the user friendly-ness of the game is great, and I love the option that you get to keep the tutorial pages near by, in case you forget anything, then you an just turn it off when you're ready, and that's awesome. The graphics are alright, but since they're really simple, it doesn't lag your computer, which is a bonus if you run off wireless all the time like me. I also like having the different tabs at the top, keeping everything seperated out and neat really helps you get to grips with the game. So overall, I like the game and won't stop playing it, but I wouldn't recommend it. I'm just stubborn and miss being able to play the old Stronghold games.(Saving the money up for the complete pack though)

(412 or so)I had an issue where my account was compromized in what I believe was an attempt by other players to destabilize our group by getting into other players' accounts and messing them up. They deleted my base, insulted all my friends, and spent all of my cards purchased with REAL MONEY.I contacted the devs to see if anything could be done and I was PROMPTLY IGNORED.I contacted them now that the new update was released, wanting back into the game after logging in and finding out that my account was blocked...And was told this: "This account was blocked in 2012 and will not be reopened.   Players are responsible for the security of their own log in information."Not even a "we'll look into it", "we'll reset your account so you can play again", or anything...Now because of their refusal to ever even acknowledge that my account was compromised, my steam account is banned from their game. content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I was suckered into this on a random search for free-to-play games on Steam.  Time, more than anything, will be your "make or break" factor here.  No, you don't have to be on 24/7.  But if you want to be very successful, or rather "not lose," you'll kind of have to have this in your background on a consistent basis; for example, I haven't actually played nearly 600 hours of SHK, but it "has" been running on my computer for that amount of time.  The mediocre charm of planting your custom-named village(s) on a real-time map wears off quickly and you're left with a grind that you can try solo'ing forever alone, or deal with inter-House politics with others in the competitive aspect of the game if you're social enough.I promise you: there are a million better ways to spend your time.  I do not suggest you waste it on this Facebook browser game not appropriately placed on Facebook.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Although it is a fairly fun and exciting stratergy game, I have many problems with it. The actually game play is very slow with building times and research times getting longer and longer each time you build or research something. The scouts take about half an hour (real time) to reach an item and return when it is not that far away from your kingdom or village. Until about 10 minutes ago (from when I'm writing this), I was queueing things up like buildings and research items so I could leave the game to work for me. Now, I have to get premium coins to queue things. This means I have to check on everything more often and the game play is slow enough as it is. Now I understand this is a Free to Play game so I would guess the company would put an option in to buy things with real money so they can get some money from it but when one of the achievements is to buy coins? It makes it a game I want to punch in it's metaphorical face. I'm going to continue to play this game because I am determined to find a way to win without paying but don't start if you haven't already.

content:
Posted: January 23
												     I'll admit, I certainly played this game a lot. However, I can't really recommend it. The game centers around building and protecting villages. They can be attacked by other players and the AI. That may seem like a really simplistic view of the game, but that's the core. There is not much else to it than that. Every action a player takes is for their village. There are some interesting upgrades players can get through research and buildings, but it all takes time. For me, that is what this game boiled down to. Time. A big ol' swirling drain full of time. Players can pay to accelerate the process, but why bother? The rewards are simply not worth the time required. TL;DR - Takes too much time to do anything.6/10

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												Stronghold Kingdoms has some good ideas including an excellent village building system, interesting and balanced research tree and challenging castle building process. Although the game is free to play, it is impossible to be a strong player without purchasing coins and card points. The top players spend massive amounts of money to crush ordinary foes. Additionally, the game drags on for a very long time and soon grows stale. After a few weeks, the servers  largely empty out as most players get bored or are destroyed. Stronghold could be an excellent long term game with some improvements, but now it is a pay to win money machine.

												I loved the original concept.  However, FireFly has changed the rules so that it is more of a pay to win game than a strategy game. The addition of certain cards, and rule changes favor those that wish to win at all costs!  I don't care for games where others are better than I am just because they have more money than I do, or because they can sit in front of their computer all day long.  I enjoy learning a skill, or technique, and then being able to use it against an opponent that is not expecting it.  However, in Kingdoms, there are not many new skills or techniques to keep the game exciting.  The actual excitement comes from meeting new people, and then, that is usually in a teamspeak, or raidcall room.  But, you could do that with any game.No, I no longer recomment this game!  If you got to play in the first couple of years, it was great, but, that is no longer the case.

number of helpful: 20 of 36 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Stronghold Kingdoms is as much a game of politics as it is a game of Medieval warfare or simulation. The articulate politician will find himself advancing far more quicker than the warrior and it is not at all uncommon to find House Marshalls who have only razed a handful of players.First I'd like to address the two foremost complaints about Stronghold kingdoms; Pay to Win and Multi AccountersMulits - Players controlling 2 or more accounts per game world.The problem here is twofold and blame falls equally on both the players and Firefly. All too often I see a user on the forums calling for heads to roll after he reports a player suspected of cheating and nothing happens. The paranoid player would do well to remember that suspicious does not equal guilty and that Firefly will not disclose the outcome of any investigation to the player who filed the report. If it appears nothing has been done it's likely because the investigation turned up nothing illicit and remember the more information you include in your report the more likely the accusation is to be investigated. The other half of blame sits squarely upon Firefly's shoulders in my opinion due to the sheer ambiguity of the game rules. Time and time again I've had players coming to me with multiple accounts firm in their insistence that they weren't breaking any rules because they "had premium tokens in play on both accounts". Despite what anyone might say to convince you otherwise the above allegation is flat out untrue. Regardless of premium tokens, players are only allotted one account per game world. All Firefly here has to do is update the game rules page to be less ambiguous in regards to the IP restrictions and premium players clause but they will not and this apathy towards one of the top complaints about Stronghold Kingdoms promotes the continued perpetuation of the myth that Firefly doesn't care and that they don't investigate informed allegations against suspected cheaters. Pay To Win - The belief that to succeed at any level in Stronghold Kingdoms the player must spend liberal amounts of money to obtain their own virtual crown. Pay to Win (or P2W) is a hotly debated topic in many 'Free to play' games and the same applies to Stronghold Kingdoms and there is no doubt that in this case it's a grey area for sure. But to answer whether or not the game is p2w one must first define what winning means to them and what winning means to Firefly. For many players 'to win' is to beat another player in a one on one mano a mano fight. Providing both players are of the same skill level and neither receive any outside help there is no doubt that whichever of the two players spends more on the game will ultimately be the winner. There are just too many cards in the Stronghold Kingdoms deck that artificially boost combat stats such as army speed or the strength of castle structures and Firefly doesn't help the matter by continuing to introduce more powerful combat cards all the time. Sure, the only players who use those aces are probably the top 0.5% but in worlds with dwindling playerbases those players hold the entire server at their collective whim. In contrast, many experienced players realize that winning is actually more than a one on one fight and that loosing one battle doesn't mean the war is lost and that there are dozens, if not hundreds, of players participating on both sides of the conflict, carder and non carder alike. This means that while you are going up against a house with spending players your house will likely have spending players of it's own which levels the playing field. Firefly's definition is similar to the above, Houses compete against one another to gain glory, ultimately eliminating all others houses to be the last one standing. That final House is considered the winner of that age and inducted into the hall of fame while their members all share in on the spoils of the victory which mostly consists of a few quest wheel spins, card packs, and new charges for their coat of arms. This means that to 'win' Stronghold Kingdoms all one has to actually do is be a member of whichever house is left standing when the dust settles. As you can now see the definition of winning in stronghold Kingdoms is actually quite subjective and by paying attention to ongoing house politics virtually anyone can achieve victory regardless of their financial status. ## Now that that's cleared up.... ##Although my Steam time doesn't show it, I have played Stronghold Kingdoms via the Standalone client for almost 3 years now and in that time I have been active in many roles. I'm currently on a sort of hiatus with Stronghold Crusader 2 gearing up for release.Anyways, here's what I liked:+ First and foremost is the community, a game that pretty much coerces you into logging in every day lends itself to the establishment of long distance relationships that can become something like a second family to you. + 2D graphics invoke a nostalgic feeling in fans who have been with the Stronghold franchise from it's inception. + Freedom to design my castle as I please, there is no generic 'castle' building that is placed with one click. You have to determine where each wall segment and Stone Tower will be built. + Village building can be as simple or as intricate as you want, village buildings fit together much like a puzzle and those who take the time to optimize their village layout will enjoy increased production.  What I felt could be improved on:- Battles aren't fought in real time, you play puzzle games by setting up your troops and letting the AI resolve it. The AI is quite predictable and stupid at times. - The ingame chat system is so unintuitive it actually drives players away from the game. - The entire card system requires too much micromanagement. For a game that requires more and more of your time as you grow having to juggle cards daily to stay competitive gets pretty old pretty quick. - The formula used to generate AI castles needs to take the number of players in that parish into account, not only the rank of the players. It's a real kick in the head to get the strongest wolf castle in your parish every week when the only 3 villages there are yours. What I'd like to see added in the future:> Castles and villages merged into one design, this would mean that defensively strong players would have weaker economies and the inverse for economically strong players. This would encourage greater diversity in playstyle. > Actual RTS battles that allow direct player control of the attacking armies and the defending garrison if the player so wished. > More units, especially siege units. Even the original Stronghold had twice as many units as there are currently in Stronghold Kingdoms. In short, yes, I strongly recommend this game. It's probably the best free to play RTS on Steam at this moment, and while the graphics hail from a previous decade they still retain the charm of the original Stronghold. - IGN DavidSpy

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												The game's too old, leading to the balances of power across basically all servers being so rigid that as a new (or in my case, returning) player have zero chance of catching up - ESPECIALLY not, if you refuse to pay for premium content, like the ability to build multiple buildings over night. Depending on where you have the misfortune of spawning, you may end up with players that raze your village a few hours after spawn protection ends, stating via in-game message system that "they don't like new players", or a Steward that you have no chance to get rid of while the parish is infested with AI camps, or people that try to force you into their houses by threatening to block the other building places or plainly raid you. Shame! This one was good during the early days, but now it's more or less dying due to the existing structures of power suffocating everything.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												As fun as this game can be, it's simply too short to recommend. There's not enough content to last the average gamer more than an hour at best. But in all seriousness, I cannot recommend this game to anyone who is not already invested in it. Many others have justly criticized the game's pay-to-win nature. If you're a skilled, connected, and active player you can be powerful and successful, but you will still have no chance of victory against players who are also skilled, connected, and active but spend huge sums of money on cards that give them massive gameplay advantages - and you can bet that every new world will be filled with this type of player. As a 'moderate carder' who has been blessed to be part of some excellent factions over the years, this hasn't been as huge a problem for me as it would be for the average player, but it's enough to make me wish I'd known before I started playing.Aside from the pay-to-win issue, my greatest gripe with the game is the attitude of the developers - they simply do not care about anything but money. While worthwhile gameplay updates are occasionally released, they often feel like things that should have been included with the game at launch. To this day there are features I would consider basic and essential that are still missing - like the ability to see your total faith generation per day, or a central page where you can modify the rations, taxes, troops, and castle repairs of all villages at once, instead of unnecessarily spending game time doing these things manually on 40 different village screens. And then there's the issue of rule changes. Starting with Age 1 on Day 0 of a new server, each server progresses through 'ages'. New ages reset land holdings and automatically disband factions, while uniquely changing certain global rules like base army speed and the faith cost of monk abilities. But when World 4 reached Age 4, Firefly was apparently too focused on milking their new Europe server to have even defined the Age 4 ruleset. So the whole server was forced to wait several weeks without any defined goals or any knowledge of what we needed to be preparing for. They finally announced the rules, but when the 4th Age actually began most players were horrified to learn that Firefly had reduced the faction player limit from 40 to 20 without saying ANYTHING. Day 1 of 4th Age, 50% of players found themselves without a faction or house. Factions that had been together for years were forcefully broken apart, and faction leaders were left with having to choose who would be left out. No apology was issued, but few players expected one from a company that was so obviously trying to kill old servers.Worst of all, frequent server issues can ruin your gameplay session and give unfair advantages to some players over others. The launch of a new world is generally accompanied by frequent interruptions. I recall one instance in particular during a war where the login servers went down but the game worlds were still up. A server error booted me out of the game and I was unable to log in again, but my enemies who hadn't been booted had a free 4 hour window to attack me. The number of client errors I've experienced have drastically decreased over the last year, but that's hardly a positive if you expect games to be launched in a playable state.Don't get me wrong, this game can be enjoyed - especially if you're playing with friends or making new friends in a well-managed faction - but recommending it for new players would be like an emphysema patient telling kids to take up smoking.

content:
Posted: April 5
												after playing this game for thousands of hours (standalone non steam launcher) i will finally review stronghold kingdoms.make a big wide circle around this game unless you are willing to either spend alot of money or waste your life away trying to keep up with the players that do.granted, for about 2 years i had good fun playing this game.i had found a well managed faction.was willing to pay money and the concept was still fresh.also,the server where smaller than what they are now.FF doesnt care about you as the player, all they care about is getting your money and the latest "update" changed the rule so that this is blatantly obvious. the one core mechanic that kept the game alive..waging war against other factions/houses...is now locked behind the 2nd highest rank. you can spend alot of money to get to that rank (prince) fast, waste your live playing "rise of the wolf world" for free cards and cardpoints or simply just trying to keep up spending 100's of hours to get to the required rank. i have also played the farming part of this game and its incredibly boring.good luck getting support from FF if you run into problems.customer service is awfull to say the least.they will refer you to the forum or reply to you with pre made one liners.FF doesnt develop this game, they have used the same outdated mechanics for years now and bugs that have been in the game for a long time are still present.all in all, if you dont mind spending alot of time or money on this game..do yourself a favor and stay away from SHK.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												I played this for months many moons ago before it came to Steam. So much potential, wasted because it's completely P2W. The community was great. Everyone was very friendly and helpful and I enjoyed chatting with them all, but the tedious pace of the gameplay eventually wears you down. Eventually you actually start considering buying cards.....just about the time your sanity snaps back and you delete the game instead of wasting your hard earned cash.If you like idle games, this may be fun for you. But you will never be able to keep up with people who pay for cards in this game, and the extremely slow pace will drive you nuts. Everything takes forever to happen in the game.  Cards are the only way to advance at more than a glacial pace, and they really are not worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Stronghold Kingdoms is a griefer heaven; it's even more hardcore than Eve Online. You can spend months and hundreds of dollars building your villages and castles, then lose them all in a matter of minutes to someone else who spent even more months and thousands of dollars. New players will find themselves losing everything they've built on a weekly basis to other players with forces so superior they won't even break a sweat. Unlike other hardcore games like Eve Online, your village can't run or hide. As soon as your "newb shield" drops, your possessions go to feed whoever gets to steal them first. If you're lucky, you'll end up next to someone willing to help you. That just means it will take slightly longer for you to lose all your stuff. Why am I still playing even though I give it a NO recommendation? Because I don't care how many villages I lose as long as there's someone weaker than me, so I can wipe them out and spam them with "GG NOOB MUCH TRYHARDS".You've been warned.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												I played this game alot before on the non-steam version before so i'd like to talk about my experience. It's fun to have economics, politics and war all play essential roles in the game and it's entertaining to play because of nice surprises that happen. However it is extremely time consuming as you have to check up on everything every day or so (especially if you are a steward  or faction leader, or else, bad things will happen... It has happened to me 3 times that when i checked up on the game in the morning, everything and all my villages were gone... isn't that nice... It's also pay to win, some people spend alot of money on this game so they can be ontop, for example if a player is p2w they can reach top rank once a new world starts in an hour because they have purchased so many cards, which can literally do just about anything in the game; add recources, get military units, speed up castle and village buildings, get peasants, get money, get honour. So the requirements to play this are: A small loan of a million dollars. (hehehehe Donald Drumf jokes), another one. And last but not least.... another one. and then you're good to go and rule the world that will forever feel sad and sorry because they can't do anything.... because they can't pay. '-.- *sigh*

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I quit after about 30 minutes, This game is a typical mobile Pay-to-win, unlike what ZAM said (They were paid off or something). You start out with about 4 villagers, and each villager is super important, as they make buildings work, can scout for food, and be turned into military units. You get units by making the overall population happy. you do this by making more space, bribing them, or feeding them. But you can also just PAY REAL MONEY to increase your happiness, or PAY REAL MONEY to buy villagers, you can really just PAY REAL MONEY to do anything in this game, which is why it sucks hard.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Soul-slurping, pay-to-win garbage. Without spending real cash you cannot be competitive. Look at my hours played. Not all of them were actively playing the game but being logged in because if people KNOW you are offline, you'll be attacked if you are a powerful player. I was a powerful player at one point and a "wallet warrior" as I spent a lot more money on this game than I should have (I cringe now when I look at the spreadsheet I made to track my purchases of in-game currency).To be a powerhouse, you are forced to spend lots of money (as in hundreds if not thousands of dollars) to buy premium tokens and card packs (which usually contain garbage). You can earn cards without cash, but it's not easy or a productive use of time. The price of "booster packs" are insane, especially their Ultimate Packs (which cost almost 5 bucks a pop!). I've opened them and gotten nothing but common cards which is a complete rip-off.There are a lot of people who cheat at this game by account-sharing, using 3rd party programs, etc. You cannot win against these people. You can't catch them unawares and they just keep coming back like herpes to attack you when you are offline and are unable to effectively defend yourself. Reporting them does nothing. If they spend money in the game, the developer will let them get away with almost anything.Also, servers quickly become stagnant once one group of whales and their tag-alongs achieve world domination. Once this happens, most people just leave the server and go to a new one, which is why they keep opening new servers all the time. This stagnation is probably deliberate as the very start of a server is when the developer makes all their money due to the whales blowing cash to try to race to the top first.Avoid this game like the plague unless you want no life and like spending your way to the top.

												I spent a lot of time playing and only got rekt by my own choice (quit). This will not be your experience cause somehow i went unnoticed long enough to become a major merchant powerhouse and then the others finally seen how many goods I was shipping constantly and tried to attack me. I build up defense in 2 days. I had none, was mega merchant. Took a few losses while researching the final towers those 2 days. Had a couple clans trying to smash me and they couldnt. I quit because it was sapping my life away and if i didnt keep up 16+ hours a day  i was gonna lose anyways cause I had the gold and they wanted it. Im sure its MUCH worse now as that was years ago. Your expeience wont be so good cause somehow i was lucky enough to not be attacked and a few times i bluffed that i would smash clans if they continued marching towards me (had to be there that minute or else you would get smashed). I watched everyone around me who was even slightly older player than me get smashed. I used this to my advantage sometimes to take down clan members who were often scouting me. I got lucky. Real lucky.  Dont play.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Played this game will over 1000 hours, and have a good amount of hours off steam as well. And one thing i have to say about this game is its extremely addictive. The start of the game can be a bit slow and boring but once you figure everything out and know what research is best for what you need and all around aspects of the game, its really fun. End game and joining a house is a big part of it and makes the game that much funner. Many people say its P2W, yet the cards do help extremely, it doesnt mean that someone without cards can't wreck too. There are treasure castles in order to get card points and card packs to keep up with all the cards. Theres also free cards weekly and quests in order to earn some extra rewards. Eventually, once you meet people and unify, the game becomes much more open and you dont have to pay a dime. I reccomend the steam starter pack, which will help you boost passed those beginning levels and get to dominating.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Well, when I first played this game a year ago, I loved it. It downloaded fast and was able to play in seconds. It was fun, exciting and good to play while doing something else. The beginning was rough, it seemed like impossible to get to an acceptable rank. Luckily I was invited to join a group of other nearby lords who later in the game invited me to the House. When I was first invited the game went smoothly because of all the support my allies gave me. Soon after I was a target for an enemy House. Of course this House member payed to get insane amount of cards, tokens and etc., and then I got destroied. I didn't pay into this game, but now I see I should. There is such a huge advantage against people who pay-to-win. I seriously don't agree with ZAM, stating "it is not a pay-to-win". It is. Again I tried playing again later down the year and of course the same thing happened on a different server. I thought this was ridiculous and a joke. I quit and wouldn't even bother playing with the new update. 4/10.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												   I liked the overall idea of the game, some of the graphics, and the possible interaction with others in the game, but that is about as far as it goes.   The progression is extremely slow, from harvesting supplies, building structures, recruiting armies, to advancement of learning. Costs for structures, armies, and such are too high in my opinion based on the length of time to aquire them. The quests in the game are decent with one exception. You can only have one atcive at a time and if something happens while you are offline that would have completed an inactive quest for you, you missed out. This game takes way too much time in my opinion to be worth it. Oh and it offers a protection period when you start the game, however, I was attacked by the AI bandits before my protection was over and lost all my army and spent most of my supplies rebuilding my castle.( which took hours)   You could spend real money to advance, but what is the point when it gets wasted after you are attacked and cannot repair your castle or rebuild your army before the next attack. Even for a free game I wouldn't try it.

content:
Posted: January 17
Title: "Stronghold Kingdoms"Release Date: 28 Feb, 2012Developer: FireFly StudiosPublisher: FireFly StudiosGenre / Tags: Free to Play, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy1. OverviewYou have to forget about your real life and live only in this game if you wanna to achieve a really high results in this game... or... the second way is... constantly spend a large sums on donations...2. GameplayThe lack of donate feels particularly acute when you have two or more villages: warehouses are limited and you have to sell each package from the tons of your resources separately, after this you have to wait at the time when the traders sells them, the numbers of traders are also limited and they have the limited load; without donations every soldier in your army should be recruited personally by you from the peasants, but you must wait from few tens of minutes to several hours when each of them will come to your village; you don't see any statistics of your villages and each of all the parameters of the village must be checked and set or changed personally by you in the manual mode in each of your villages.So, "donations" is an automatic mode of the game, "without donations" - your personal time and only the manual mode almost to any of the aspects in the game.Also, don't expect to see your village intact if you decide to have a rest a little time and don't launch the game for a few days. Constant attacks of AI or others players will partially destroy your castle and you must almost every day launch the game and manually repair your castles in each villages, districts or capitals.3. VerdictThis game is the game of donations, "farmers" and the unapproachable castles - often you can find the castles which never can't be successfully stormed only by you or almost impossible to be successfully stormed by you and all your allies together.This is an unique online game with this setting and concept, good continuation of the first part of the "Stronghold"... but all the beauty of this game can being received only with donations...Don't start to play this game... Be free...4. RecommendationsIf you like the games with the such theme, I can advise...Similar games: "Stronghold" (2001).

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												If you want a decent enough game completely ruined by the pay to win factor then this is the game for you. The in game system for buying cards means that while it might not be a complete trade off for time put in the huge advantage of paying makes it a bad game to play. Cards can be used for army units, resources (including ones that help you level up and gain access to more technology and such), faster movement and more. Add on to that the fact if you get special tokens (using real money) you get building queues, tech queues and auto scouting / attacks.Overall it isn't a bad game but the pay to win aspect does make it bad if you are not willing to invest loads for every advantage. Generally one of those games about long term however long term for me doesn't include having to constantly pay to be on par with other players.Generally speaking knowledge and such will only go so far when everything is lacking compared to a heavily paying user.EDIT:Almost 2 years later tried to access game only to find out my account is locked out and I had to contact customer support. It seems customer support is "investigating" issues with payments in the past so either they can't do anything in almost 2 years or they are just banning me for paying them and having issue with the service. AVOID LIKE  THE PLAGUE.

												If you want to buy your victory play this. If you want rule because you earned it... Good luck. I find this a failed attempt, I play this game quite a bit, but that's only because Mobile is on the way. I feel if firefly gave this another try with natural geological formations instead of a flat boring same as everyone else's land, and if they didn't use these gimmicky cards, I believe this game would do way better, just slap a 15.00$ tag. Trust me, you'd make way more money off of sales in units compared to 3.00$ card sets... All in all, it sounds food on paper, executed poorly.But, it is free, and the game actually does have a cool diplomacy system, and castle building is a waiting game but it's really pleasing watching your castle develop.There is a wait time in building though, something used in cash cow money grubbing Clash of Clans mobile games, that's probably what killed this, it doesn't work because Firefly has a relatively small fanbase, being a "AA" company as said by the head of the marketing department , Nick.  [{6/10}]I hope Firefly makes another Castle MMO and doesn't make it so harsh on new players, and Firefly, whatever you do, DO NOT make the next one a free to play, and completely scrap the use of cards, this isn't yu-gi-oh. Not a bad idea, but not well executed. [/u]

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												I originally played this back in summer 2012 and returned summer 2014 to see what had improved. But like all free to play games it just has too many limitations and timers to recommend on a long term basis.What's good - Watching your village becoming fully operational, scouting, trading, researching and seeing the occasional level up process, watching the battles from bandit camps, wolf lairs or your castle keepWhat's bad - timeframe limits, the only thing that stops this is Maths but ultimately everything just takes too much time unless you play an insta-build card or time speed card and even then it only lasts a few hours. Castle building takes days, village building takes hours, raising your own military requires several researches and buildings which you "must" have unless you like being attacked regularly by the AI and having no means of defending yourself thus losing resources. The card system is a mess and you have to click through them until you find what you wanted at the time. 7 day premium tokens and cards are where they want you to pay but really unless you can fully use a 7 or 30 day token dont even bother. If you want me paying Â£3 a throw I expect a 30 day token, not a 7 day one, I think the 7 day ones should be scrapped entirely. But back to my point, you need merchants+speed, scouts+speed, max housing capacity and military to fully get your moneys worth from the tokens, all of which takes time. The biggest thing that kills the game however is research, once you run out of RP you either need to level up or spend gold to get more, Philosophy helps with this but like Maths it's a temporary fix at best.Conclusion - when I first played I was around a few weeks and then left, there were several things I never got to experience like trading for gold or helping a house/faction take an area while watching big all out battles occur, never raided a vilage, never done parish heals, and it goes on and on because the game is basically a giant timesink even with a premium token. Does the token speed everything up? No! Does the token provide you with extra research points? No! And guess what...when you use a token it ONLY applies to the world you were in instead of applying to ALL worlds, sorry but I want my 7 or 30 days to cover all worlds that I play instead of just the 1, forcing you to buy several tokens for the worlds you do play in assuming you can get any fun or enjoyment out of this game. Sorry Stronghold Kingdoms but ultimately you dont offer enough benefits to justify the time spent in the game and you don't do things you SHOULD be doing. Personally I dont have the time to stay up and wait for a timer to end just so I can see the end result. Which means I wont spend the money for cards and/or tokens unless I felt like I was getting proper value for money. You can do better and you can implement changes like what you did for banner creation or the recent avatar update. Give us players more options, more choices, scrap the 7 day token and make the 30 day one viable for 3 pounds a throw, give somebody like me enough of a reason to play and it's a very viable F2P game. But until you do these things I cannot recommend the game long term. This ends my review.FusionBunny

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Oh dear, Oh dear.Before I begin, I would like to point out the major problem I have with most "free to play" games, Well, two.1. They suck2. They seem to all be based of the "Farmvile Forumla"Do not get me wrong, there are plenty of Free to Play games that do not do that, like Tribes Ascend, Star Trek Online after the F2P conversion, and a few others that operate on the concept of "Pay because you're having fun and want to support it." not "Pay because you have to." Those games are fine. Hell, I enjoy playing STO still, even after the F2P change.Stronghold Kingdoms, on the other hand..is a medival reincarnation of Farmvile, but even more hands off! I came into the game expecting a cut-down version of Stronghold, but what I got out of it was pretty much like the fabled "Age of Empires Online".When you're put into the game, you're given a basic tutorial, and some things to help. Sadly, it's not much (unless you preordered Crusader 2, or bought the starter pack for some reason), and even if you manage to make do, it's only a matter of time before you run into some barrier, like lack of resources or even not having enough gold. When that happens, you either have to bug your friends, making them hate your guts forevermore, or get your credit card and pay up, which, again, seem very much like the Facebook games we're all spammed with.So then, would I reccomend this game? Are you joking?!  It makes me worry for the future of a decent series, being all pay to win and such.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												If you want a decent enough game completely ruined by the pay to win factor then this is the game for you. The in game system for buying cards means that while it might not be a complete trade off for time put in the huge advantage of paying makes it a bad game to play. Cards can be used for army units, resources (including ones that help you level up and gain access to more technology and such), faster movement and more. Add on to that the fact if you get special tokens (using real money) you get building queues, tech queues and auto scouting / attacks.Overall it isn't a bad game but the pay to win aspect does make it bad if you are not willing to invest loads for every advantage. Generally one of those games about long term however long term for me doesn't include having to constantly pay to be on par with other players.Generally speaking knowledge and such will only go so far when everything is lacking compared to a heavily paying user.EDIT:Almost 2 years later tried to access game only to find out my account is locked out and I had to contact customer support. It seems customer support is "investigating" issues with payments in the past so either they can't do anything in almost 2 years or they are just banning me for paying them and having issue with the service. AVOID LIKE  THE PLAGUE.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												A free time sink. Enjoyed it for a little while because I like the medival time period and some of the sound design felt good but quickly became repetitive. Like with many games that require extended amounts of real world time to build things it quickly became a chore rather than an enjoyable experience and my hours on the game mainly involved leaving it on in the background. Stopped playing after a few months but I still remember playing it and having some fun with the politics and interactions.If you know what your getting yourself into go ahead but if you are looking for a multiplayer strategy game there are many other titles.

Posted: October 14, 2015
												Please do not support this game.  At first it seems like a cool game and fun.  But after you get into it you cannot really do anything worth while unless you have no life and can play 24/7 and if you are willing to spend hundreds of dollars if not thousands on buying cards.  The staff that support this game are crooks all the way up to the producers.  They will do things with your account and say too bad so sad we messed you up it is our fault but too bad you can suffer no matter how much they messed you up or how much money you spent or time on the game.  To even be in the top houses which seem to be all be run by the most arrogant ignorant gang like thugs.  People seem to support and follow these people yet a lot of these people are not even good at the game or are very nice people or even have any kind of good leadership qualities.  Yet people follow them and they run the show like a cult. And if you are not in it forget ever winning. After years of play you really end up with a bad experiance in the end.  Takes a year just to finish the first glory round even if you do make it and the map is dominated.  Maps usualy become totaly dominated by one group of people and thats it.  Do not expect fair play from players or the staff.Do Not Buy this game and waste your time and money.  So many better games out there.

												I've enjoyed being a part of this medieval version of a modern day soap opera with catapult's since Alpha started a few years ago,, (only just started playing it through steam) and have been delighted by most of the recent patches,, which made trading a lot easier,, sped my armies up,,gave me more defensive cards.. content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												This game was fun for what it was, but after waking up to log in and find that my castle had been ransacked and my only village taken over by a player of higher level it just left a nasty feeling in my gut.Now if you were like me and lost your only village all is not lost you can setup a new village retain your rank and some other stats and are given some basic resources to start rebuilding and you are protected from attack for a couple of days so you can try again, but that doesn't seem that fun to me...All those hours of collecting resources, building improvements, new buildings, conducting new research so I have access to said improvements and buildings. I can't say this game is worth the time if you lose almost everything you have been working towards.If you like spending many hours working on something and then see it vanish by all means have at it. For now I am just going to shelve this one for now.Also they need more variety in units what they got seems to be a bit minimalist to me but eh to each their own.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												A clock watching game.That's pretty much what you'll spend all your time doing. It takes a lot of time and resources to do anything, and each time you do something it'll only cost more next time. Pretty obvious from the get-go that if you want anything interesting you have to pay. In all it's simply an endless grind. Farm stuff, build the castle, keep peasants happy and recruit them into soldiers, watch other dudes attack your castle, repair the castle, repeat for eternity. It's not a bad time waster, and it's too bad I haven't had a chance to really try the feudalism simulator they have going on; but I'd say your time and money is much better spent on the HD Stronghold and Crusader games.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												The game as a whole can be fun but the gameplay itself is often very tedious and boring.  The best aspects of the game are the politcs: joining a guild, interacting with your allies and using your combined numbers to accomplish something.  Whether it be getting a certain person elected head of a county or conquering all the villages belonging to a certain House in a region its the politics where the game is interesting.But the actual game mechanics themselves are boring; often extremely boring.  Most of the time I spent playing I was actually surfing the internet and only occasionally checking in on what was happening.  Things can move very slowly.  Wars can be frustrating as well since the game lets you spend money to protect your castles from attack.  You'll often find yourself logging on after work or school to find half your villages have been conquered and they are immune to attack for several days so you have no way of getting them back.  And these are villages you've spent months building up only to have it all thrown away when you weren't even playing.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												The game is alright, I played it way before it even came to steam when it was just browser based. It's till stronghold for the most part but it's completely online. Sounds like cool fun right? How about no. This is strictly one of those broswer based Facebook style games in every sense of the word and has no business on steam. It's "P2W" and timer based like every other free-to-play RTS out there. Nothing ruins a game more than getting neck deep into it just to find out you HAVE to quit for 6 hours because there's nothing left to do. Seriously, it's going to take that long for some of your buildings to complete construction. If you like these kinds of games and find the majority of your free time syphoned by similar games on Facebook, go for it. If you're a serious Stronghold fan however, avoid this monstrosity at all costs.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												SHK is not really a simulation nor a tactical challenge, for new players there can be fun grinding ability levels but this is ultimately  pointless as in the long run as no matter what you research or how many cards you buy you cannot protect your villages. The game world runs 24/7 which means that unless you do without sleep completely or get someone else to play your account  when you are offline (bannable offense) then all your work can be stolen or destroyed. Yes you can in turn steal or rebuild replacements but that is not what makes this game special.This game is special not because of the graphics/sound/game logic which are windows 95 era ,it is special because it is a mirror of all the worst possible human behaviour, motivations and emotions. All the offensive behaviour of the worst politicians and criminals, all the abusive and maladjusted behaviour of pychopaths is promoted and rewarded by this game.Truely once you have played this game for a few months then you are going to be drawn into things that would not only get you put in prison but also shuned by any civilised society if you tried them in real life. It is one thing to play games like GTA where you can abuse bots and act out being bad but in this game you will end up abusing real people, intimidation, verbal abuse, haressment all are standard techniques employed by the veterens (I say veterans  because they are mostly over 40 and are often retired and so need less sleep) to win each game. If you play for long enough then you are going to be wading in the slime of the dregs of society and hence become desensitized to abberant behaviour such that you are likely to have problems in real life.To top it off the support agents will know that once you have put a few hundred hours in that you are an addicted deviant and will treat you like a retard, the game is buggy and often fails to work as advertised but your chances of getting any money back are slim at best.Lastly during my few thousand hours of play a number of people really died or became seriously ill, I would say because of the stress related to going without sleep, healthy exercise and the constant high levels of negative emotions this game evokes.Personally I think this game should be made to carry a health warning but I would also say the company have even less morals than the players so I guess it balances out.

You only have to look at the number of hours I have played this game to see I enjoy it (I have probably played just as many hours in the stand alone client as on steam!)However it is also evidence of the downside to this game, it has a tendency to take a hold of players that get very involved in the game. It can be hard to leave the game alone and you will find yourself thinking about the game when you perhaps should be focused on something more productive. This is only exacerbated by the persistent nature of the game and, for the most part, the awesome community that support this game. There is also a pay to win aspect to this game, as you might have noticed by the other reviews.  Some benefits are only available to those who invest not only time but money into the game., But you have to remember the game has to be supported and without money the developers canât do this. Hiding features behind a paywall though is never popular and it is something I can not defend. Automated trading and having a requirement to put money into the game in order to unlock more than a measly number of free in game stratagy cards are two of such features I would point out. However as long as you know this going into the game you shouldnât be disappointed. It may take you longer to achieve your goals in Stronghold Kingdoms if you play it entirely Free To Play, you may also have a hard time going up against people who play it Pay To Win (and know what theyâre doing) but thereâs no reason why you still canât have a lot of fun playing this game and meat a lot of cool and interesting people along the way.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Okay, so SHK wanted players to give feedbacks and review of the game so here it goes. First off to those that does not know the game, it takes a long long long time for ages to pass on different worlds and they never seem to be ending soon so I will give some feedbacks on the future of the game and for future new ages(which desperatly needs to warp up and end really really soon.Edit: The end game is finally going to come (Not too soon but soon lol) so thats a plus at least for me. Why? Because the game will die out if there is no implementation of this said end game. Anywho, on to the review! :)Intro: As for the game itself, well reviewing this kind of game is going to be a tough one since its really different from any other game I had ever played. To keep it short, SHK is a game somewhat like trivian or tribal-wars which are real-time based (Build your kingdom type)strategy games. Of cause SHK is much more complex and beautifully complicated than any other MMO out there. Just know that these kind of games will suck in all of your time and all the beautifully built villages that you have put so much time and effort can easily be taken away over night. Yes that's right, over night! But that is not so much of a bad thing because thats what makes the game very interesting and complex. Yes you can lose your villages but the honor, gold, faith points and rank will remain the same even if you lose all your villages. Keep in mind these such points are the important part of the game, not villages, so that is a good thing that you dont lose your progress. Gameplay / Graphics As for the gameplay, this is a straight forward build your kingdom and expend it at all costs. It can be time consuming, very very much so. I had played this for over 3 years on and off and I can never get on top of the leaderboards yet. Also, there are groups(factions and houses) where you join and fight for that particullar group. These houses either ally themselves with one another or declare war on each other because the main goal of the game is to win the glory race. The gloary race can be won if a house can eliminate all other houses thus the last house is ultimately the winner of the race. You get big rewards if you win the race that can be used to give some perks on the world you are playing and on every other worlds.Graphics on this game is taken almost 100% taken out of the original "Stronghold Crusader" game that came out over a decade ago but thats not a bad thing either since that was one of the best games ever created, ever. They did improve on the quality of the game though so its really well done. This is a stretegy game not a 4K graphic driven game so graphics doesn't really matter. P2W(Pay 2 Win? Well, many of the reviews here are stating that it is a P2W game and I won't try to argue it because to an extent you can progress much faster with the cards in the game but it will only get you so far as to how much you are willing to spend on a free game and hornestly you really don't get much advantage over other. It is totally possible to get to the top without spending a single dime on this game. Just need a lot of hard work. --- I would say this is 10% P2W and 90% hardwork.Final Verdict: Yeah I would totally recommend trying to game out especailly if you are a big RTS-MMO fan and even if you are not its just fun to grow your village and take over other people and fight for glory. Just try to out, don't let these stupid one sentence "BAD!" "P2W" BS of a review get in your way of a great game. My score of this game is 7.5 or 8 out of 10.
