												Brilliant MMO, I love the castle building and warfare and the way it has the characters from the other Stronghold games such as the Rat, Wolf, Pig and Snake. The researching and honour system is genius but I believe it could improve by adding a farming mode/Capture only world like in the original Stronghold games were the was a construction mode where you could build in peace I would love for that to be added also.The new Wolf AI world was very fun to play as there was a feeling of unity from the community that is rare in most games these days as everyone worked together to defeat the AI and take control of their world.Over-all it's a brilliant game and I reccomend it to everyone however I'd like my idea of the farm world/Construction World to be considered.Cheers, iAura

												The problem with playing this game on Steam is if you have a Client version and you want to play that on Steam rather than using the Client version, it is impossible because you have to create a separate account which would be against the rules made by Firefly even if you attempt to change it to Steam.  I would not recommend this game if you are playing with the Client version of the game since you would have to start over and playing off Steam would be using two accounts rather than one.  If they would allow you to move the account onto Steam without any problems of turning off your Client version and keep the Username of the Client on Steam, then I would recommend this game if people like playing this game off Steam rather than the Client version.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												First of all this Game is not for everyone unless you get in with a good house who fights if not most likely your house will be eliminated. I like it for the constant excitement that waking up in the morning I could be reset at anytime (being reset means all your villages have either been captured or destroyed) even with the strongest build we will still get in and take it over, waves and waves of troops timed attacks and your village is mine or mine is yours. it's Medieval village management and castle building.there are no vehicles except your horses and trading carts you start on a plot of land and start building you get villagers who do all the hard work of growing and collecting food and supplies like wood stone pitch & iron so you can build your castles. run the right tax amount they will stay put it to high they will leave so it's your own little kingdom so to speak and you manage it. there are research tasks you can do to make life a little easier like troop and peasants you can research everything make your scouts faster to pick up items on around your castles make your troops stonger. Now monks are the key to winning or losing a battle so you want those first because as time goes on and you research so many things it takes 16 to 20 hours to research one thing so you need to do the important ones first you just need to figure out what those are. same as the village buildings go the further up you are in rank the slower it becomes to build. now you can play this without ever spending any money I have played it for a long time without spending any money but I never got very far. you can only research 1 thing at a time not 5 and you can only build 1 thing at a time in your village without the use of a premium token, there are a few different ones you can spend your real money on a 30 Day  premium token will allow you to do so much 5 research tasks 5 village buildings in queue to build, it also allows you to trade while your offline. the premium token allows your scouts to seek out stashes while your offline you can also attack a chosen target when your logged out, you also get idle peasants into your army and this right here is so useful too because when you get too many of these they make your village popularity go down and this will result in them leaving also. another thing the premium token does is allow you to keep track of what has happened while your offline and why they don't do this for the people that don't play with cards is beyond me, So like if a player scouts your village you won't even know they are prepairing to attack you unless you run a premium token so in my opinion it is pay to play because if you don't pay you lose you can spend 5 bucks and get a premium token and some playing cards to help your villages. this game is a very political game I have seen players run 5 different accounts they could be your enemy and join your faction on another account just to see what your faction is up to who they are planning to attack it's a very hard game to start out fresh in not knowing who the real players of the game are. anyone who claims to be your friend on this game is lying because they are looking at angles to take you out if you don't belong to a house your a target, if your in a faction and not a house your still a target. So the A.I in this game is set up so the higher in rank you go the harder they hit you I have had an entire side wiped out of my castle and by doing this it will set you back a few days in build time but you get honor who the F cares about honor when your castle gets wiped out 2 times a day by the A.I but wait it's not over here comes another attack and another and another they don't start doing a lot of damage till you are a prince but they do even more damage when you become a crown prince. so now that you have been offline for a few days and people take notice that you have been attacked by all kinds of A.I they know your castle has been badly damaged and they take advantage and scout you they see the damage and take over your village.https://gyazo.com/bef6ef0755292602660b1b5013f2aece this is here  my castle completed.so this is a design I got off the internet this is what I have built but without the use of cards it took 71 Days to finish and all that time I was being attacked everyday unless your in a capitol parish and that person fights all the A.I forget about trying to build, like I said this game is not for everyone. I will update this as I go but for now getting into this game right now may be a waste of time because the end is coming. When you have a build like this it will survive a lot of attacks but it's hard to put everything back 


this is the newest design & survived 6 timed attacksÂ

By: Charley Tank




or a design like this and this design has held up to 6 timed attacks and still survived the fight


This is my New Castle design.Â 
A Screenshot of Stronghold Kingdoms
By: Charley Tank




 think about researching castle designs if you plan on playing this game for long. These two here were completed with cards in just 1 hour but at a huge cost.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Could have been good for a free game, but it will wear at your patience faster than mine!It's finally got me - I cannot play this anymore, ain't nobody got time for that! Shame as this could have been a really good game. I have a lot of patience, even for really REALLY slow games like this one, but this has finally got me. You may find it entertaining and fun at first as I did, and the map is very good, but as it rapidly slows down, it becomes increasingly frustrating, and even multiple villages/worlds cannot keep you busy and entertained.If you want to feel pressured into spending money on a 'free' game to succeed, or want to end up staring blankly at your villagers making repetitive movements while you wait an hour to build each building, send out a scout or start each research, and have every intention of playing this daily (as your village gets wiped after a few days of non-play, and you will in the most part have to start over), then sure, I guess this is the game for you. If you can log on.I really wanted to love this game, I gave it a very good run.... but I've had enough, and I dont feel like waiting around on it this week :(

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												As a casual player I cannot recommend this. I play it because I enjoy the castle building element. I've built up a large number of castles over the span of a year, but the truth is someone could fire off a couple cards and raze every single one of my castles in an hour, if they wanted to, and there's nothing I could do about it. (Edit: This happened)It's a timer-based persistent world game so it is closer to a browser game than your typical PC game. The castle building element is akin to a facebook game in complexity, the quest system is just ok, the combat is automatically resolved.I also have tons of cards which are the things you pay for, and I really don't see the use of any of them. This dated game just isn't very good. The only praise I have for it is that clan-based persistent worlds can have some fun player politics in them.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Could have been good for a free game, but it will wear at your patience faster than mine!It's finally got me - I cannot play this anymore, ain't nobody got time for that! Shame as this could have been a really good game. I have a lot of patience, even for really REALLY slow games like this one, but this has finally got me. You may find it entertaining and fun at first as I did, and the map is very good, but as it rapidly slows down, it becomes increasingly frustrating, and even multiple villages/worlds cannot keep you busy and entertained.If you want to feel pressured into spending money on a 'free' game to succeed, or want to end up staring blankly at your villagers making repetitive movements while you wait an hour to build each building, send out a scout or start each research, and have every intention of playing this daily (as your village gets wiped after a few days of non-play, and you will in the most part have to start over), then sure, I guess this is the game for you. If you can log on.I really wanted to love this game, I gave it a very good run.... but I've had enough, and I dont feel like waiting around on it this week :(

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Though the game itself is fun to play at first. It heavilly follows the pay to win model of gaming that doesn't work with the majority of people, who don't have money to spare. I went into the game expecting the average free to play game, of no initial cost, with a cash shop. They do have this, but the encourage you to spend money you may not have in order to do a ton of things.One of the major beefs I have, is it's Premium Service. They encourage you, everytime you log off, that if you don't have it to get it. And that makes sense to do something like that. But the concept of 'Commanding even when you are off' Breaks the balance of the game.Here is why:Say you have two players near each other in-game. One of them, who we will name James, has a weekly job and a family. He plays a few  games online during the weekend and days off. He also can't afford to buy Crowns. Now, we also have another player, we will name him Jack. Jack lives with his parents and goes to highschool. His father has a good job, and so pays Jack a large allowence that he can spend on anything. He spends it on Crowns every time. Say he also gets the Premium Service and sets everything to max.James, the man with a job, will have the things Jack, the teenager, at a much slower rate due to money spent on the game.And so, I declare Stronghold Kingdoms, as a Pay to Win game. Not a Free to Play game. For anyone interested, avoid.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Well, I'm a new player... Needless to say im getting buttâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥by my stronger neighbors around me. Starting the game: It gives you a 2 day taste of the full premium experience... but only for 2 days... In these 2 days you can advance rather rapidly, building 7 buildings 1 after the other, and in general just feeling like the game is not broken. You also get a 2 day slot of "no one can attack me" which is great, I mean people would always then attack the newbie for easy resources. You research you expand very rapidly and then your protection is gone!Mid Game:This is when the game starts to fail... there is no limit for those players that are substantially stronger to just go and wipe out smaller players. This game is not new player friendly! Immediatly after ym protection is gone I get raided by my super powerful neighbor, he first sends 20 peasants. Nothing too bad right! Then he just swarmes me 3 times untill I fall and eviscerates what was once my wooden fortress. New players have no way to defend themselves once their premium trial is over and their "spawn Protection" is over. Features: I love the research system, makes you think ahead. As well as teh fortress system. I hate the preimium Pay2Win ability. The fact that higher ranking players can just swarm your village every 2 days to plunder you for your resources. They also don't need to micro as much as the newbies since they have 7 buildings building which takes up to 4 hours whereas the newbie has 1 and that takes 20 min tops. The game is jsut not newbie friendly, espeicially since its pay2win... someone suggested a one time payment method, I wish that was a thing sicne id rather pay 5 or 10 bucks for the game and have a balanced fair game... But no...The day microtransactions lose their ability to give players better weapons or in this case, just the full game, and lose their ability in general to give players an advantage is the day that MMO's might make soem sort of a comeback!

content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

												highly adictive, i have twice as many hours on the server that are not registered on steam.if you have a lot of of free time and want a drug to take out of the real world this is the game for you.I kicked the habit like two years ago, just went back now to check out the new worlds but iÂ´ll not get sucked into that again.some people say itÂ´s pay to win, i dunno, by the time i was playing i got a lot of free crowns and cards from amazon, they had a reward for registering at the time. and i only made 2 minimum purchases to activate the quest meter to receive cards at maximum speed. But i havent even spent the crowns i bought, just a few(i still have 1k crowns sitting around), not even all of the ones i got for free from amazon, and I was one of the strongest players in world 4 two years ago.So I dont think itÂ´s pay to win, you need premium tokens ofc, but not all the time and you get many from quests and if amazon is still giving crowns you can get like a year of premium with those, unless you want to be the king, I assume then you would need to spend some cash, but I managed to run 8 parishes at once and became the governor of the province, started a faction, which i named 'The Night's whatch', and it got really strong, the house i belonged ruled over 2 of the 4 countries, I had like 50 vassals, all of that without spending crowns or barely spending. itÂ´s a lot to handle.Obs. i noticed now people have way more villages than it was possible when i played, so the numbers above may seem insignificant, but 2 years ago you could hardly get any more powerful than that.In short, great game, but be careful, cocaine may seem great at first too

Posted: December 12, 2013
												I have loved the whole Stronghold franchise and was excited that this MMO version came out.  It was fun for the first week or so building up my little village.  Every building takes real time to build and it is ever increasing so I build a hut and then check back 2 days later to build a wood cutter shack and then check back 3 days later to build a farm then, check back 4 days later to discover that everything was destroyed by another player.  Awesome.  I get to start all over.  Ill stick with the RTS version.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												To make 1 thing clear real quick, don't let my number of hours fool you. The reason I have so many hours is because I used to keep the game running in the background while I slept or played other games. I have not actually put +2000 hours into this game.It's fun, but its pay to win. Otherwise you best stay away from other players. Takes months to build up 1 village to complete size, just so you can lose it overnight and wake up to seeing you need to start all over. Takes forever since anytime you place a building or research a class, your next building/class costs 2x more time (which leads to hours, then days and so on), and same with resources, that doubles, take that feature away, and the "pay to win" feature, and it'd be a great game. Make it to where you earn cards through quests, make your buildings take instead about 10 sec - 5 minutes to build (Depending on the building), and make premium the only thing you gotta pay for, and it'd be a great game. Otherwise, you'll find yourself bored of it in the first 10 minutes and a little let down when a village you worked so hard on is taken so easily. Also an offline mode would be nice, building your empire just dealing with AI castles and bandit camps and so on, or a co-op mode where you and a small faction of friends are doing so. I dunno. I do like the camera view a lot though, great looks. But although I do play this when I'm bored and have nothing else to do. I don't reccomend it. Get the other Stronghold games. Those are better.

												Well ive played this game for soo long now.. and i still suck at it...but always come back to it..... Whether you love this game or hate this game you have to admit its very addictive.... for any newcomers i would suggest read up everything you can before playing this... as although it may look basic there is a lot to learn about it... and the fewer mistakes you make earlier on in the game the better the experience will be ( yes i messed up many times for not reading )     This game is not a pay to win game... although it does drastically help with card packs premium tokens etc... and if your not at war with another player ( which is definetely not always the case ) then buying tokens just enhances the game and helps you on your way...makes it more fun....but you dont need to buy tokens... ive played over 1000 hours on this game (steam version 624 hours) and have hardly bought any tokens ( twice i spent maybe Â£6 that was it) and ive had plenty enjoyment from it.   Game is free so have a go :)

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Stronghold Kingdoms is in my opinion the best city building stragey game i have ever played online and i have tried quite a few. this game is very unique in that you have AIs to attack and also they attack you such as all 4 of the AI castles from the stronghold line of games such as the rat which is the easiest to deal with up to the wolf which is hardest. Thier are also wolf lairs, bandit camps which you attack for quests or just honor. the game is based on an honor system u advace by gaining honor. THe game icorperates a research system you can do very little without researching to do it first from building diferent buildings to troop types and even religion. There is an extensive religious system where you use monks to do things like heal deseases and protect ur villages and things of that nature. The maps r devided into parishes, counties, statesand countries. these parishes require a person (called a steward) this person takes charge and builds builds in the parish that help the others who live in the parish this can range from use troops there to take out the AIs to building guilds which when upgraded give benifits to all citizens within that parish. You can join with other players in your area to form factions and house these factions and house go through what is known as a glory race in which they r trying to be the only one left at the end of the race winning house of this race at the end of an age get fabulous in game prizes. There are four ages each with it's own unique set of rules. There are also cards that allow u to do things in the game like make your troops faster, make free troops,  help production of goods, all kinds of diferent things. As I hope u can see from just vthis breif discription of the game that it has alot to offer you many hours of great enjoyable play time. I would very highly recomened this game to all stratagy city building game lovers even if you have never played a game like this I would encourage anyone who likes online gaming to give it  a try.SpitfireSam

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Stronghold KingdomsWhat should i say about this? Its a GREAT MMO. I could write a Book about it. Its just awesome with all the possibilitys, the most awesome feature is: The Players decide the Game. You can join a house/faction. And these factions are allied or at war with other factions its possible for you and your clan/faction to just conquer the world!You can even become a spy, join the enemy faction, work your way up (pretend to had a fight with your own faction) and destroy the enemy from the inner.The possibility are endless since the world is player driven!AND ANY BODY WHO TALKS ABOUT PAY 2 WIN: JUST STFU, IDIOTS! it is definitly NOT P2W! It doesnt really matter if you pay or not. Its just the usual: make things easier with real money. And whats the problem. the devs/publisher need to earn money. You think they are making games for free, idiots?!What you get for Money is a premium account so you can qeue buildings and research. good when you go to work or something.And you can buy card packs with RANDOM Cards. like your scouts reach the location sooner 2000 wood, and so on. Thats not gamebreaking, just a kickstart for newer settlements (you can have up to 20+).You even get cards without money, and the REAL good cards like, instant building or instant research (1 time use only!) are REALLY rare. since you open card packs like in yugioh or fifa ultimate team, you dont know what you get. most time you get cards that help you a little. so stfu idiots!

												I would recommend this game only to those who have patience and confience in themselves. Too many people blame this game for 'wasting' their time, which is quite untrue. If you feel you are wasting your time playing SHK it is probably because you are not playing properly. You must balance all aspects of the game and prioritize accordingly. One great quality about the game is that it is very unforgiving, which is why finding amazing and supportive teammates is so important. Once you sift through the players, you'll find a niche of awesome, helpful and resourceful gamers who want to kickâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥as a team. Be patient learning, ask players around you for advice and explore all options because it IS a big game and there are many ways to fall behind, so it is always a constant challenge and quite rewarding when you succeed! gl hf! :)Miss Jupiter

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												I'm not proud of the fact that I ended up giving up over two thousand hours of my life to this piece of crap. It was terrible â¥â¥â¥â¥ing addiction that I'm glad I got over. I got the starter pack free with Stronghold HD and this rubbish has been stuck in my library ever since.The fact that they recycled a lot of the assets(graphics, music, sounds, etc.) in this game from the first Stronghold means I can never enjoy that amazing game again without being reminded of this.The gameplay is the typical "strategy" pay 2 win, wait-festâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥you'd expect from a browser F2P. The combat is composed of you throwing hundreds of units against your enemy's walls, with the only real control you have over your units being over their spawn location. And then you have to wait for them to casually stroll across the landscape/Irish Sea(the latter of takes literal days without paying for speed boosts) before the attack you planned finally comes to fruition. Even then, you have to send multiple simultaneous attacks in order to actually capture or completely destroy a village, because they can repair all the damage you dealt and protect their village from being attacked in the time it takes for you to send your next attack. Later on the wait times for villages can take entire weeks if you don't pay. Literal real time weeks. And castles(the defense portion of your village) will take an entire month to be fully built. I can not stress this enough: the one line of defence preventing other players from freely raiding and burning down your village whenever they feel like it takes an entire month to be built. And this is a game where you can lose all of that in the blink of an eye due to multiple attacks hitting your castle within the span of a few seconds.This is a game that requires you to be awake and playing the game for as much time as you possibly can. If you aren't online 24/7, then you are at serious risk of losing villages to attacks during the night.The "community" in this game is the worst. I'd imagine the only reason it hasn't accumulated as much infamy as most MOBAs or other notably toxic games is because it isn't nearly as popular as those games (thank god). The game technically has 'rules,' but everyone ignores them because the mods rarely do anything about the cheaters. People in my old faction(don't know or care what those are actually called) even bragged about having dozens of alt accounts! You know a game is screwed up when people are bragging about cheating. Even the mods are cheating! Some of them even abuse their mod status on top of the cheating. I've seen screenshots of conversations between mods and other players where the mods try and bait the other players into insulting them or raging, just so they have an excuse for a ban.The meta-game revolves around helping your house take huge tracts of land and keeping hold of them for a longâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥time. Your house earns points for this and the first house to recieve the goal number of points wins a prize. And after months of work, if your house wins, each member gets a bunch of comparatively meager prizes. The winning house also gets a post in the news section on the the world select screen declaring their victory which will get buried shortly afterwards by other houses' victories on other worlds.I am not sure why I found thatâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥even remotely fun.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												Alright, many people tend to become expert after a 'mere' 300 ours of gaming. I am approaching the 5,000 hours, so I have been around. And this is a game to pay to win, some people say? Not true. It's possible to buy cards that give advantages. But spending many hours online does get you free cards as well as a bonus. And when fighting a player, using cards does not give an overwhelming advantage. Attacking skills do, and building strong castles helps too. Lastly, some commentator says starting players are being attacked for they are very weak. Yes, starting players are weak, but for an experienced player to attack a starting player, there is a severe penalty for the experienced player. So starting players are not going to be attacked by the stronger players. So does paying help? A bit. But it can be countered by staying online a lot like I do. In fact to be online a lot has a greater effect than to pay your way. Paying players will receive some small advantages, but not enough to change the odds when they are stacked against them. Please, if you want to give your opinion, stay with the game long enough to give a good advice.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												This is perhaps the greatest free to play game on steam, perhaps even the internet. Many people say that it is pay to win, which I will have to disagree with. Although you have the option to purchase "Cards" which have numerous effects, the effects are extremely small (such as add 10-300 troops, which isn't alot considering you can have 40 villages in the game, equaling 20000 troops, so is 300 troops really worth it?). The stronger cards are somewhat good, but those are so rare that it is not very efficient. So this in my opinion is not a pay to win game, whoever said that, I am sorry, must be rather noob like to even come up with that excuse. Anyway, this is a great game and you can win even if you don't pay, you just have to play this game right.

												Stronghold Kingdoms is a passable game if you like building villages and castles, along with some strategic warfare.It is a multiplayer game which you play online against other people in real time.It is based upon a map of the world, which is divided up into kingdoms and provinces. You can choose an area for your base, and then build a castle. You can remain as an independent player, or join an alliance.However, you will discover that - if you really want to play the game properly (and not have your castle taken over or destroyed by enemies) - you have to play the game pretty much every day, which is a big ask.I enjoyed the building up aspects of Stronghold Kingdoms; the military aspects were OKish; but once I realised that the game is based upon the notion that you are committed to play the game every day, then I started to get over it pretty fast.By the way, the game has achievements, although they are not linked to Steam.Apparently, the game can be pay-to-win (you can buy extra abilities for short periods); however, I haven't noticed that aspect being too obvious (although it may not be too apparent, as you can win extra abilities, so you wouldn't know if your castle was being beseiged by someone who had paid for extras or not).Whilst I have logged a lot of hours on this game, the actual number of hours playing the game were a lot less than actually logged - as Stronghold Kingdoms is a small programme which can run in the background whilst you are doing other things on your computer (as buildings can take hours to construct, increasing each time you finish another building, I would swap to Stronghold Kingdoms every hour or two, click on a couple of items, and then swap back to whatever else I was doing on the computer).So, if there are wider statistics available on how many hours people have been playing Stronghold Kingdoms, those statistics may be a vast over-estimation of actual hours of game play.I can recommend this game for people who like strategy games, but only if they want to commit to playing almost every day for months on end.If you don't want that sort of commitment, then I recommend you don't play it.However, it's a free game, so no big loss if you play it for a few weeks, and then walk away from it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												A religious system that allows you to protect your villages from attacks by other players and AI. A political system that allows you to hold seats of goverment and command larger sized armies of those seats of power. A research tree that will take close to 2 years to complete all make up the depth this game has to offerWhen you maxed characters and run all the content that other MMO's offer in the first year, you will find that time in Stronghold Kingdoms is just scratching the surface. The server you play may be coming close to its conclusion of the 1st AGE after 1 year of play and rewarding the players who won that age but the game is far from over.There are 7 ages to the server and you carry everything you have attained into the following ages (gold, research , villages , faith points , honor). A server will on average take between 5 to 7 years to complete with great rewards in the end for those who played it throughWith the 100's of ways to play , you will be left wanting to do it all over again with what you learned. Most surprising is the number of women who play the game and I have known 3 who held the highest seats of power in the game, House Marshal. Leading 100's of players to age victoriesMy only complaint is the graphics are dated, but proof if you have a product with years of playability and a community where you meet players from all over the world forming life long friendships the player base will stay and grow.I look forward to the mobile release of this game

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												My favorite of all the MMOs I've tried. Consistently deep and fun, without ever feeling routine, bland, or mechanical. I don't know whether it's a pay-to-win game, as some claim, but it's certainly free to have a whole heap of fun. At its heart, though, the game is still an MMO and suffers from the relentless need to continuously push ahead â a few consecutive busy days in real life can be hard to overcome in the game world, a situation which doesn't match my lifestyle very well, I'm afraid. But if you enjoy MMOs, I highly recommend Stronghold Kingdoms. Shoot, you might even be able to talk me into getting back into it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I've been playing this game for over a year now and it is by far one of the best MMO War Games that I have played. With the monthly updates and near 100% uptime you never have to worry about this game crashing or bugging out. I love the card system and the ability to increase pretty much every aspect of the game with cards. From increasing the speed of your scouts and troops to the ammount of food you make in a day everything can be made better. Also One of the biggest selling points about this game that got me into it was the customizable Castles that you create 100% yourself. Other games dont allow you to do this which is what makes me like this game even more. Also seeing the scouts/merchants/armies/monks going across the map is pretty awesome. Being able to see just who is getting attacked and by how many armies is just awesome. Nothing better than seeing 10+ armies flying across the map to 1 village. Honestly, what got me to play this game in the first place was the fact that they had a USA map and that I could have a village in the actual state/county that I live in. No other game has their map based on Real Life locations that I am aware of which makes Stronghold Kingdom that much better. I strongly recommend this game for anyone who likes realtime war games. Username - XxMalachixX

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Want to re-live those thrilling days of yesteryear when Lords and Ladies lived in castles and chivalry was a way of life? Stronghold Kingdoms is the game for you! It's a castle builder game... it's a build-and-grow your economy game...it's a wargame, all rolled into one! Join a faction to team your resources against invaders, or go it alone,  if you dare...You can build armies and be a marauding Prince, or build a religious conclave and spread the protection of the one true religion. Interactive choices means that every game is different...you decide how best to grow your medieval world!Perhaps the best feature, being an MMORPG, gives you an opportunity to interact with players from all over the  world, meeting new friends and cementing loyalties that can last for Ages. ---Guillaum---

												"This might be a game, but isn't meant to be played" These words fit perfectly with this game, a huge Massively Multiplayer with a very profound game politics and mechanics that you won't find out in any Wikia, This game its actually very simple to play solo, but the Multiplayer aspect makes this game one of the hardest arround, you wouldn't be only making a huge castle and a nice village, taking resources from the map and attacking the IA, you'll have to join a faction, then a house, follow the rules and war statements, sometimes loosing all your villages and hard work in only a few hours, for reasons you don't understand, even voting yourself in some parish to complete a quest its enough reason to get 10 players start Ransacking you with out a warning.And still i love this game, it has a whole new depth level that you won't find in any other real time strategy in the world, you have to work out your diplomacy, make friends and enemies, this might be a war game but you have to play it smart, even if you spend a lot of money the boost it gives will become less important over time, its not a "pay to win game" if you play it for long enough to realise. 												Not that I installed steam, because I wanted to get the prizes from the giveaway, I always wanted to share my opinion on this game. IÂ´ve been playing this game since the Alpha and I was astonished how cool it was and still is. Yet, in World1, I needed a break, because it was too much time consuming. I came back 4 years after that and started World8 where I was very succesful, but then they announced there will be the Europe Map, something I wanted since the very beginning. Europe was a big disappointment for me because i wanted to be king of my home country, however there were so many Polish I had no chance to fight against them with just a few of my countrymen, so I quit it. I eventually got to be Crown Prince in World8, but that world was too competitive for me and after I finished the quests I wanted (I wanted to unlock all charges for the coat of arms designer), I quit the game and the whole summer it was left untouched. But I love that game so much, building villages is the greatest thing ever, fighting might get repetitive, research is slow, but cards are a great thing though and very helpful, quest make the game interesting and even though as a newcomer to a nAge4 world, you can rise up the ranks if you make the right friends. ItÂ´s the perfect game for strategist and lovers of the Stronghold franchise and because it brought me back to play it after 4 years (I kept thinking about the game the whole time!!) I have to say itÂ´s the game that fits my appetite most. :) Matthias Vitalis

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												Once you get your head around the real-time play, Stronghold Kingdoms is an exciting, absorbing and really fun game for the dedicated player. You can choose to advance quickly or slowly (there are advantages and disadvantages to both) and you can build your empire to suit your own strategy. Once you join a faction, you can communicate and cooperate with other players in common goals. Or, you can play as a lone wolf, quietly inveigling yourself into positions of power (or weakness - be careful!)The responsibility is yours to keep your peasants fed and housed, your fields producing, your businesses trading at a profit and your county free of villains. If warring strategy suits you best, you can battle against the wolves, the bandits or the Enemy for starters. Beyond that, there's the wicked marauders who will try to overcome your best plans and beat you down. Be ready for them or pay the price!If your plans are successful and you grow in wealth and power, you can gain status as a sherrif or even a prince. You can muster multiple armies to defend your capital or extend your reach. During all this, you can chart a course of study and upgrades that will govern the way you earn victory. There's a lot to do in Stronghold Kingdoms and much to ponder on.Come and visit me in any of my parishes. My name's Betrisher and I'm a Lady of Galway. :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Hi.  My name is Amber_Rose, and I am a SHK addict.  (Say "Hi Amber_Rose!")  I've been playing for almost four years.  I do sometimes get irritated with the game, and it often seems like a full-time job, but I've never seriously considered leaving it.  Yes, it has flaws.  Yes, it requires a lot of dedication.  But it has aspects that draw you back to it.  It's highly complex and can take years to master.  It has quirks that you learn to work around.  But it also has a great group of dedicated players from all over the world, and the opportunity to get to know people in a remarkably personal way.  I've read a lot of complaints here about it being 'pay to play'.  But many of the best players I know spend very little (if anything) to play.  It's not a game for people who buy an Xbox game and expect to master it in a week.  It rewards you for sticking with it.  I've experienced great success in the game, and I've experienced monumental failures.  I've made serious enemies who have threatened to find me in real life, and I've made lifelong friends.  I've seen people disappear from the game for years only to suddenly return.  Every day brings  something new.  In some ways it's changed my life.  And my knowledge of the geography of Europe has improved tremendously!So if you're looking for some amusement on a boring day, don't consider this game.  But if you're someone who has the time and inclination to immerse themselves in a virtual world with like-minded people, by all means try it.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												I read the reviews before playing this game and have played 'free-to-play' games, before.  I just got done sinking 6 months of intensive time into this game; and then left it like so many others. Turns out that player turnaround is high - is it any wonder why? Firefly certainly doesn't seem to care as long as buckets of money are pouring in.In a nutshell, it is a very addictive game and it 'can' be fun - but veteran players can be very 'clickie'. Also, many people end up in a fat cloud of disappointment for a few different reasons despite their best efforts.For example: If you manage to be lucky enough to start fresh in a new world that has just opened (I got to participate in 2 of them; I found the already-established worlds to be - well, established); don't expect to be anything other than a farmer or a merchant unless you are a heavy 'carder' - someone who sinks lots of money into cards for the game.No, you don't need to sink a bunch of money into the game, yourself - but other players who are on power trips and apparently have nothing better to do with hundreds of dollars; can really put a kink into your game experience. Unless you are kissing their butts, of course. And in that case, you are often just a tool for them to use.And don't expect to be able to come into the game with new perspectives and ideas... You will promptly be put in your place real fast.Also, don't even bother trying out the PvE 'wolf world' until they get it out of Beta. They make you pay for that game and it is so out of balance, it is ridiculous - although the game moves faster and is the most fun world to play, in my opinion (if/when they get it reasonably playable -I may return to check it out if they ever do).For instance, in the PvE world; AI castles can move in and immediately land as a large castle with several hundred soldiers that can immediately be used against you. Wheras, YOU can only have an army of 500 - and only 400 of those can be on your castle at a time to defend it. Add multiple captain attacks coming at your villa at once, and you DEFINITELY need cards. You CANNOT play in the wolf world without them - and even then, don't expect to get very far very fast. Even with lots of help from other players.If you don't have a lot of money to sink into this game, but you have some... Do buy the 2 sets of crowns that they want you to buy to progress for about $5 each. That will bump you up to getting 14 cards a week to use or turn in for other cards that you need. You can stop there and not spend any more - you will also win extra cards & prizes, at times. Also, foraging will bring you lots of wheel spins in the PvE world if you really want to try that one out using as little money as possible.Do I recommend Stronghold Kingdoms? Only if you are a hardcore gamer who likes to be on a ts (teamspeak) team.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game may be in a basic platform and simplistic type of animation, but don't let that turn you away. This game is the ultimate in midieval strategy. It takes place in... well. wherever you really want it to. You place your kingdom, or have it placed randomly, it doesn't matter, however your placement can change who is your ally, and who's at your throat. As a general tip, you should choose a name that isn't offensive or brutal, otherwise that could influence people to attack you. This game is not exactly hostile, but if you make people angry, there can be great wars that could wipe you off the maps, so choose carefully your words, your contacts, and your alliances, along with your enemies!

Posted: September 8, 2014
												This game is a very fun game and it has its drawbacks. There are very few drawbacks the fact that it takes a long time to get things done but they try to reduce this by starting and kind of scaling up in time, but eventually things will take a very long time to get done but thats the kind of what you get with games like these. For the genre I think that SK is the best I have played because of some of its features, like the skill tree and its titlebased honor leveling system. The game is strategic also if you have a couple of friends playing with you it would be best because it would really help in getting up the ladder faster. I really like the quest system as well because the rewards are actually useful for the quest u complete like they are fair. 10/10 would play again.

Posted: September 11, 2014
												This is a game that I have grown to love and enjoy, I feel like I am in medival times having to make those tough descisions on what to research and what to build as well as keep my villagers happy. You will need to be patient, this game is meant to look after it self while you enjoy searching for a faction and house to join. I have been lucky enough to find such and flourish without much complication and I have been given useful advice by everyone in my faction. You will be involved in wars, you will have times where you need to adjust your village for better purpose and you will most certainly loose soldiers. The combat is fun to watch and NPC castles can be a challenge to those that wish to test themselves.Overall it is a game that requires thought, patience and willingness to make alligences. A game for people who desire a chance to build an empire.Auroran

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Stronghold Kingdoms is not for everyone. Some people love it and play it for years, and others get bored with it after a couple days if not even an hour. It will take up a lot of time, requiring you to play for countless hours to rank up, fight, and earn gold. It is very much a Pay to Win game. The people who spend the most money, usually end up winning. It takes some skill, but the benefits that can be earned through the cards system which you mostly buy with money can make up for a lack of it. I have played for over two years and have enjoyed it and hated it at the same time. It is addictive and will keep drawing you in. But there are many things about it that are not good. There are bugs and glitches that have never been fixed, it is too easy for one side to dominate and completey kill a server, and just the amount of time it takes up is insane(easily 7-8 hours a day). However this being said, I would recommend atleast trying it out. I have made some really good friends through the years playing this, and although there are many problems it can be fun to the right person.  -spudicus

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												*Deep Voice* Stronghold Kingdoms...A universe which allows you to humiliate an adversary and destroy their hard work and diminish their hard earned money. After sucking you in through their delightful and peaceful trailers, not all is what it seems. After you have logged in you must put out the flames of war upon your world, unite the good (or evil) factions and annihilate your enemies. If you are not one of those people prepare to face a might greater than the roman legions! Stronghold Kingdoms introduces are Card system, whereby you can magically form an army together in a matter of seconds; however this also works when the army is facing your, clearly well built wooden walls and stingy overpaid archers, as you can invoke a sally forth card to hire some overpaid, slightly overweight knights on horseback (obviously, i mean a knight without a horse???!) to obliterate...2...or 3 peasants, before they gracefully slump to the ground with 100+ arrows in their chest.The world of Stronghold Kingdoms is a chaotic hell hole that will suck every living moment from your soul, until your so hell bent on revenge that you will do whatever it takes to defeat your opponent. If all else fails you can march upon them with the might of the 300!!...peasants!Overall this game provides hours of endless torment and destruction of hope. Once all your hope is gone it continues to wear away at your gaming soul with a simple tech tree, that leaves the indecisive staring endlessly at that page until only bones remain (shouldve researched more APPLES!). The games time-based/Real time strategy element allows you to combine with others to completely obilterate their castles with armies of over 9000!!!!! (Only works once YOU have united the good of the world!), otherwise itll be a few hundred troops, then all you have to hope is that the player hasnt got hold of the ultimate weapon...Daddy's credit card...and then hell breaks loose...Play the game and find out if you are the chosen one that will unite the world and destroy evil people (that includes the rich).-Username: XanoXL

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												This game has a depth that most strategy games lack, that is the necessity to form relationships with other players in the game to achieve success. No single person can hope to win this game, but every house has an equal chance to dominate depending on the level of cooperation they achieve. It has a great pace for those who are willing to part with some money, but if u decide to go the no money route u can still achieve success, it just takes awhile longer. It has a nice mix of game features that can be done at your pace from scouting, warring, to just plain farming. Although its a war game, monk and farm based players are essential to the success of your house and ultimately your own success as well. I have played this game for over a year and still find it enjoyable to play. But dont just take my word for it, create your free account and join in the fun. Your Friendly Warlord  "Meadamaster"

												A fun and easy game to get into, new players will soon find themselves immersed in a world far more complex than it's user-friendly interface would have them believe. Most tasks don't feel like chores, and completing any task or quest leaves one feeling rather accomplished.  Friends and allies are easy to find, and even if one invests minimal time into this game, they will find themselves rising through the ranks far faster than they may have anticipated.  There are challenges ahead, mostly earned by facing down other players, but it is easy enough to rise to the task.All players have within them a ruler struggling to break free.  Do you have what it takes?Come, join us, and show us your true mettle.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												This game is absolutely stunning for strategy and intelligent quick thinking. Large scale wars, faction vs faction, House vs House. The thousands, the millions of players choosing to either share and get along in a lasting community, or to destroy anyone in their path. The game has it's ups and downs. Up: You can have 40 villages as of current! There are tons of ranks to work towards, and many many unlockables and boosts you can get for no charge, including researches (You may buy spare points with in-game gold), you can own tons of landmarks such as Counties, Parishes, Provinces, and even the Countries themselves! Downs: You're prone to destruction at a low level if you don't find yourself protected by a high standing Liege Lord. My Liege Lord is my grandfather, who currently holds a high position, in the top 500 players globally, with over 14 villages, he's a Crown Prince. I chose a small island community, which may have it's ups as far as being seclusive and peaceful goes, but the resources can be a bit slim until you are able to go over-seas.Will I reccomend the game? To be quite frank, â¥â¥â¥â¥ YEAH I WILL!!! Nothing can really amount to this game's content and abilities, without completely copying it's style.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Like many online browser games of the "freemium" genre, Stronghold Kingdoms greatly favors big real-money spenders and gives everyone else--from small money spenders to the free-to-play majority--the shaft. This is not a game for someone who isn't willing to exploit every little fiber of the system or the fact that one is playing with real people, and therefore the smart player who cannot afford to spend hundreds of dollars to keep up with the big spenders must essentially lie, cheat, and backstab the majority of the player's adversaries--and at the same time, the big spenders with their awfully game-breakingly large armies are liable to do the same to you! Even if you chose to be a peaceful bystander. On the technical side this game features doznes of technologies from four trees: Industry for resource production, Military for the army, Education for cultultural influence (which moves you ahead), and Farming for general agriculture. Their functions in the game are more or less obvious, but in order to use them effectively you must be willing to forgo wasting in-game currency on "useless" technology and find the best way to combine the usefulness of technologies.The military is very simple: Peasants who are easy to draft en masse (expect to use these little guys a lot early on, and expect the premium players to never use them until they're spent), archers whom are fragile but can easily snipe enemies at a distance (expect to see big complex castles hosting these in their towers, which are protected by statkes early on and moats later on), pikeman for a balanced assualt and defense (early on these guys are impossible to get without spending real money, meaning you will not be able to use them for nearly a month while players who pay large sums of money will almost certaainly send these guys in waves in the first week!), swordsman who are basically the ultimate offensive unit, and Captains who serve as city-takers and leaders.The castle construction part of the game is more complex and a bit fun when you're in-game rich enough to capitalize on the insane powers of tall towes and thick stone walls built in a maze with deliberate weaknesses in certain spots for the sole purpose of luring the attacking A.I. (even human enemies cannot control the battle itself, therefore the winner is essentially determined at the start) through your death maze with hailstorms of arrows!Although the beginning can be rough, if you survive, you might see what I mean in the above.However, this game is in real time, which means human enemies from the other end of the world hitting you in your sleep and real people waiting on you. If you cannot commit to serious play then don't play at all--"semi-actives" are almost always ignored, bullied, pillaged and eventually conquered by the 16-hour players.Luckily the majority of the players don't like money-spenders unless they're in the same "faction" (i.e., a group of players who formed a veritable country with a government and political process and everything), and will therefore be willing to work with you in fighting the rich. Also note, the real fun comes from factions, as they have the real power (despite the fact Houses are meant to be groups of factions, they don't have any direct authority whereas faction leaders are practical dictators). In my experience the best role to play is that of a faction leader, but I highly recommend you find people to join you at least a month ahead of time. Otherwise you're putting faith in the random people you recruited in the local regions.  Also note being a dictator--or oligarch--requires you to invest much of your personal time and have extensive knowledge of the game (or at least a very good idea).From the follower perspective, the game is much harder as it's very difficult to find a decent faction to match your desires. And if you join then leave too many factions you will almost certainly develop a bad reputation and be shunned by many. Therefore you might want to consider taking up leadership--even if it's small and weak, it's better to be the sole owner of a small-time business than a shareholder in a coorperation because you will at least learn from your mistakes and from them, do better next time (under a different name and account ideally).In conclusion, this game is the epitome of Social Darwinism and it greatly favors people willing to shell anywhere from 30$ to 150$. With those who spent 150$ effectively buying out the game.I have found it a massochistic pleasure, the challenge is punishing but the rewards are great, I'd give it a score of and 80/100 compared to most browser games and a 60/100 for games in general. This game will tease you with it's fun times and really bite you in the butt with it's jerks and big spenders, therefore if you want to play, you better bring your poker face and conceal don't feel.Username: Alois Blucher

Posted: September 10, 2014
												First of all , im a Strategy game nut. Stronghold kingdoms is a good and fun game where there is alot I like about it and some things I do no like. I love the complex of what you can do and be in this game and the different strategys you can use to defeat your opponents such as taking his castles by force or beating your opponents in monking ( political power by votes etc) and even taking his weapons / food and resources. The one downfall I do not like about the game is how much cards can help you or aid you in winning over your opponent who has not buy cards. Than again this game is free so they gotta make there money somehow.As a little review of the game you basically start off with 1 village and begin making buildings and upgrading your castles to defend either against AI's or real players from either destroying your castle, pillaging , ransaking ( destroying your buildings you built inside the village ) or even destroying the castle all togethor. Also in the game there are what is called Parishs, and each village inside this parish gets to votes once per day electing one person to contol the parish as a steward of it. There is also even more seats that you can earn thru people voting for you to be the leader.You level so to the speak from Honour, Honour is used to lvl up thru the ranks earning your more villages , research points and the ability to attack your opponents. You can earn this thru buildings , Banqueting, defending your castle from troops or from attacking AI.There is so much more and I can go on and on but Overall its a fun and great game as i have over 700+ hrs played and strongly recommend it.NerdRageDan

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												I thought I'd write a review of this game since there seems to be a hell of alot of negative reviews about it, so I I'd try and share my experience of it so far.I started pretty late on, and as such had no idea what was going on. I'd never played any MMO game before as my laptop specs are retro to say the least. The tutorial was quite useful, letting you know the bare minimum to get your village started. The rewards and quests are nice, it breaks up the gameplay. I realise this was a recent addition, so I'm not sure if I'd stuck with it without the game giving regular feedback to tell me I was doing something right.I'm also puzzled at how people are giving negative reviews to a game that they spent two THOUSAND hours on. Some people spend less time with girl/boyfriends in their lifetime. I'm amazed at how it can take two thousand hours to find out you don't like a game.To some extent the online the experience will be affected by more experienced players. For instance, when I started, the players were really helpful to new players, communicating lots of tips to level up, and advice about castle/village layout and build order. It's not a game for lone wolves, which may deter new players, and you have to play regularly to get to the attacking/defending stage. And although you do have an advantage if you pay to buy cards, it's not a single player game, and you can always ask a higher ranked player for help and advice. At worst, they won't message you back, but most active players seem to welcome newcomers to the game.I'll continue to play as long as other people do.meu02136, currently in USA2

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												This game has it's ups and downs.  Challenging, but rewarding.  Basically you'll start from scratch starting from a single village scouting for resources, creating weapons for your armies, adding new buildings to your villages, researching new technologies/upgrades and designing castles.  Eventually you'll have multiple villages and sizable armies where you will join with others to attack enemy factions.     If you can get into a friendly, helpful faction things can be easier for you.  Unfortunately, one of the biggest downfalls for SK is in order to compete with hardcore/longtime players you will have spend cash on this game.  Buying cards and tokens can get pricey so I'd recommend trying out SK for a week or three before throwing money at this game.  Even with a card edge don't be surprised on losing resources, villages, etc from a enemy faction or from some who is having a bad hair day.  I've seen strong and skillful players lose everything and have to start a new village from scratch.   This game is slow paced and you will need patience in order to get the most out of it.   If you like faster action paced games then SK might not be the  game for you.  If your into teamwork, slower paced thinking strategy with an added touch of cunning and skulduggery then this game might be for you.  The game does have it's positive points.  One of the more interesting aspects is the research tree.  The research tree is huge and it will take you many months to go through a sizable portion of it.  Careful research planning is vital if you want to survive in SK.  Another interesting aspect are monks.  If you don't like the direct frontal approach of fighting players monks give you a more subtle Machiavellian way of messing with enemy factions.  Despite it's problems I still enjoy playing this game and plan on playing in the near future.  I've had people ask me if they should try it.  My response is try it out for yourself.  You've got nothing to lose and everything to gain.-Stonetailz

												very addicting, its free so what have you to lose other than countless hours of you life on here?pros- they have a max army per village you have, the reason thats a good thing is that it doesnt matter when you start, if you are fast and tactical you can fight anyonevery helpful communityif you dont like asking people for help, simply hit the questionmark that you can find on literally every screen and it takes you to the wiki of the game so theres no worries about not knowing what a certain building does or how to unlock buildings and unitsthey have cards that give you a little extra bonus but cost money to get the packs, however you can get up to a max of 2 of these cards for free a day, if you dont like what you got simply save up 5 of them and swap them for points and after awhile you can buy your card of choice without spending a pennycons-pay to win, ive seen one person single handedly take out an entire house (alliance) single handedly because they spent alot of money on the game, to get around that you have to keep your head low and not aggrivate people unless you dont mind losing your villas or have alot of cash to blow off to keep up with them... but, as i said earlier, the community is pretty chill, ive yet to get attacked for no reason, only during war time so you only have to worry about heavy spenders if you ware going to war with themall in all a great game to pass the time, takes time to build stuff so you can minimize the window and do something else as you wait out the build time, completely recommend itin game name fiz cola

												Like many online browser games of the "freemium" genre, Stronghold Kingdoms greatly favors big real-money spenders and gives everyone else--from small money spenders to the free-to-play majority--the shaft. This is not a game for someone who isn't willing to exploit every little fiber of the system or the fact that one is playing with real people, and therefore the smart player who cannot afford to spend hundreds of dollars to keep up with the big spenders must essentially lie, cheat, and backstab the majority of the player's adversaries--and at the same time, the big spenders with their awfully game-breakingly large armies are liable to do the same to you! Even if you chose to be a peaceful bystander. On the technical side this game features doznes of technologies from four trees: Industry for resource production, Military for the army, Education for cultultural influence (which moves you ahead), and Farming for general agriculture. Their functions in the game are more or less obvious, but in order to use them effectively you must be willing to forgo wasting in-game currency on "useless" technology and find the best way to combine the usefulness of technologies.The military is very simple: Peasants who are easy to draft en masse (expect to use these little guys a lot early on, and expect the premium players to never use them until they're spent), archers whom are fragile but can easily snipe enemies at a distance (expect to see big complex castles hosting these in their towers, which are protected by statkes early on and moats later on), pikeman for a balanced assualt and defense (early on these guys are impossible to get without spending real money, meaning you will not be able to use them for nearly a month while players who pay large sums of money will almost certaainly send these guys in waves in the first week!), swordsman who are basically the ultimate offensive unit, and Captains who serve as city-takers and leaders.The castle construction part of the game is more complex and a bit fun when you're in-game rich enough to capitalize on the insane powers of tall towes and thick stone walls built in a maze with deliberate weaknesses in certain spots for the sole purpose of luring the attacking A.I. (even human enemies cannot control the battle itself, therefore the winner is essentially determined at the start) through your death maze with hailstorms of arrows!Although the beginning can be rough, if you survive, you might see what I mean in the above.However, this game is in real time, which means human enemies from the other end of the world hitting you in your sleep and real people waiting on you. If you cannot commit to serious play then don't play at all--"semi-actives" are almost always ignored, bullied, pillaged and eventually conquered by the 16-hour players.Luckily the majority of the players don't like money-spenders unless they're in the same "faction" (i.e., a group of players who formed a veritable country with a government and political process and everything), and will therefore be willing to work with you in fighting the rich. Also note, the real fun comes from factions, as they have the real power (despite the fact Houses are meant to be groups of factions, they don't have any direct authority whereas faction leaders are practical dictators). In my experience the best role to play is that of a faction leader, but I highly recommend you find people to join you at least a month ahead of time. Otherwise you're putting faith in the random people you recruited in the local regions.  Also note being a dictator--or oligarch--requires you to invest much of your personal time and have extensive knowledge of the game (or at least a very good idea).From the follower perspective, the game is much harder as it's very difficult to find a decent faction to match your desires. And if you join then leave too many factions you will almost certainly develop a bad reputation and be shunned by many. Therefore you might want to consider taking up leadership--even if it's small and weak, it's better to be the sole owner of a small-time business than a shareholder in a coorperation because you will at least learn from your mistakes and from them, do better next time (under a different name and account ideally).In conclusion, this game is the epitome of Social Darwinism and it greatly favors people willing to shell anywhere from 30$ to 150$. With those who spent 150$ effectively buying out the game.I have found it a massochistic pleasure, the challenge is punishing but the rewards are great, I'd give it a score of and 80/100 compared to most browser games and a 60/100 for games in general. This game will tease you with it's fun times and really bite you in the butt with it's jerks and big spenders, therefore if you want to play, you better bring your poker face and conceal don't feel.Username: Alois Blucher

												I thought I'd write a review of this game since there seems to be a hell of alot of negative reviews about it, so I I'd try and share my experience of it so far.I started pretty late on, and as such had no idea what was going on. I'd never played any MMO game before as my laptop specs are retro to say the least. The tutorial was quite useful, letting you know the bare minimum to get your village started. The rewards and quests are nice, it breaks up the gameplay. I realise this was a recent addition, so I'm not sure if I'd stuck with it without the game giving regular feedback to tell me I was doing something right.I'm also puzzled at how people are giving negative reviews to a game that they spent two THOUSAND hours on. Some people spend less time with girl/boyfriends in their lifetime. I'm amazed at how it can take two thousand hours to find out you don't like a game.To some extent the online the experience will be affected by more experienced players. For instance, when I started, the players were really helpful to new players, communicating lots of tips to level up, and advice about castle/village layout and build order. It's not a game for lone wolves, which may deter new players, and you have to play regularly to get to the attacking/defending stage. And although you do have an advantage if you pay to buy cards, it's not a single player game, and you can always ask a higher ranked player for help and advice. At worst, they won't message you back, but most active players seem to welcome newcomers to the game.I'll continue to play as long as other people do.meu02136, currently in USA2

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												This is definitely a game where the lone wolf dies and the pack survives.  You need to join together with other players using the faction and clan system.  It takes a lot of effort to build up your castles and villages to rival the best in your chosen Kingdom.   You can play without ever being attack by another player for many months if you mind your own business.   When war does inevitably arrive, you could lose everything, this adds a massive risk element to the game and really makes you defend your castles.  This is when you need your friends and allies you have acquired through the well developed chat and mail system that the game provides.Of course, when you have developed your castles and villages you can become an aggressive war maker.  You can wipe out villages and castles that may have taken weeks to develop in a matter of minutes.  The game heavily favours the defender over the attacker, but nothing is ever totally safe.     Even the strongest individual player can easily be destroyed by a combined effort from a faction or clan.If you do manage to rise to be a Sheriff, Governor or King you must remember  âSic transit gloria mundiâ.  Many other players want to rise to your position.Cripper2

I feel that is what makes this war game fun.Pyloth

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Wow so many harsh reviews.   I played the standalone client before the steam version so ignore timed played.Pros:A slow paced, strategy, non-fantasy, medieval, castle building game for working adults that don't have 24 hours a day to sit in their mom's basement and play all day.  If you have a FULL TIME job, you either need a game like this, or you have to lose something else like sleep, social life - screw that. Cons: Spending $7.00 a month gives you advantages, not overwhelming by any means, but noticable compared to F2P people.Pros (for in game):  Playing solo is almost always going to lead you to getting raided, your villages burned to the ground or captured. This is an MMO and without a guild/clan you will get smashed (I rate this under pros cause otherwise, why arern't you just playing a single player game..?)Cons (for in game):  As a casual playing full-time-working adult, the game seemed good for my varied and rare play times, but the people in your guilds/clans are ALWAYS hardcore 24/7 people and generally want you to be as well, almost forcing you to either be in a terrible, losing-the-war guild or to go solo (see above on solo)CARDS:  Although I have payed for about six months worth of this game to be a paid-member, I refuse to purchase their booster card packs.  The cards can do things like make your armies move faster, add flags to your capital (flags are building currency in your capitals), give you extra food, and things like that...   I have found NONE of the cards to be overwhelming to the point where the game forces you to have them.  This is where the chicken and the egg theroy starts with most people complaining about this game.  Some guilds/clans enforce you to have certain cards availible so when you attack or are being attacked you can play them, and use the cards text (whatever it may be) to your advantage. This is especially helpful against F2P players who most likely have no cards.  I played a map from the beginning to the end of AGE II and never had the cards that the guild/clan wanted me to have and it made ZERO difference.  I know, I know, not a team player.. blah blah - BUT, i'm saying I still had a fun time, still have fun memories of assualting an entire faction and winning (losing some too..) without spending a dime.    The subscription I choose to pay, ($7.00/month works out to +20 coins to spend on things and 30 days sub time) was because I was unable to play the game and micromanage things 24/7 so it really was there to help me work 40 hours a week and still stay somewhat competitive with my basement troll friends that don't have to pay rent!All in all, I'd give it a passing, 6/10, for the pass-the-time play and attempt at making a game that feels somewhat realistic, but i still feel a 6 is stretching it a bit because there arn't enough worlds openeing now, and joining one that is already near the end of an age is almost pointless. The best thing you can do it simply wait for a new non-domination realm to open and get your friends to jump in with you.  I promise you will have fun and remember, this isn't a PEW PEW PEW game.. it's not a twitch and win game, it's a long term strategy game that resembles Axis and Allies.  BTW, if you don't know what the Axis and Allies board game was, my god, look it up - it's better than some video games.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Great Game!  It is challenging on many different levels, and requires multi-strategy.  You dont just build your villages you build and maintain castles.  At the same time, you research, trade, and cultivate faith points to make sure you have enough to ID when needed, and to use them to fight.  Your villages can be destroyed with a well timed attack or multiple attacks timed up, so there is strong impetus to learn how to defend well.  By playing with a faction and ultimately a house, you strive for glory, learn how to fight as a team, and end up joining communities online of like minded people; so in effect it becomes a very social game.  One issue is that certain individuals (I wont name any Russians names) multi account, and because they spend alot of money firefly allows it, and they dominate certain servers, Europe server being one.  Overall though, very good game!  Brethranus (in game name)
