content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												NOTE: I had fun while I played, otherwise wouldn't play at all. Having in-game connections helped. I still recommend it for the sake of trying and knowing what is what, it's not for everyone. I didn't feel that I needed to Pay4Win to get a good game and be a good player. Sure, you won't get to the feet of those that love to spend their pennies, but not bad either.Aaaah...I remember playing this game not so long ago. Once I logged in I had the gut feeling that I was going in for a treat at first glance on the map. It looked peaceful at first but the objective in this was quite clear: TeamworkWarDominateRuleThe first thing I did was set me up good with the parish ruler and all the parish player. Help each other out, ask what were the objectives of that specific parish and keep in touch so to work together on setting up a good strong parish. In no time I'm recommended a faction since I had a good set of objectives and knew how to team around and keep in touch. A sense of loyality eventually grows, got to trust those more experienced and keep in touch with everyone (again) to dominate and secure all the parishes/counties belonging to your faction. Once secured we just got to keep the rule, enter a wee bit of peace time and in a flash trouble brews and once again, lose some win some (territories).Sounds quite exciting doesn't it? Seems like your thing? It was for me, too. The game's diplomacy is brutal and if you end up in a very active territory you should be ready to be farmed/conquered and do the same too. Unless you've got more military driven people to back you up, climbing the ranks as a peace keeper will be very very painful and very well a waste of time. You basically have to set up two main initial roles at least: Fighter or Support. I was a fighter and got to admit it was one of the best online fun (browse(kinda)) experiences I had. The communication, the fighting, the commerce, the conquering the thrill of getting payback and crushing opponents knowing I was making them angry in real life. But after 1 month and a half I had enough. This game requires a certain commitment and while I knew how to manage the time, this game isn't for the person that doesn't know how to manage time of online fun. Otherwise you'll look at the clock and your wife/husband/partner/errand fell asleep or was ditched waiting for you. Unless one does know how to manage time, this game will only suit retired people or very very bored people with much time to spare.I recommend the game because of its strategical competitivity and how it can all turn into a messy chaos with all backstabbing and having to rely on teamwork/diplomacy for survival. The collective ladder climb. If you're a competitive person that seeks some competition in the online gaming department this game is a great provider of such.Just be aware of the timing downside and be very manageable. Otherwise stay away.Cheers

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												*Deep Voice* Stronghold Kingdoms...A universe which allows you to humiliate an adversary and destroy their hard work and diminish their hard earned money. After sucking you in through their delightful and peaceful trailers, not all is what it seems. After you have logged in you must put out the flames of war upon your world, unite the good (or evil) factions and annihilate your enemies. If you are not one of those people prepare to face a might greater than the roman legions! Stronghold Kingdoms introduces are Card system, whereby you can magically form an army together in a matter of seconds; however this also works when the army is facing your, clearly well built wooden walls and stingy overpaid archers, as you can invoke a sally forth card to hire some overpaid, slightly overweight knights on horseback (obviously, i mean a knight without a horse???!) to obliterate...2...or 3 peasants, before they gracefully slump to the ground with 100+ arrows in their chest.The world of Stronghold Kingdoms is a chaotic hell hole that will suck every living moment from your soul, until your so hell bent on revenge that you will do whatever it takes to defeat your opponent. If all else fails you can march upon them with the might of the 300!!...peasants!Overall this game provides hours of endless torment and destruction of hope. Once all your hope is gone it continues to wear away at your gaming soul with a simple tech tree, that leaves the indecisive staring endlessly at that page until only bones remain (shouldve researched more APPLES!). The games time-based/Real time strategy element allows you to combine with others to completely obilterate their castles with armies of over 9000!!!!! (Only works once YOU have united the good of the world!), otherwise itll be a few hundred troops, then all you have to hope is that the player hasnt got hold of the ultimate weapon...Daddy's credit card...and then hell breaks loose...Play the game and find out if you are the chosen one that will unite the world and destroy evil people (that includes the rich).-Username: XanoXL

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												First and foremost, let me say that this is a game where you will need to pay to support the game at some point if you want to really get into what others can do. However, it is never necessary to just play and support teammates and your factions. You can get enough free cards with just a couple of minimal purchases to allow you to do a few interesting things such as intantly repopulate an army on occassion or keep your production levels running high in your villages.I first ran into Stronghold Kingdoms just after lauch. I had been a fan of the franchise for several years already. I had already played a few 'MMORTS' games already, though, and was a bit burned out on the type of gameplay necessary to keep from getting steamrolled, i.e. sleepless nights, missing work or school, constantly watching from your smartphone... well, you get the point. The change from the high competition to strong cooperation was such I actually felt let down and dropped the game after a few months. (I will note that I did not make a strong effort to find a faction or join a house in the glory race, and so I had missed out on a huge section of gameplay that would have kept me playing.0I recently picked up SHK again and started playing and noticed some of the changes that had been made. I played a few weeks and noticed some of the core things weren't really different, though. If you don't join up with a faction/house, things are pretty boring. I should note that is unless you just decide to be the thorn in everyone's side, and of course, that has its own levels of excitement. I joined a house on the latest server, USA 2, and things are promising to be interesting.The one big addition to the game I have really liked is the quests. For people completely new to the game, it gives some direction as to how to play and what to do. For all, it's extra rewards that help you get established in the game faster and something else to compete over. They start off easy and build up to the difficult or very time/resource intensive.My final complaint about the game is that the honor cost of attacking smaller players can still be prohibitive. This is what gives the game its more laid back style, but makes it difficult to deal with the annoying players that deliberately don't level up and constantly harrass with cheap troops just to annoy those around them.Overall, I give SHK a thumbs up as it can keep a properly-minded person entertained for hours and days at a time without requiring you to sit and stare at your avatar 100% of the time. For those easily addicted and like to micro-manage each minute: play at your risk.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												I thought I'd write a review of this game since there seems to be a hell of alot of negative reviews about it, so I I'd try and share my experience of it so far.I started pretty late on, and as such had no idea what was going on. I'd never played any MMO game before as my laptop specs are retro to say the least. The tutorial was quite useful, letting you know the bare minimum to get your village started. The rewards and quests are nice, it breaks up the gameplay. I realise this was a recent addition, so I'm not sure if I'd stuck with it without the game giving regular feedback to tell me I was doing something right.I'm also puzzled at how people are giving negative reviews to a game that they spent two THOUSAND hours on. Some people spend less time with girl/boyfriends in their lifetime. I'm amazed at how it can take two thousand hours to find out you don't like a game.To some extent the online the experience will be affected by more experienced players. For instance, when I started, the players were really helpful to new players, communicating lots of tips to level up, and advice about castle/village layout and build order. It's not a game for lone wolves, which may deter new players, and you have to play regularly to get to the attacking/defending stage. And although you do have an advantage if you pay to buy cards, it's not a single player game, and you can always ask a higher ranked player for help and advice. At worst, they won't message you back, but most active players seem to welcome newcomers to the game.I'll continue to play as long as other people do.meu02136, currently in USA2

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												This is definitely a game where the lone wolf dies and the pack survives.  You need to join together with other players using the faction and clan system.  It takes a lot of effort to build up your castles and villages to rival the best in your chosen Kingdom.   You can play without ever being attack by another player for many months if you mind your own business.   When war does inevitably arrive, you could lose everything, this adds a massive risk element to the game and really makes you defend your castles.  This is when you need your friends and allies you have acquired through the well developed chat and mail system that the game provides.Of course, when you have developed your castles and villages you can become an aggressive war maker.  You can wipe out villages and castles that may have taken weeks to develop in a matter of minutes.  The game heavily favours the defender over the attacker, but nothing is ever totally safe.     Even the strongest individual player can easily be destroyed by a combined effort from a faction or clan.If you do manage to rise to be a Sheriff, Governor or King you must remember  âSic transit gloria mundiâ.  Many other players want to rise to your position.Cripper2

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												*Deep Voice* Stronghold Kingdoms...A universe which allows you to humiliate an adversary and destroy their hard work and diminish their hard earned money. After sucking you in through their delightful and peaceful trailers, not all is what it seems. After you have logged in you must put out the flames of war upon your world, unite the good (or evil) factions and annihilate your enemies. If you are not one of those people prepare to face a might greater than the roman legions! Stronghold Kingdoms introduces are Card system, whereby you can magically form an army together in a matter of seconds; however this also works when the army is facing your, clearly well built wooden walls and stingy overpaid archers, as you can invoke a sally forth card to hire some overpaid, slightly overweight knights on horseback (obviously, i mean a knight without a horse???!) to obliterate...2...or 3 peasants, before they gracefully slump to the ground with 100+ arrows in their chest.The world of Stronghold Kingdoms is a chaotic hell hole that will suck every living moment from your soul, until your so hell bent on revenge that you will do whatever it takes to defeat your opponent. If all else fails you can march upon them with the might of the 300!!...peasants!Overall this game provides hours of endless torment and destruction of hope. Once all your hope is gone it continues to wear away at your gaming soul with a simple tech tree, that leaves the indecisive staring endlessly at that page until only bones remain (shouldve researched more APPLES!). The games time-based/Real time strategy element allows you to combine with others to completely obilterate their castles with armies of over 9000!!!!! (Only works once YOU have united the good of the world!), otherwise itll be a few hundred troops, then all you have to hope is that the player hasnt got hold of the ultimate weapon...Daddy's credit card...and then hell breaks loose...Play the game and find out if you are the chosen one that will unite the world and destroy evil people (that includes the rich).-Username: XanoXL

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												First and foremost, let me say that this is a game where you will need to pay to support the game at some point if you want to really get into what others can do. However, it is never necessary to just play and support teammates and your factions. You can get enough free cards with just a couple of minimal purchases to allow you to do a few interesting things such as intantly repopulate an army on occassion or keep your production levels running high in your villages.I first ran into Stronghold Kingdoms just after lauch. I had been a fan of the franchise for several years already. I had already played a few 'MMORTS' games already, though, and was a bit burned out on the type of gameplay necessary to keep from getting steamrolled, i.e. sleepless nights, missing work or school, constantly watching from your smartphone... well, you get the point. The change from the high competition to strong cooperation was such I actually felt let down and dropped the game after a few months. (I will note that I did not make a strong effort to find a faction or join a house in the glory race, and so I had missed out on a huge section of gameplay that would have kept me playing.0I recently picked up SHK again and started playing and noticed some of the changes that had been made. I played a few weeks and noticed some of the core things weren't really different, though. If you don't join up with a faction/house, things are pretty boring. I should note that is unless you just decide to be the thorn in everyone's side, and of course, that has its own levels of excitement. I joined a house on the latest server, USA 2, and things are promising to be interesting.The one big addition to the game I have really liked is the quests. For people completely new to the game, it gives some direction as to how to play and what to do. For all, it's extra rewards that help you get established in the game faster and something else to compete over. They start off easy and build up to the difficult or very time/resource intensive.My final complaint about the game is that the honor cost of attacking smaller players can still be prohibitive. This is what gives the game its more laid back style, but makes it difficult to deal with the annoying players that deliberately don't level up and constantly harrass with cheap troops just to annoy those around them.Overall, I give SHK a thumbs up as it can keep a properly-minded person entertained for hours and days at a time without requiring you to sit and stare at your avatar 100% of the time. For those easily addicted and like to micro-manage each minute: play at your risk.

												A good Free to wait instead of being able to skip things the premium tokens allow you to queue building things and research tasks making the microtransactions worth while but not overpowered. Graphicly the game is appealing but not too demanding with a bright mostly realistic style however the audio however can be irritating. The music is mostly monks hymns which I found annoying and I find it hard to belive anyone liked the soundtrack. The only real problem with this game is not being able to play other games at the same time such as an FPS as the game randomly stops your mouse from moving on whatever other game your playing which seems a shame since I would really enjoy leaving this on in the background to check on every now and then.-topone940

												I do recommend this game because of how in depth and captivating the gameplay can become. Start from nothing and quickly gather resources, build your village, build a castle to protect your village, climb the ranks,  and research new techonolgy to strengthen your empire. Join a guild to help out other players just starting, defend eachother from enemy attacks, attack the enemy head on and so much more. The number of possible tactics and strategies are endless. content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												My favorite of all the MMOs I've tried. Consistently deep and fun, without ever feeling routine, bland, or mechanical. I don't know whether it's a pay-to-win game, as some claim, but it's certainly free to have a whole heap of fun. At its heart, though, the game is still an MMO and suffers from the relentless need to continuously push ahead â a few consecutive busy days in real life can be hard to overcome in the game world, a situation which doesn't match my lifestyle very well, I'm afraid. But if you enjoy MMOs, I highly recommend Stronghold Kingdoms. Shoot, you might even be able to talk me into getting back into it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I've been playing this game for over a year now and it is by far one of the best MMO War Games that I have played. With the monthly updates and near 100% uptime you never have to worry about this game crashing or bugging out. I love the card system and the ability to increase pretty much every aspect of the game with cards. From increasing the speed of your scouts and troops to the ammount of food you make in a day everything can be made better. Also One of the biggest selling points about this game that got me into it was the customizable Castles that you create 100% yourself. Other games dont allow you to do this which is what makes me like this game even more. Also seeing the scouts/merchants/armies/monks going across the map is pretty awesome. Being able to see just who is getting attacked and by how many armies is just awesome. Nothing better than seeing 10+ armies flying across the map to 1 village. Honestly, what got me to play this game in the first place was the fact that they had a USA map and that I could have a village in the actual state/county that I live in. No other game has their map based on Real Life locations that I am aware of which makes Stronghold Kingdom that much better. I strongly recommend this game for anyone who likes realtime war games. Username - XxMalachixX

content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												For a start, Iâm sure this is the first time Iâve had to make a download, with the majority of the genre being browser based for easy access by less savvy players (and the Facebook crowd, of course). Itâs also one of the first thatâs been so specific, American players wonât know how cool it is to be able to pick where you live from a map and find yourself building a village within a couple of miles of your actual home. Itâs a small thing, and it has no bearing on the game itself, but still it instantly invests you in your own stronghold because it almost feels like youâre playing a role in local history. From the calming music to the nice graphics and constant movement on screen, sometimes itâs enough to make you completely forget youâre playing an MMO Real Time Strategy game at all.Founding an EmpireI really canât stress enough how cool it is to be able to set up a village in your local area. The first screen youâll come across, depending on what server you choose, is a map of the UK and the option to choose where to found your new village. Split into counties, there are more than enough places to choose from and, upon selecting a county youâre finally taken to your village â a place that (if youâve chosen somewhere local) you might even recognise. All in all this process takes a few minutes and is far less involved than creating a character, although a lack of customizability is a little bit off-putting. Even my very least favourite MMORTS games have allowed you to pick your very own advisor (usually from a choice of beautiful busty babe or constipated knight, but the choice is there) and it seems odd not to be able to choose.

												To those who have given negative feed-back due to the "pay to win" aspect of this game....I empathise.  However, I never spent one penny on this game and was able to overcome that "handicap".  It is a strtegy game, it is a team game and it's a political game wether you like it or not.  If you're incompetent in those areas, you will fail regardless of how much you spend.  The game has the same limitations for all players.  I urge people to play, but NEVER spend money on it!  It's not exactly a fast paced game, so having patience will keep you from being burned to the ground instantly. It's free...so play it for free...just dont expect to conqour the world by your lonesome.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												A religious system that allows you to protect your villages from attacks by other players and AI. A political system that allows you to hold seats of goverment and command larger sized armies of those seats of power. A research tree that will take close to 2 years to complete all make up the depth this game has to offerWhen you maxed characters and run all the content that other MMO's offer in the first year, you will find that time in Stronghold Kingdoms is just scratching the surface. The server you play may be coming close to its conclusion of the 1st AGE after 1 year of play and rewarding the players who won that age but the game is far from over.There are 7 ages to the server and you carry everything you have attained into the following ages (gold, research , villages , faith points , honor). A server will on average take between 5 to 7 years to complete with great rewards in the end for those who played it throughWith the 100's of ways to play , you will be left wanting to do it all over again with what you learned. Most surprising is the number of women who play the game and I have known 3 who held the highest seats of power in the game, House Marshal. Leading 100's of players to age victoriesMy only complaint is the graphics are dated, but proof if you have a product with years of playability and a community where you meet players from all over the world forming life long friendships the player base will stay and grow.I look forward to the mobile release of this game

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Many say this game is full of trolls and pay 2 win.... Well it kind of is. Some complain that weeks and months of progress was wiped out while they slept..... Yeah it happens. It is said that Stronghold Kingdoms has the most ruthless, paranoid player base of any game ever..... True, but you do meet the odd pretty chilled Lord or Lady.What the haters fail to mention is that the game is simply beautiful. Easy to learn with a good tutorial but near limitless little tricks and strategies to master.I have played much of this game and never once while playing with thousands of other players have I experienced any kind of bug.Pay 2 win is in someways a fair comment because there is the potential for someone to spend lots and lots of money to do virtually anything. The game is actually very good free 2 play, and spending cash is much less important than it seems when you understand the game more.This is a perpetual kingdom mmo. It is a game to play for the long haul. There are many decent online guides but I would say that none of them emphasise the importance of maximum defensive technology research as a priority. Grow fast. Do not grow faster than your castles. This is a great game to play with friends, and even if a solo gamer you will need to be somewhat social especially when new to the game. I have laughed harder at this game than any other, I have near cried on login, I have raged like a wounded bull at some percieved outrage. Part of me died playing this game.... The part that cares about villages.I highly recommend this game but it is not for the faint hearted or the impatient. This in my honest opinion is a filthy little game and one of the greatest games on computer or otherwise that humans have ever played.I give this game 7/8 Influential Monks.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												My Stronghold Kingdoms username is: L0neRanger. Stronghold Kingdoms is a game made to last, jam-packed with content and endless entertainment. Its a real time waster, but well spent. What i look for in my games is something special about it, which stands out from the rest, this game meets that criteria. With my game hour count reaching 1,400 + and 3-4 worlds i play daily. Though, what makes this game great is the fact that its free, well partly...Free to purchase, incredible, i couldnt believe this was available for free. Though as i ventured deeper into stronghold gameplay, i realised the benefit dominance of cards and premium tokens. Of course not free this time. Players which throw cash away like water was flowing through a drain, guaranteed success, dominance in fighting - which gives non-cards (like moi) a hard time. I suggest you do a switcheroo, charge a price for the initial game, because its worth it. Then scrap payment of cards and prem tokens, or reduce it by a lot. This is the only real problem for me in this game.Everything else, top notch. I can think of minor improvements and additional add ons you can implement. But this realy doesnt effect my respect and appreciation for this masterpiece of entertainment. 10/10 .

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Stronghold Kingdoms puts strategy and cunning to the test. You need a balance of strategy and diplomacy to excel to greater heights in this game. While some may be content to just sit back and be farmers, there are others who wish to seek their glory as knights. I enjoy being able to build my villages and castles as I see fit and the anticipation of if they will still be there the next time I log on. Having played all of the stand-alone versions, I found it interesting how this game was adapted for MMO. While I think it's interesting what changes occur in every new age, I still have yet to see (after 4+ years) a world that uses NO cards and truly sets player against player. Overall, I have found this game "frustratingly entertaining" and will stick around a bit longer to see what happens next.  Jesterking

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Hi.  My name is Amber_Rose, and I am a SHK addict.  (Say "Hi Amber_Rose!")  I've been playing for almost four years.  I do sometimes get irritated with the game, and it often seems like a full-time job, but I've never seriously considered leaving it.  Yes, it has flaws.  Yes, it requires a lot of dedication.  But it has aspects that draw you back to it.  It's highly complex and can take years to master.  It has quirks that you learn to work around.  But it also has a great group of dedicated players from all over the world, and the opportunity to get to know people in a remarkably personal way.  I've read a lot of complaints here about it being 'pay to play'.  But many of the best players I know spend very little (if anything) to play.  It's not a game for people who buy an Xbox game and expect to master it in a week.  It rewards you for sticking with it.  I've experienced great success in the game, and I've experienced monumental failures.  I've made serious enemies who have threatened to find me in real life, and I've made lifelong friends.  I've seen people disappear from the game for years only to suddenly return.  Every day brings  something new.  In some ways it's changed my life.  And my knowledge of the geography of Europe has improved tremendously!So if you're looking for some amusement on a boring day, don't consider this game.  But if you're someone who has the time and inclination to immerse themselves in a virtual world with like-minded people, by all means try it.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												I read the reviews before playing this game and have played 'free-to-play' games, before.  I just got done sinking 6 months of intensive time into this game; and then left it like so many others. Turns out that player turnaround is high - is it any wonder why? Firefly certainly doesn't seem to care as long as buckets of money are pouring in.In a nutshell, it is a very addictive game and it 'can' be fun - but veteran players can be very 'clickie'. Also, many people end up in a fat cloud of disappointment for a few different reasons despite their best efforts.For example: If you manage to be lucky enough to start fresh in a new world that has just opened (I got to participate in 2 of them; I found the already-established worlds to be - well, established); don't expect to be anything other than a farmer or a merchant unless you are a heavy 'carder' - someone who sinks lots of money into cards for the game.No, you don't need to sink a bunch of money into the game, yourself - but other players who are on power trips and apparently have nothing better to do with hundreds of dollars; can really put a kink into your game experience. Unless you are kissing their butts, of course. And in that case, you are often just a tool for them to use.And don't expect to be able to come into the game with new perspectives and ideas... You will promptly be put in your place real fast.Also, don't even bother trying out the PvE 'wolf world' until they get it out of Beta. They make you pay for that game and it is so out of balance, it is ridiculous - although the game moves faster and is the most fun world to play, in my opinion (if/when they get it reasonably playable -I may return to check it out if they ever do).For instance, in the PvE world; AI castles can move in and immediately land as a large castle with several hundred soldiers that can immediately be used against you. Wheras, YOU can only have an army of 500 - and only 400 of those can be on your castle at a time to defend it. Add multiple captain attacks coming at your villa at once, and you DEFINITELY need cards. You CANNOT play in the wolf world without them - and even then, don't expect to get very far very fast. Even with lots of help from other players.If you don't have a lot of money to sink into this game, but you have some... Do buy the 2 sets of crowns that they want you to buy to progress for about $5 each. That will bump you up to getting 14 cards a week to use or turn in for other cards that you need. You can stop there and not spend any more - you will also win extra cards & prizes, at times. Also, foraging will bring you lots of wheel spins in the PvE world if you really want to try that one out using as little money as possible.Do I recommend Stronghold Kingdoms? Only if you are a hardcore gamer who likes to be on a ts (teamspeak) team.

												it's a build your castle, and fight to defend in present time vs real players game. Always something I've ever wanted, doesn't require money, and it has continuous game play that never ends (to my knowledge). You never have to worry about a server ended and all your villages going *poof.* The hard work and time spent pays off, and you have possible boosts that require money, but they are well worth it. It deals a great number of benefits, that seem to be worth your money.  Overall its a great game and worth the time, but you don't need to have that much time either. 9/10only thing i would change is to have a easier way to distribute, sell resources, build troops etc. from one screen. After you get so far into the game and have multiple villages it would help a lot!!! :)

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Personally, I disagree with everyone who says that you will be better if you pay for crowns and premium tokens. True, auto scouting and trading is very useful, but let's be honest, you can gain that gold with trading in half an hour, if you know how of course. I had only one premium and it was when I started playing, didn't even knew what I was doing at first place, but as the time passed, the game became very interesting. Farmville more complicated? lol, you don't know how to play SHK then ;)I got better because I was actually playing it, completing quests and communicating with other players in the world.And yes, this is actually multiplayer game and yes, you can actually be attacked by other players. What do you know, it's multiplayer game, real time strategy game, it's not like in single player game, you save it and continue from there. This game has a very complexed mechanics to understand, so if you are not willing to think a bit what to do, then play candy crush saga. Cards - those are helpful and I got those from completing quests, not buying them. And I don't use them at all, I just stockpile them just in case if needed.Highly recommended to play.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												sadly this game has gone downhill recently. I played this game before the steam version in beta and i did not play long when it went to steam. It used to be that if you wanted to be steward or king or anything in between, you could with good politics, strong allies and a solid strategy. If not then you could just fight NPCs and nobody would care as long as you werent randomly attacking people for no reason. Now, if you want any of that (especially the second option), you have to just get lucky. This game has also become extremely pay to win, and most of the time you will spend hours building up and some random kid will take your castle from you because he has hundreds of allies and 14 other castles so he knows you cant touch him. Its sad. Over all i say if this game looks interesting, try it, its free. if you get lucky and dont get into an area thats a bunch of douches then you will get lots of enjoyment from this game

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Great, game with massive potential but a serious flawed play to win system makes it almost unplayable,  most people leave the game quickly after realising how horribly broken it is. The churn of players must be truly massive. The game is run by no more than 5 players on each world. They spend tonnes of money in some cases thousands of dollars but ruin it for everyone one else.Players leave, the world get stale and they create a new world.Pay to win is  how the company makes their money but with no upper limit its an arms race most don't bother with and they drop out.  This is sad as the game has  great mechanics but these are broken by the pay  to win system making it the only game mechanic that matters.I believe this is a vulnerable business model for several reasons.1) More and more  pay to win games are coming out firefly are now  competing in a crowded market place. 2) The mobile market is taking more of this type of games market.3) The game hasn't  evolved at all since it's inception ( no insignificant features like paladin castles  don't count) players will  get bored and leave.4) Including the  significant "big spenders" not good having  a  significant chunk of your revenue at the whim of a few people. They loose interest  then what?I believe an alternate option could make the game more profitable, decrease churn and  be more fun.I suggest a limit to the amount of cards a player can play in a day.I am sure if you looked at the average churn rate, the average spend of those players before they where burnt, compare it with the average spend of your currentlow tier, mid tier and hight tier spenders you could work out a card limit that doesn't break the game and is more profitable then what you have got now.Do some projection on how long you have to keep players in the game  and/or reduction in churn rate you need  to recoup any loss from the difference between the max spend and the big spenders.The math wouldn't be that hard,This still gives the advantage to purchasing cards but does not break the game.The limit will make card  selection a tactic, what cards to use when.   Heavy spenders would still spend money to get either the "good" cards  or trade in for better cards. But they would have to choose when to use them.This would be an advantage but not as big as now getting to Prince  in 5 days, or instant spam armies, capture village build full castle, rinse repeat.They would not be able to bully the entire server which forces everyone to leave, and loss of income for firefly.It would be a safer more sustainable business model, it would also most likely accumulate over time. To have many people paying a little is better than a few paying a lot.Players not willing to even get involved in the Pay to win war would probably spend if they new that they had a chance of  competing and if this bullying was gone.This change would bring many players back to the game,I suggest you trial it as a world, just like the wolf world.It would be a great marketing event to  bring back old players.I mean seriously there would be approximately 2000 active players looking at the world figures.You boast 4 Million players signed up,  that means you have a  retention rate of about  0.05%  or about 1 in 2000.For a free game that's actually pretty damn good and actually quite addictive.This should tell you something is horribly wrong.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Imagine, if you will, sitting and staring at a wall for a month and a half straight. It is a pretty wall, full of green gradients, little red circles with arrows on them, a bunch of names from places in England, and a few too many stone towers.All in some fruitless attempt to reach a #1 spot on a list of people throwing their life savings into this wall, all to get some fancy cards that make a bunch of imaginary wood appear in an imaginary stockpile.For some reason though, I couldn't leave. I kept returning every week, repairing city walls broken from AI sieges and drowning the happiness of a few thousand imaginary citizens under a wall of alcohol and maypoles.This is a month and a half of my life I will never get back. Do yourself a favor, and don't start. It will consume your life. The only solace that I have left is that I didn't spend any money across the two year vortex that was Stronghold Kingdoms, and I now know the southwest tip of England kind of looks like a boot.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												9/10Stronghold Kingdoms is an excellent game, especially for a free-to-play. The game gives you control of your own vilage right from the start. The technics of the game are perfect for the era of time that the game is set in. Building castles out of cheap but easy-to-build wood or expensive but sturdy stone is only one of the concepts of Stronghold Kingdoms that you have control of. More intricate and complex characteristics include setting tax rates within your village(which has both positive and negative effects that must be taken into consideration), training armies to annihilate your opponents, and joining a Faction within a House. Overall, Stronghold Kingdoms is a great MMO that you definitely want to check out. I'd recommend it to a friend, personally.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												This game is a brilliant game to sit down and play after a long day at work or school. You really feel like you are a Medival Lord ruling over your personal empire and helping your fellow players along the way. The game has a brilliant community feel to it, and it would be great to play with your friends. You could work together, help eachother and fight together. Here is a small summary of a few of the main game features:Your Village: When you spawn into the game for the first time you aquire your first village, this can be customized to your liking. Your villages can be captured and taken over by other players and you can add you your village total by capturing other villages.Your Castle: When you spawn into the game you have no castle, and you must build yourself one using stone or wood. This is your defence and without a good castle you will not be succesful.Trading: You can trade with Parishes, Counties, Provinces and Countries for gold. You can also trade with other players and give them some assistance.Attacking: When attacking you can Vandalise, Pillage, Ransack, Raze and Capture. When sending a attack on a player, you will lose some honour, however when attacking a AI castle (Wolf Lairs, Bandits Camp and Castles) you gain honour for each opponent you kill.Scouting: When scouting you can scout resources from the map and scout other players villages to learn there defences.Monking: Monks can be used to change the game and are probably your houses strongest and most effective weapon. They can be used to protect your villages, monk players into Parishes and much more.Research: Research is the most important part of the game. You may research new technologies or improve other ones by using the Research Points you gain by ranking up. Ranking Up: In the Stronghold Kingdoms game you can rank up along your fellow players. The 'expeirence' is called honour and it is used to rankup. The ranks go from 1 - 22 (Village Idiot - Prince). Each rank has multiple 'subranks' which must be completed to reach the next level.I strongly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys Medival MMO Games.  See you there,Gregory of Ireland

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												`Faith must trample under foot all reason, sense, and understanding`. 7/10So, how much faith you got there left , Sire?! ...SK2 is  a medieval village management game and castle builder with  military and politics aspects, that are governed by religion. This is a very "patient oriented" MMO strategy game that brings a good impression of the medieval times (except the USA maps which are out of place a bit). It is a game that you will love and hate in the same time. The game has a lot of potential which is not yet exploited to the max, leaving it with flaws that some will consider to much to give it a thumbs up.In order to achieve a level of satisfaction in this game, you need to play it for a while, learn its ropes, and when a new world opens, begin your real journey. This game is not a single player crush em rampage style game, you need friends along and to become a better team you need to organize yourselves to communicate better and react faster. Along the way you will meet all kinds of players - liars, cheaters, traitors but also players who will help you at their own expense, teach you how to play, watch over your villages to protect them, enthusiastic newbies, grim veterans etc. From each one you can learn something and along the way you can try build up your team the best way possible. Then lead this group of players to victory using diplomacy and military skills. However, off the record, this game is not about getting there - being the last one standing, its more about the journey and the people you meet along. Friends and enemies alike, contribute to the heart and soul of SK2 and their desire to `colour` the map is the main fuel which this game runs on.PROS:- SK2 is the worldâs first slow paced castle building MMO, with the sounds and some of the gameplay giving you a unique medieval feel;- Nice overall community with interesting people from all the parts of the world;- A large European map with actual country borders and lots of player nationality driven intrigues that keep the game interesting;- You get a lot of satisfaction when your team manages to achieve something by working together;- If you are a builder type of person you will have alot of fun  trying to figure out the best castle design or the best building placement in villages;- This game really makes you think strategy. Its almost like a diplomacy simulator, you work with real people and you need to adress their needs in order to gain their trust. You can build a team of hundreds of players under the same flag.CONS:- Time demanding. You always need to check with the game during the day or risk loosing all your work in a few hours. So this game follows you in real life, you find yourself often doing something while wondering what is going on with your villages;- Players learned how to bend rules to advantage and as such there are players with multi accounts who make it very difficult for straight players to prosper;- The game interface is annoying at times.(Example: A player applies for your faction but you cannot click his name to see details about him, rather you have to close the window, open up another, then remember his name to search him... ). At times, to keep up, you will need a notebook to make addnotations.- Pay to win, sort of. BUT... the amount of money you put in this game its totally up to you. Sure you get some short term advantages,  but in the long run its the team effort that shapes the map. Being successful in this game demands time and teamplay coordonation more than real money imo.CONCLUSIONS This game has  good parts, it also has some bad parts...but it deserves a chance if you are into medieval stuff and prefer politics and management over real time strategy. My recommendation: this game is free to play, installs quickly, so give it a try and see for  yourself  if you like it or not!Sori

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												After one day of exciting gaming, it becomes tedious and at the end of the second day, there are so few things to do at this very very slowzzz..., that I have decided to leave the game. My âpremium try outâ ran out. Thatâs when I found out what a big advantage paying players has when they are asleep/at work/school; Auto trading, Auto scouting for important goods, Auto attacking, Auto recruiting and Vacation mode up to 15 days where no one can attack you. Mind you all disadvantages for free-players. Besides the premium, one can buy cards. To get cards one has to buy crowns. Crowns comes in packages from 3,56 euros to 114,99 euros and gives various big advantages in the gameplay. Besides these disadvantages as a free player, one can only work on one quest at a time, some take hours and even days. For instance as a new player, your scouts horse is so slow that you think it is dead, which makes it impossible to get to any of the hidden stashes before other players with speedy horses gets them. Another thing; In some EU countries it is illegal to get people use the feature âsend email to a friendâ to obtain certain goods. In my first two days I have encountered 2 highly important quests like that. I am really disappointed about this form of illegal activity in a free Steam game! But of course, both times I have sent mail to fictive persons! Now I just need to delete my account, for I am sure that is easy and possible (again according to law).I would like to buy a similar game, but when bought, one canât pay to win. Does a game like that exist?

												I've played this game for a year now and still love it as much as ever. It's the type of game that allows you to learn as you go along, faction members help so much with information, strategy, materials etc and also give a great sense of team spirit. It's lovely to be able to chat with others in your faction and the game is easily left off and picked up at anytime. I also find it great for multi-tasking, I can play and watch films at the same time. It's a very relaxing game (as long as no-one is trying to raze you :P)Mamakinz

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Can I exuse the faults this game has? Absolutely. The charm of the medieval stronghold legacy is present everywhere. The prospect of more maintains the sense of enjoyment. The joy of taking a completely unique route from your neighbours in your starting parish is exhilarating. One could build themselves a strong castle and defensive force, while another could focus on a trading monopoly. One builds churches and appoints monks for great honour, and another is keen to scout and raid bandit camps. The threats are always near. High taxes travel down the chain from top to bottom, causing discomfort amongst citizens. A rogue castle is built, and armies sent to assault towns. Yet kinder forces can watch the backs of younger players and ensure their success. All the while, powers greater in houses and factions are feuding for shires, counties, and the crowns of the kingdoms.The game of thrones even the most humbled of village idiots can eventually play a part in.Henry Scheldt

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												For a free to play game this is probably one of the more strangely addicting I have played. Expecting something I would try for a few days and move on rapidly became one of my more played games on Steam. While the leveling system does get drawn out towards the middle of the line I still manage to get atleast one level up a day. How ever the research system is probably the least well liked in my opinion, with each leveling up giving you 3 points (or researches) per, and the gold cost of buying a extra one escalating with each purchase leaves one trying to sort out priorities more often then not. For the few minor issues I have with this game. Its still rather enjoyable and the premium tokens are a life saver to keep your scouts going even while your offline as well as trading with parish capitals and other players.I'd recommend this as one of the better F2P games.Kingdoms User Name: Nalthren

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												At first I saw much potential in Stronghold Kingdoms. I was really looking forward to playing something that was different from Travian. And at first I was right, I had a good time the first 3 months, I made lots of friends, even in enemy Houses, but then everything started to look so similar to Travian in so many ways that it was scary... One would think that the House 16, that controlled the most parts of the gaming world I play on would do so with grace, respect and act through honor and truth. Now I know the REAL truth, they are the worst bullies I've ever encountered and I've seen my share of bulliyng... from the recieving end. They act through deceit, lies and their sheer force of power both politically and military to get whatever they want, whenever they want. Sure... they'll be your friend, only to stab you in the back in the end.And I say this with all good intentions:For the love of god, DO NOT JOIN HOUSE 16! You are so much better than them and you deserve better! And should you want to play this game... PLAY IT RIGHT! STAND YOUR GROUND! BE THE GOOD GUY/GIRL! AND ABOVE ALL ELSE: DO NOT FALL FOR THE TEMPATIONS OF EVIL!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Having played this game for over two years I've had my ups and downs, the game revolves around Glory Points - the more land you own the more Glory you collect, and those who obtain the most get several rewards such as Card Packs, Premium Tokens and Wheel Spins for being part of the winning House. Teamwork is key for success and leadership can make or break a House!There are no set objectives in the game, meaning all wars and peace negotiations must be created by the players. Villages and research are also varied aswell, there is no one clear way to success. In the end it will take a combination of different factors to find yourself in the Hall of Heroes. To help with research, building your village and ranking up you can purchase Crowns in-game. These can be used to spend on Tokens or Cards to que research and buildings, or to give production boosts.Overall a very good game as you can see amount of hours I have. I have played several Worlds where each one offers a new approach to Alliances and Wars, it is often a good idea to play alongside players from previous worlds as it will help alot.Best Regards,PsychoticUK

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												After playing this game for just over a year, and somehow managing to clock up around 1500 hours game time total across both the Steam and Standalone clients, I think it's safe to say I have an addiction to this game. I would like to say the whole game is unique, but it's really not. It's a generic place a building in your city and wait X amount of hours for it to build, and you can pay to use some sort of bonus to speed it up, theres 1000 other games like that, so why is this one so good? For me, it's the sense of freedom. Firefly has set us up with the base game, and left everything else to the player. The politics, how the world progresses, the choice of how you want to play, is all down to the players. Each player can join a faction of allies, and that faction can join a House, a group of factions that vow to work together, these Houses can then become allies with other houses, or wage war in an attempt to gain more land, or to defend the land they already own. The only real problem with this game is how easily it is to think "I'll buy some crowns, it's only Â£10" and then another Â£10... and another.. and before you know it, you've spent far more than you intended. But Firefly has to make money some way :)IGN: Sir Hurp McDurp

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Have invested thousands of hours into this game off steam. Never once did pay and I understand why people would say it's pay to win. But realistically it isn't if your willing to work, and work as a group. Played over several servers and on most of them I was almost always with the same faction. For almost 5 years I managed to stay in a faction which was top across 3 servers and at one point had so much people applying for it that we needed 5 subfactions and started our own house. The game is fun and easy to get into if you put the effort in. I was keeping up with people who spent money simply because I had better stratagies than them. It's more than pay2win, it's about working with others to make all of you prosper and expand. Heck, at one point I was even the leader of 2 counties and a province because people had the confidence in me that I could work hard. What most who play seem to not understand is the underlying fact that above all else this game is about politics. Keep up with your groups/houses TeamSpeak, when you start a new server it doesn't hurt to send a quick message to the people around you saying Hi. I've learnt over the 5 years I played this that it's much better to have an ally than an enemy. 99% of the poeple who I ever encountered on the game were pleasant nice people. I mean, even the houses we were at war with we could have a good laugh with.However, I honestly do miss this game but I quiit long ago. It was far too addictive and I would find myself on it for hours each day. Eventually you will get bored of it (took me 5 years :D ), but you will have a brilliant time for the most of it and you'll honestly meet some cool people from it.

Yes there is a Pay to win aspect but people that got time for this game won't need it to rule all lands. Its more of a bonus than actual gear like in some game that would make you immortal. Ex.: You can put card down to make you army move faster for 12 hour, or you can play card that make a precise building free of time and ressource but nothing that is permenant.I will give a modest review of 7/10 because this game isn't made for everyone. I wouldn't recommend it to child since there is a politic aspect.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												In this review I will go over why I do not like the game, but also like the game at the same time and also when I would recommend this to someone else and when I wouldn't recommend it to them. As you can see by the amount of hours I have on the game I have played this game quite a bit and have additional hours on the standalone Stronghold Kingdoms Client that doesn't use Steam.I will not go over the whole concept of the game, but it's set in the medieval ages and and it is an RTS-MMO that is very slow and is meant to be played over a very long period of time including months, even years. You join with others to conquer the lands to achieve victory and get your name in the Hall of Heroes where it can be seen forever. Now onto the review.Free To PlayYes this game is quite a good F2P game as everything is unlocked for you and you can do anything that someone else that pays for the game can do. Granted that the premium token members do get a few extra features, but the features just enhance the game and are not needed. All players do get free cards every so often depending on how much they have completed the checklist for free cards, with a maximum of 14 free cards per week. Cards are just "power-ups", if you will, that you can put into effect anytime you want and give you a bonus of some sort whether it be increased attack speed, x3 production on farming, woodcutting etc.Now here is where the F2P aspect goes to Pay-to-win. Those cards that you get each week, you can just buy them and get way more cards than you'll ever get from the 14 cards per week. I also forgot to mention that you have to click to collect the cards you get free and the time for the next card doesn't stack up so you will only end up getting 10 cards a week unless you're on the game everytime you can collect your card. So in 1 month you will have about 40 cards or so on average from the free cards, well if someone pays $20 on the game then buys 30 random card packs then he just got 150 cards + the 40 from the month so he's already way ahead of the player that doesn't pay. I've seen players on the game spend way more than $20 too, some people spend hundreds of dollars on the game every month and if you're competing against them then good luck because experience says the carders will be the ones that win.PlayersOn here, if you join a big active house, you will meet a lot of people from many different countries and it's probably one of the coolest experiences you will have in terms of communicating with large groups of people. Compared to other MMO's, I find that this game exposes you more to being able to talk to new people since you will be in a giant team of people and will be spending lots of time with them. Communication is also a large part of successful houses, so a lot of times they want players to get on TeamSpeak or Ventrillo and voice chat with players, coordinate attacks, or listen to a house meeting. Yes some people on the game are rude, but most of the people you meet are very nice.Time ConsumptionI have never played a game that is this time consuming before, and in this game if you don't spend a whole lot of time with it, you will be surpassed and defeated quickly. On average I would spend 8 hours a day on this game and I would still find myself getting outranked quickly by the carders that probably spend more time on the game than I do since they've invested money in it. If you wish to be in an active house in this game and go to war a lot, then be prepared to spend at least 8-10 hours a day on the game or else you'll be losing villages very quick.Let it also be known that a lot of times you'll have waiting periods of where you're waiting on something to build or waiting to get peasants for troops. In those times, I just minimize the game and come back to it and this will apply a lot in the beginning when you're starting out.Houses (Kingdoms)A house on this game is essentially a kingdom which they all compete with each other to conquer the lands and win the glory race. There are 20 houses so almost everyone playing can join one. In the beginning of a server each house usually has their portion of land and its really cool to not know whose going to be attacking who. Unfortunately, near the end of the server people will all join 1 multi-house alliance and destroy anyone that opposes them making the server a farming server. This can be seen on many of the servers, you'll log on and see a map that is 1 color and has all the big players in 1 house together. Not all servers are like this, but it is a problem that I have seen before.RecommendationI would recommend this game to anyone that sees the good in the review above. If you have some extra cash to spend and are willing to devote a good portion of time each day to the game, I say go for it. If you join the right house, then that is just icing on the cake.I would NOT recommend this game to anyone that doesn't have a lot of time to play and doesn't want to spend money on the game. Not spending money means you'll probably be way behind the pack and will be seen as an easy target to enemy houses, especially if you don't get on a lot.My review above does mainly reflect the people that join houses, if you are a neutral and just want to farm then some of the above won't apply to you although many houses see neutrals as fair game so it possibly may even be more stressful to be neutral.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												What keeps these MMO games alive and prosperous are the players, it is not supposed to be a single player, and it would be quite dull if it was.Now players are kept in the game mainly through the social aspect of it, yes the nice features get you to try it but it is social aspect that keeps you going on..I've played several worlds, and out of them all Europe world is the biggest and most diverse battlefield. In it you see people clash because of glory, because of land gain, because of vanity, because of the diverse human nature..The players themselves have sort of hierarchy, from the casuals and farmers to the ones who spend massive amounts of time and money on the game. Now while it is appealing to have the long wars and big wars, for quite a lot of crowns is spend in them, it is the small players who give up for they cannot compete. and without them the hierarchy crumbles, when only the strongest remain, we pool ourselves into a single house and we "win", but we actually lost that joy of battle, and the one thing that kept this whole game fun.. the conflict..If someone buys a charter in your territory, pops politics card and swaps everything, and when you try to fight him back he has fully built castle, well you must understand how this makes a little man give up. And even tho the carder will fill your pockets, he will kill the average players in the process, and without them world will become a barren wasteland, one man per parish, all in one house. It will die off.What I recommend is: give the average and dedicated players a fighting chance against the big ones.Some ideas:1) Decay of goods in the parish- As prices inevitably go down in the parishes as the goods are being sold, it becomes harder and harder for an average guy to earn enough to compete in the wars, with let's say 10%  or 5% decay of goods in parishes weekly you'd see prices going back up. And since it is percentage based, it will make these evening better. Example: If there is only 5k apples in the parish, 5% decay means 250 will be gone. and would effectively bump up price by a half a gold or a gold 143 to 144 let's say. BUT if there is 150k apples, 5% decay will make 7500 apples gone and bump the price by a bigger margin, 73 to 82 let's say.. So the more goods there are the more it will be effected by decay, hence increase income, hence prolong the wars and give average guys fighting chance and would keep them in the game.2) Repeatable quest / Quest Chains- Quests get progressively harder, as they should, but it means there are no rewards for dedication and time spend if you just cannot complete those, especially in the times of war. If there are let's say, repeatable quests on daily or weekly basis, that would earn some rewards, ranging from small ones to big ones, we'd see more activity overall.Example: - Repel the wolves - kill 200 wolves (or 10 wolf lairs) => reward 2,000 gold or 300 faith- Repel the invader: Rat - Kill 5 rat castles => reward 10k gold or a random card pack or 500 faith- Repel the invader: Wolf - Kill 5 Wolf castles => reward 30k gold and 2k faith or a wheel spinAlso chain quests, for instance, if you construct the quests, 7 of them for instance, and put them in the separate tab, only ONE can be picked DAILY, and if you complete all 7 you get some reward or a bonus. Those quests could be:Destroying AI castles, Trade quests, Production quests, Monk based quests, Donations, Supplying quests, etc.. 7 of them. Player can pick one per day, and after 7 days they reset, regardless if he managed to complete all 7. But if he does complete all 7, you grant them a wheel spin, let's say.This would make players log into stronghold daily and give them something in return for the time put in.3) Make room for strategy, increase unit diversityAt the time being, as you well know, only solder units used in game are archers and pikes, swordsmen are not competitive any more, other then as moat digging crews but even  then you'd want pikes and battle cry, and it will be more efficient. Swordsmen just die to fast in the attack to make any difference, and they are rarely used in defense as you'd prefer pikes to hold off the enemy while automated defenses and archers fend the enemy off. I say change things around a bit.example: - give pikes bigger health pool, give them higher resistance against melee attacks, oil pots and spike traps. make them less resistant against the arrows.- give swordsmen lower health pool, give them less resistance against oil pots or spike traps, make them more resistant against arrows (they do have a big shield after all, in addition to suit of armor, that pikes don't have)Due to the targeting priority of ranged attacks Sally > Archers > Captains > Swordsmen > PikesArchers will go after swordsmen first, and even tho pikes would be more vulnerable against ranged attacks, you can still achieve good results if you apply strategy => send a mixture of swords and pikes, and while swordsmen "absorb" the enemy ranged attacks, pikes can eat oil pits and spike traps, etc..^This is just an idea, needs more work on itAdd new unit in defense!I've longed to see Crossbowmen added to the game. Make them similar to archers, lower range, higher damage, make people create their own strategies with them. Archers have range of 27 paces from the biggest tower (would be nice if we can get it confirmed), so make Crossbowmen have 18 - 22, and give them bit more of a punch, compared to archers. God knows defending castle is rather tricky, unless you card massively. Increase passive and well planned defenses' resilience against the attacks, crossbowmen, strategy designs, add rolling logs or allow pitch to be placed outside of the white line and to be set ablaze to burn the foes. Limit the number of squares you can put pitch on so players cannot cover all of it in pitch, but must use it strategically.. etc..Meanwhile, limit the amount of defensive cards you can play per let's say castle. You can only ever have 5 effects turned on, or 3 effects. So people get to choose the best card that suits their castle design, for instance:- Big oil pot / moat castles => people will pick oil pot card, moat card and last stand- Big massive stone castles => people will pick stronger stone structures, call to arms, ballista fire rate card^Still an idea that needs thinking about, could work on it, but this is raw idea.Make a difference between carded and strategic defense less distant. At this moment you get: Carded defense => can't touch thisNon carded defense => I got slapped so hard by 2 or 3 timed attacks that guy next to me in a parish lost two towers :)During wars if you're not awake to card defense, you need to sleep by the hour, and it is exhausting. That is why people give up on the game... Let well built castle with strategic defenses be conquerable but costly to take, let people go to beds without worry of what might happen if they oversleep. I don't mind losing a village, but I wanna know it was worth it if it was built well.------------------------------------These are just some of the ideas. Given time, and proper testing we could come up with more.If you liked any, well I am there to discuss or help, will include both in-game name at the end and email address------------------------------------What you liked about the game?I love the game, and I love it brings people closer to have fun, and I love it has so much room to evolve and to grow. I love that you brought on the Europe server, one of the greatest battlefields in SHK world, I love that it is fueled by glory, land grab, nationalistic pride, and bonds forged and broken and reforged again..What I disliked about the game?Oh, there is a lot.. but it can all change.My info: damjanjelic@hotmal.comIn-game name: The Dire Wolf

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												OK, first off, if you are looking for a game that offers real time strategy on a massive level where you face off with literally thousand of players (I am talking real people now), this is a game worth checking out. It's one thing to play a Real Time Strategy where you face off against multiple AI and/or with a few players, it is another thing entirely where you soley interact with people from all walks of life (remember, I am talking thousands of people) in a scope of a game that is the size of full countries and even continents. There is more to this game then constructing apple farms and land grabbing, a single poor decision can result in all of your villages being burned down by an entire House (a coalition of united factions) containing dozens if not hundreds of players, or just one lone player who did not care for you gold raiding his parish. The potential events are endless. Stronghold Kingdoms is a game where Diplomacy and warfare go hand in hand to a level that the most shrewd and cunning strategist can be undone by a unsuspecting foe. One single misstep could mean the difference between being a King of a whole Country commanding armies of fellow players in a war campaign, or finding your self surrounded by enemies by waking up one morning to learn all your villages have been pillaged, ransacked, and razed (all of which are game features by the way). As for who could be responsible for this? A old foe you scorn long ago, a recent rival who seeks to usurp the power base you have amassed, or possibly a well trusted ally who has stabbed you in the back. In truth this game needs a Game of Thrones expansion of sorts, it is THAT indepth with it's warfare campaigns and politcal intrigue. As mentioned, the potential events you can experince are endless and impossible to express properly in a game review.Now in terms of actual gameplay, it might not have the most top of the line graphics or all-star game engine at this time, but that is not the intended appeal for the game. The Gem this game offers is the scope and the depth expressed previously. With that stated, you basically have five modes of play that you will likely at some point or another partake in while playing Stronghold Kingdoms, these modes are "Research", "Village Contruction and Managment", "Castle Construction and Management", "Player vs. Environment" (things such as AI lairs that are run by a computer), and "Player Vs. Player". These main features have their own sub features but for someone totally new to this game who would be reading a Steam review, you don't need to concern yourself with sub groups at this time... besides there are already plenty of guides written covering such. In the end, these features while on the surface might appear fairly basic, can offer you literally hundreds upon hundreds of hours of enjoymeant with them alone. Not too bad of a deal with a game you only pay into at your hearts desire.....And with that mentioned, time to address the big fat pink elephant in the room with dollar sign tattooed all over it. Stronghold Kingdoms is very much a free to play game which does not prevent you from achieving anything in the game a "subscriber" or "premium token owner" can do aside from a few things such as moving village buildings around and having a simplistic trading feature telling you which goods sell for top gold in location "A" while said good sells for rock bottom price in location "B". Aside from that, a Free to Play player can do and achieve that of anyone. Period. HOWEVER! There is a "Pay to Win feature" now before you stop reading, pause, breath, and read a bit more to understand how the title is true but the definition is inaccurate. Stronghold Kingdoms is a game that is designed and true in everyway I have mentioned thus far, however there is one aspect I have not yet been able to touch on until this point. It's a game that is designed to have you keep returning to it in order to maintain not only your villages and castles, but the game it self. This is a game 110% designed around it having a strong and active population of players, without people playing it, there is nothing to do in it aside from picking apples and hunting helpless wolves in their lairs, who just want you to stop growing apples and spend more time breeding pigs! (not to much to ask, is it?). But seriously, it needs a active population, to help ensure this it has a gradual constructing-build-progression-system. Basic way to explain this is "construct 1 village building takes 5 seconds to complete, the second takes 10 seconds, the 3rd takes 15 seconds...... the 80th a whole freakin' day and a half!" this sort of system applies to things such as castle buidling and research but they work in seperate ways but to the same point. There are research option you have to increase castle build speed, village build speed, and research completion speed, again the three operate differently but the point of them is the same. Here is where the "Pay to Win" feature comes in, or as I like to call it "Pay to speed this #$%^ up already!" ... better known as "Cards". Cards come in a variety of things but the majority of them focus on speeding the processes of the game up dramatically so you can achieve your goals faster and move onto other goals. To describe a few, cards which instantly give you things such as resources (so you do not need to wait to produce or steal them.. oh yea, have I mentioned you can steal peoples stuff? Mmm, dat pillage.), army speed cards so rather waiting 5 hours to reach a target on the other side of the map you are there in say a hour and a half (provided you have the army speed research done), village and castle construction speed, etc. In a effect it is a time saver but the advantage of "carding" to speed the process of the game up can give one a distinct advantage over others who don't, thus the "Pay To Win" common phrase but it is simply "Pay To Complete This $^&@ Today Junior!" Only a few cards make a player have a distince advantage over another in terms of combat / warfare and those are cards such as X2 to wall strength, handy to have but not god mode by any level. A half skilled player who is persistent enough, does his planning properly, and has some patients can beat a heavy "carded" castle.If you are right now asking yourself "Is it possible to obtain cards without paying into the game or at least where I always need to do it?" The short answer to that question is... Yes! The game has over the years installed systems to give all players cards for free or for a short time investment. One common method is the "collect Your Free Cards" method, which is a option you see while looking at the campaign map on the near top left of your screen. Follow the steps listed to gain more free cards per week, maxing at 14 per week. Other systems are invite-a-friend, where you get crowns for a portion of anything your friends pay into the game if you invited them, treassure castles which gives wheel spins that have a chance of landing on card packs in a varity of quanities along with alot of other goodies, and quest rewards which either give wheel spins or just card packs out right.With all that covered, is it easier to achieve your goals with card packs while playing the game? Yes. Do you need to buy card packs? Not unless you see it worth it. Can you obtain them throughout playing the game without dropping alot of $ consistently? Yes.I would say that about covers my review for Stronghold Kingdoms, I could easily write and cover more about the game.... but while writing this, my House Marshal has finished debriefing me on my assignment to be dispatched with a buddy of mine to move far behind our enemy lines, go full swing viking rampage mode of pillage-ransack-razing the country side to instill fear while the bulk of our House holds the front lines from being over run by filthy Italians. I'll admit it, I am eager to enter Valhalla. Shadow_Ordo

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												 My name in-game is Biyt....       I have not played this to much according to everyone else who played 500+ hours on this game, yet it seems as if i have had my fair share in just about everything there is in the game. First off, I think this game is great. Good aspest to it. Really is what the medieval times would be like if you were a lord or king, and its free-to-play! Free-to-play though is a bit a janky thing to say, while it IS free to play it is also a pay to win game (meaning you can pay a good amount of money to be better than everyone.) You can still play the game without buying any crowns (currency in-game to buy cards which give you bonuses and such) or buying premuim tokens (they let you do more stuff in game.) All you have to do is be very patient, very careful, and very. very conservative in what you do since the building and research times keep going up and the you have to have more and more supplies to build things to. One example of the pay to win is with one of my friends, Adam. Adam decided to buy a TON of cards one day because he thought it was fun. I, on the other hand, did not. After he opened all his card packs he had A LOT of bonuses such as; more troops, more peasants, supply cards, anything you can imagine thats with the game...he had it. Needless to say, he was ahead of me in every aspect of the game yet i was patient and while he wasted his cards and troops i reserved mine and kept the cards i got weekly. Eventually he asked for MY help with him getting supplies and such. So with all that information you should be able to understand that it's not just a pay-to-win game but it's also a game where you can be patient and conservative and still come out on top. If your'e reading this and are new to this game then get a village on world 8 on the Isle of Wight! :D   Btw, My name in the game is Biyt
