content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												In a huge multi player fuedal landscape test your talents for diplomacy in making friends and enemies, constructing armies and castles, and unlocking evolving trees of developement in crafting, farming, military and other facets of Medieval life. Rising from a lowly bumpkin you could achieve princely status or even with the backing of a faction and allied houses become a sherriff or ultimate ruler of a kingdom. Strategy is key in surviving the months and years of real time  entertainment. This is not a game for trigger fingers but decision making and effective interaction with other players. Team work is the key. all that is missing are AI enemies to spawn for the monks to deal with. When will witches and pagans start spawning to give those of "the cloth" equal footing with knights taking down enemy keeps?WIGWULF

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Stronghold has a particular type of gameplay that is suited to city builders.  However, it has a battle element that supercedes the city building aspect.  No matter what you can build, someone else can destroy it.  Of course, you can be the destroyer too. It's not pay to play, but if you pay enough money, you can certainly get many advantages and be far ahead of anyone who didn't pay in terms of progression.  I wouldn't say pay to win necessarily, but it's close.I enjoy slow-playing this game, content with any losses that i might incur.  In practice, you can set yourself up just to do research and city building and by and large be left alone.  If that's what you want it's possible.  If you want a game that you can waste many hours on, with rapid tactics and counter tactics being the only thing between survival and losing all your cities, you can have that too.  There are a lot of ways to play, for just about every stripe of player.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												The best online multiplayer strategy game Ive played which is offered for completely free to play. Not too complex not to simple. Dont have to live at the PC for hours and hours like most other strategy games that involve castle defense. A more relaxed type of a game and I highly recomend. I have played other games like Caesary which was the other BEST game I played. But that was before I found SHK. It had too much stress and commitment to be given for a gamea nd I simply could not afford to waste time like that. Reached the maximum rank I could reach there and stopped playing cuz it was too much work.That is why Stronghold Kingdoms is the best game out there and everyone should try this. Been playing this for now almost two years, reached the max rank and still playing. Because its a relaxed and a fun game to spend time on. ~HIGHLY RECOMENDED for strategy gamers.~LONG live SHK

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												This game is a very fun and strategic game but takes awhile to build up and learn. If you don't like pay to win, then I would not recommend playing this game unless you can put up with other people being far ahead of you and far more powerful than you just because they bought card packs. The gameplay is pretty casual but has some intense moments where you're just waiting for the outcome of a siege or you are at the break of a faction war. Overall a good game aside from the over-powered cards you can obtain just by spending $50; but hey, its a free-to-play, so they have to earn money somehow. Im not very far into the game but I am looking forward to a long and exciting adventure on USA 2.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Pros: Loads of fun, seing your little empire grows. Very social Game, without friends you're lost in this game. Grand strategy game. Loads of different tactics that you can apply and lead you to victory.Cons: Pay to win! A lot of the players are just scumbags, with no respect for players who just want to build. All they desire is destroy. Multi accounts! Most of the good players have mutli accounts. This is unfair.To sum it up: This is hihgly addictive and fun game. One great Idea that is poorly implemented. There are lots of aspects that just MUST change. Castles are unrealistic, they should make them be close to real ones. Pay-to-win advantage must be reduced. They should add more diplomacy relations levels. Now there are War, Ally, Neutral. Perhaps they should learn from all the Grand Strategy games out there and add Trade Agreement, Embargo, White Peace, Non-Aggerssion Pact, Alliance, Neutrality. They should perhaps add a change in the state according to alliances. May be even Glory Points rewards or penatlies respectively for supporting or denying support to an ally. Embargo state: If you're in war with someone you cannot trade in their lands, or if you're neutral you cannot trade, only with Trade agreement should you be able to trade with their parishes.Two big issues of this game: MONKS and ATTACKS:    - One MUST be able to perform Army-vs-Army Battles, hence be able to cross the path of a capture/raze attack before it reaches the castle. This will open the game to even bigger battles and more interesting strategies.    - Monks MUST, and I say MUST be eliminated from the game.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Let me tell you a story, One you wont forget.Once upon a time, their was a person named Nate. Nate was a ordinary person looking for a fun game to play. He then heard of Stronghold Kingdoms, a game that had everything he wanted; Wars, politics, cities and more. At first, Nate hadent trusted this new game and even disliked it. But that soon changed as he saw the real affects of the game. He soon lived in a place called "World 4". He met neighbors, friends, and allies. In this strong community, he thrived and blossomed into a huge empire. Prosperity was abundent and war was far from a possibility. But that all changed as a group of people called "House 13" moved in and stole land, cities, and wealth from the mighty empire. Wars raged as troops battled troops and cities burned to the ground. But House 13 was too strong, Nate was no match to a overpowed enemy. His empire dwindled until it was no more. However that wasnt the end to Nate. He traveled to a new realm called "Europe 3" and is attempting to recreate his once glorious empire. Will he be succsessful?  Maybe. But in the end Nate will never doubt the game Stronghold Kingdoms again.The End.Username: blueluke234

												This game is kinda uniqe, because the time that used in this game is exactly REAL time, which is mean, when you build some building and it said it wil done in 4h, it will indeed done after 4h passed. if you are an impatient and no fond of structure-tactical game, dont play this game. it will spend your time more then you can imagine. but, if you are instead of what i said before, go ahead, this game will satisfied your hunger of game with this genre. things that maybe you need to consider it, that this game is not money-sucker. yes, you need some money if you want to research researches in automatic queue mechanism while you logged out from game, because if you dont, you have to wait one research done (that the more researches you research, the more time it will needed to be done) before you can reasearch another things. this will happen not only in research, but foraging too, and so many others. easy to say, with real money, you will be eased in almost everything. but, if you like more challenge, (broke gamer, like me T_T ) you won't need real money. all that you need is your endless patient while you see your city become bigger and bigger--stronger too..... as well as your enemies.....

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This is an excellent game for those who are strategic, not afraid to spend time on it, and are willing to cooperate with others.Pros:Easy to play and there is a guide available to beginners at the official stronghold wiki for those want to learn more after the tutorial.Factions are like a community who help each other out and 95% of the players will not attack if you show a presence and respond to their emails asking if you are active.Attacking and defending are simple as placing troops and letting them go into action.Making money is not complicated at all nor is gaining honour.Cons:Everything is run on real world time so you have to spend a few months in the game in order to be able to do anything effectively.If you don't get a premium token badly planned villages will hamper growth and reduce efficiency.Castle designs make or break whether you survive an enemy attack from the A.I. or other players.If you don't find a faction to join once you gain power you may become a target from numerous factions as you have no allies to back you up.If you don't research important techs early on you will have a hard time expanding, gaining honour, and making money.If you are willing to spend time and buy a premium token occasionally you can make yourself into a powerhouse and someday lead your own faction,  become a house marshal, or even become king of the world literally. For new players be sure to read the guides that talk about early research that you should  do as it will help you out immensely.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
PRO:+ Under the village tab, you will see your small village grow into a budding and bustling town as you construct buildings, + Politics with other players + The research possibilities+ The player community is very helpful+ Leveling up is a large part of the gameplay, as it unlocks new abilities in research, building, and player abilities. + The game continues while you are logged off. Your buildings continue to construct, your villages continue to produce resources, and if you pay for a game token with real money, you can automate some functions of the game as if you were playing. + Free to play+ MultiplayCONTRA:- The graphics are more functional than fancy- If you don't build your castle well enough and defend it, you lose your village   and start over again, sometimes you also need to pay in order to win. It depends where your location is.CONCLUSION:This grand strategy game will offer hours of fun, intense, rewarding strategy gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Stronghold Kingdoms does deserve the honour of being the worldâs first castle building MMO and it does -despite its presentation- do it well. The gameâs depth and scope go beyond that of the regular Stronghold games and is guaranteed to keep your mind firmly lodged into medieval times for a long, long time. The game is a hybrid of a traditional tower defense games and a modern RTS. While the graphics might be a bit behind the times, the gameplay is engaging and full of the right amount of challenge. This title does a great job of appealing to both the casual and hardcore gamer market by mixing the elements of economics, politics, and war. I would highly suggest giving this game a try.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												I've played the game now for a few months and after really reviewing the game I'd have to say it's becoming a real waste of time. I'll give you a few reasons but you should decide for yourself. 1.Building anything can take hours or even days to finish. You'll start out with "Oh 15 sec to build a house, not bad" to "WTF 1 day 19 hours to build a house!" Which will keep increasing in the amount of time to build anything the more you build. 2. The game is completely Pay to Win! You can buy cards that give you Troops,Builds,Special Perks. (So basically someone could drop $100 on the game and completed distory your well built villages and castles that will take you months to get fully built up.) 3. The Castle building options suck and the area they give you to build is extremely limited. (So is the villiage building) 4. When you attack someone you can lose (Honor) which you use to level up so that game punishes you for attacking players. 5. When you join the game you'll be tax to death by parish leaders building armys which will make your life a living nightmare epically with AI Castles blowing up yourâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥that took days to fix up cause your low level. Ok, Think of this do you want to play a game where it takes months upon months to get anything real and when you reach that awesome point where you can finally do something have someone walk in with there house and stomp all your hard work in the dirt? If so welcome to stronghold kingdoms... a truely boring experience.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Although slow-paced, the game is nice. It does play a little heavily on the microtransactions to help speed things up. Premium is needed just to queue up researches and construction. On the plus side, you do occasionally receive premium bonuses from some quests, and the game's funny-money is quite cheap.The game requires patience and time. It's not easy to just sit there playing it all day. It works well as a casual game. To jump each day for like 15-30 minutes to get the essential stuff done, or maybe alt-tab while you watch a movie or play another game.So here's my synopsis.Pros:-Casual-Free-Interesting (and sometimes fun) concept-Has unique strategic elements-Rewarding if you can get friends inCons:-Maybe too slow-Requires money for a better experience (albeit cheaper than most Freemium games)-No decent spawn selection-Takes a lot of time to even make friends-Community is at war, making it harder for newer players to start out without asking for protection from their Parish leaderAll in all, I'd give it a 7/10.Remember though that this is my opinion, and your own opinion on it will vary from mine. Since it's free and a reasonably small download, give it a try to see how you like or dislike it. Don't knock it till you try it.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Read Me. This game starts out slow reseach is everything.I am a very experianced player who cards very heavly in this game. I have 4 years play time and some of you may know me who currently play this game. My in game name is Boardwalk you can find me on Global 1 for now. I have played many maps over the years and destroyed many enemy and also have been destroyed its a war game.These are the two play styles people have in this game. Farmers and Fighters and you will know what you are if you play the game long enough to find out. You will see a village near you and for some reason you will just want to destroy it. That is how you will know if you are a fighter. As for a farmer they have a smooth way of avoiding confict at every turn with an excuse to stay friendly with everyone. Before you learn how to two shot a casltes most people will stay a farmer as a new player learning the ropes. You will fear to lose a village because you do not know how to take another one. You fear you will upset someone and get destroyed. In this game there is nothing to fear but fear itself as you can always respawn again. Fighters need to be trained or you will never destroy anyone. This game is allot of typing messages and how things read to some players can really alter your future for good or bad. Also big players do not go around destroying low lvl players for nothing and because it costs way to much honour. A prince to raze a knight with 1 villages is about 1 million honour. Costing both the prince and the knight allot.The people who buy cards are yes rather dominant but research is everything in this game meaning your researching tree needs to be full to really start to play the game and there are many tricks to be dominant on the map other then just cards. Acivity level just like any other game is just as important. Catching and shutting down attacks sometimes daily becomes the norm for a active warzone.Now the game offers a rare 50% sale of crowns the ingame currency I gain another 10% because of a card bundle I bought a while back. This means I gain 60% more crowns when I buy them myself I wait for that sale.You will go spend a few bucks to play a priemium token when no sale is going and waist that hard earned money on a game you will never really learn. Then you will be destroyed by a player like me and cry on this forum about how its a pay to win game only. You will never learn why you were destroyed and nightly you will cry out to the heavans about how you suck at most all video games and real life. You will cry out because you are poor in real life and in most games you play as well. That frustration builds up to the max when a red eyed player like me wipes you off the map like a nat. As in any game people cry when they get destroyed and this is where you will see them all coming first to post that bad experiance.What about the glory of the game most will never expericance? Like landing in a new land destroying everyone in it and taking out the old king and making it a place for yourself. A place you rule and everyone else looks to you for leadership. Smashing Russians and watching them burn. Timing in 15 attacks on someones 18th village to see it burn. Stopping 15 timed attacks with that wallet and a smile as you peer at your enemy as if a God of War. Consider these fun times before passing judgement on this game. Also consider playing other games of the same type that are well not as good I have played them all.Now if you want to pay to win and bend the will of everyone around you this is the game for you. If you like to devestate peoples hard work in one night by smashing them with that big wallet this is the game for you.I still enjoy to log into this game years after playing it has grown on me. Once you have mastered the game and are not broke in real life its really fun and still not easy. You poor non paying gamers look out for me if you decided to play I will be near you with a moutain of cards just waiting to wreck that trash castle you thought would hold up well just so I can read that post on here of how its pay to win. Makes my day really.

If you like to devestate peoples hard work in one night by smashing them with that big wallet this is the game for you.I still enjoy to log into this game years after playing it has grown on me. Once you have mastered the game and are not broke in real life its really fun and still not easy. You poor non paying gamers look out for me if you decided to play I will be near you with a moutain of cards just waiting to wreck that trash castle you thought would hold up well just so I can read that post on here of how its pay to win. Makes my day really.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												It's a great game, but you have to be careful about maintaining your town(s). Your population is consistently growing and when the population grows large and the food can't compensate for the population inflation, people will begin to leave. You also have to be careful about invaders as they can come at any point, and you'll need to always defend your castle.I stopped playing for a while and it was a big mistake; my village was taken over and I had to restart back from the bottom.Luckily, you can keep your rank so you can still show that you've gotten decently far into the game, and that you're a force to be reckoned with.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Free to play, yes, but if you want to actually be able to compete with other players you have to pay around ten bucks a month. Otherwise, you fight with stick.Besides that the game is addictive and can be fun, and possesses a great deal of potential cooperative strategy. The game's focus on combat is significantly less than it would have you believe, and the real-time construction winds up being reminiscent of a Facebook app. More like Farmville than a tower defense game. Recommended if like that sort of thing and have a lot of time on your hands.

number of helpful: 17 of 38 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Most people dont understand that this game represent a new breed of gaming genre. The game is not an online multiplayer version of Stronghold Kingdoms standalone series.It can be described as "persistant massive open team based multiplayer online real time strategy game"."Persistant" means that it is a game to  play for a very long time. Imagine some pet game where players needs to nurture an online animal, or some online never ending facebook/gadget games, or the famous farmville. Un-like the stand alone version of Stronghold Kingdom that has clear ending, some people play in a world for years."Team based multiplayer" means that the game winner is a team, not a person. The team here called faction with upto 40 members, and some 12 faction grouped into a house. There are 20 house in each worlds. This is interresting since some "unworthy" players might be included in the winning team. While good players, players who pay alot, and players who spent lots deal of time might stuck in a loosing team. Winning is not decided by how good you play the game, but by how good you build and manage alliances, or sometime, how good your faction leader and house marshal."Open team" means that you can change team at any time. This make the game full with backstabbing, political intrique, lies, and deception. It adds a unique political nature to the game that is not exist in any game, ever. People who like a game with lots of communication, politics, strategic relationship, and complex interaction will love being faction/house officers. Everyone could create their own faction and become faction general. Becoming an FG is a real test of your EQ. You might even use the game to enhance your EQ and other real live personal skills.SHK has quite complex resource management. You need to find a good quide to understand how to micromanage your resources. It also has some arcade combat action with limited tactical option. There are many worlds to play in, and you can play in as many worlds as you like. Every several month Firefly starts a new world where you could join the competition again from the start.There are many type of ingame cards that players can use to help them in the game.Its free to play the game, and you will get free cards from time to time. But if you like it you should pay at least 2x $5 to get a constant stream of 2 cards a day. I dont recommend to buy any other ingame / DLC (including the started pack) until you reach rank of Prince and decide that you like the game. Buy the starter pack and other stuff only after you feel comfortable with the game. Pay wont make you win, it only provide some advantage to enjoy the game and to reduce your online time.Players could choose to play for win or just playing for fun. To win you need to join or build a solid faction with 20 - 40 players. It wont be easy. Most people will find themself stuck in a not so effective faction that will be slaughtered by other faction. You can choos to be a neutral farmers who fight to keep your villages, Parish, and friends from greedy faction. You could become monk player who support your faction with monking ability. Or become a warrior who'd love to attack and bully other people. Some other dedicated themself to help others.The game is quite slow in progress. It utilize human nature to love something that you built / managed with plenty of time and efforts, to make people love their villages, return to maintain, and become very angry when others raze or capture it. You wont be so mad when your enemy raze your Starcraft II base that you build in 10 minutes. Try to have people capture your main SK village that you build from a scratch and nurture for months. You'll find a lot of dissapointed people in the forum or spend time to wrote bad recommendation review for this game, because they're so angry for loosing their villages.The nature of the game requires serious player to play alot. One needs regular daily online time. The reason is because SHK requires player to pay for all build/research queu. Otherwise you need to be online twice a day to start research, to build or to get free cards. So the game is not suitable for people who can play only weekly. Many people will find out this after several weeks and abandon their villages.To attract more players, SHK should provide queu for free: to build, research, and to get the regular card. Therefor the weekly players could also enjoy the game.Dont play this game if you:- Dont have daily online time (unless SHK provide free queu).- Dont like a "persistant massive open team based multiplayer online real time strategy game".- Dont like complex resource management.You'll enjoy the game if you:- Have spare time to be online daily without ruining your marriage or get fired.- Like to communicate, enjoy politics and strategic interraction with lots of people.- Spend time to understand the game mechanics.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I played SK for 2 years after release with my friends from another MMO game.  Then I took a break and tried it a little bit last month to see what has happened. I really do like this game. Particularly in factions and houses. I find it fun and authentic to what I envision a strategy game would look and feel like. Grdphic is pretty neat. I like the game concept... but the actual stages of developing one's character in the game are most interesting. I like how the developers are maturing the game with the new ages, with adding more content, taking care of fixing bugs. All these things are good and healthy advancement that I think will help maintain the current player base a lot longer.Stronghold Kingdoms is not just a game, it a way to spend your free time. It's a true saga, which in my case has continued for 5 years now. There's not a day I have spent in SK, which I would call empty because it gives me not just pleasure of playing but also many contacts with other players. At some point I was an addict, and played SK for many hours, sometimes even days, forgetting about real life. So, be careful, people, don't get addicted if you want to feel the true pleasure of dealing with SK.ivansmagic

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												You are already a big fan of stronghold, and you want to play with thousands of other Stronghold-Fans?And you are good in being patient? :D (I play on ps3, and on my laptop stronghold kingdoms and never waste any time) :DThen you should try this game, and with âTRYâ I mean, really âTRYâ it ;) don't start this game, and spend only 5minutes with it and waste village places, write some people, join a faction or a house, that help you in your first steps, download team speak, talk with real people, and after around 2-5hours, you will see, itÂ´s a â¥â¥â¥â¥ing awesome game!!!I really can say, Stronghold Kingdoms is one of my Favorite games, that thanks to FireFly Studios exist!Every day in this game is different, there are lots of opportunities, that every one, from the small village idiot, to the prince have to choose.In this game, THE PLAYER makes the story!If you want, you can threat your friends, and help the enemy, to become famous in the world on that you play, or you can be an evil tyrant, that raze the villages of his enemies without mercy, but also in the mission of the church it is allowed you to use monks, to make the medieval lifeÂ´s of the other ones easier, or more painful. And there are much more opportunities, that you have!I started to play this game, since the polish world 1 opened (world 3 would be nice, but please, not only Poland, white Russia, Ukraine, Czech and some other eastern countries would be nice there to) and I can't â¥â¥â¥â¥ing stop playing it, after I give this game a chance, to let it affect me, and it was a good idea! *-*I started to play in h20, and I swear, it makes a lot of fun, in the long nights at this game, but with some time, it started in me with the feeling, that i have not enough power, and I start to want more, till I threaten them, and my name was a short time there famous on the path of polish h20 :)but now, I am only a faithful knight and play on europe3 and swiat1.Seriously, I would recommend this game to everyone, who likes medieval times, castle building and other similar games, and pleas. Try it out a bit, don't throw it away after some minutes, and really listen on me, and spend at least an hour :) you will not regret it ;)Conclusion:Fun: 10/10Atmosphere: 10/10Politics: 10/10 (if you have a good house)War: 10/10Community: 7/10 (from world to world different)Farming: 8/10 (better weather system would be awesome)Pay2win? If you pay, things are easier, but there are treasure castles, that help you out on a good way too, and you can farm premium and cards on other worlds ;)Hope I will find some new people there on the battlefields :DGreetings from: TheodinManus

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												For my play style on RTS this is a very very slow paced game.  I am standing with it to see if things change for the better when I catch up to what, "Should have been done to start".   Though it is diverse in many aspects, the starting quest line dies off with letting you build one of this and that then. bam just stops.  leaving you with nothing to let you know how to build your army with the extensive tree of knowledge.I of course worked on my scouts first, then found out everything in town is going to take forever to build now.  Thinking gathering would actually net me more resources to get building.  But then i quickly learned that I can't build anything, because I don't know how and it will take forever to get on the track i should have been on to begin with.  So in a nut shell make the most of your starting time mass learning whatever you can that will let you build.  Otherwise all you can do is collect resources and sell them.   Watching your dots collect stuff and hopefully get enough honour to finally rank up to get those needed learning points.   It is a fun game however, some form of warning that buildings are learned would have been a huge help.  My normaly RTS strategy was definately fail to start , but may yet pay off in the end.  no more to say but happy building and great time sink.Being as I am new, I so far with its diversity give it a 7/10. thumpinz

Posted: May 31, 2013
												Pros:+Free to Play+MMO (Massively Multiplayer Online)+A near endless experience+Hundreds, if not thousands of players+Developers are continually updating it+15 - 20 worlds+Great graphics+Supports several different languagesCons:-Is hard on new players-Areas can be overrun by AI camps/castles-Has in-game purchases, sometimes not worth the money-Research and build times get exceedingly long, leaving fewer possibilities-May take a while to level up-Can only conduct 1 research a a time, and a queue is $5 USDAI's attack too often-One type of AI cannot be attacked, and is very powerful---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall Rating: 89 out of 100Play This Game? At least give it a try.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I played SK for 2 years after release with my friends from another MMO game.  Then I took a break and tried it a little bit last month to see what has happened. I really do like this game. Particularly in factions and houses. I find it fun and authentic to what I envision a strategy game would look and feel like. Grdphic is pretty neat. I like the game concept... but the actual stages of developing one's character in the game are most interesting. I like how the developers are maturing the game with the new ages, with adding more content, taking care of fixing bugs. All these things are good and healthy advancement that I think will help maintain the current player base a lot longer.Stronghold Kingdoms is not just a game, it a way to spend your free time. It's a true saga, which in my case has continued for 5 years now. There's not a day I have spent in SK, which I would call empty because it gives me not just pleasure of playing but also many contacts with other players. At some point I was an addict, and played SK for many hours, sometimes even days, forgetting about real life. So, be careful, people, don't get addicted if you want to feel the true pleasure of dealing with SK.ivansmagic

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												After reading many reviews concerning my most favorite game, Stronghold Kingdoms, there are some things about the game I'd like to clarify. There are many players that keep trying to toss the game out as a Pay-To-Win game. I hate Pay-To-Win games, and if this was Pay-To-Win, I wouldn't be playing it as much as I do now. With or without real money, people in this game are going to be able to kick yourâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥when you first start out. The game is rough for somebody playing alone. However, when an already-experienced player brings in their to play with him, the game can be a ton of fun. Strength in numbers of manpower is much greater than the strength of buying cards and premium tokens. Do yourself a favor and don't not play the game just because other reviewers are saying they got wrecked by Pay-To-Wins, you get wrecked and wreck people back, it's a lot of fun if you like screwing other people over. It's what the game is about! Feel free to add me on Steam and join me on my World 3 so I can force-feed honor until you're level 16 with 3 villages on your first day of playing.

												You are already a big fan of stronghold, and you want to play with thousands of other Stronghold-Fans?And you are good in being patient? :D (I play on ps3, and on my laptop stronghold kingdoms and never waste any time) :DThen you should try this game, and with âTRYâ I mean, really âTRYâ it ;) don't start this game, and spend only 5minutes with it and waste village places, write some people, join a faction or a house, that help you in your first steps, download team speak, talk with real people, and after around 2-5hours, you will see, itÂ´s a â¥â¥â¥â¥ing awesome game!!!I really can say, Stronghold Kingdoms is one of my Favorite games, that thanks to FireFly Studios exist!Every day in this game is different, there are lots of opportunities, that every one, from the small village idiot, to the prince have to choose.In this game, THE PLAYER makes the story!If you want, you can threat your friends, and help the enemy, to become famous in the world on that you play, or you can be an evil tyrant, that raze the villages of his enemies without mercy, but also in the mission of the church it is allowed you to use monks, to make the medieval lifeÂ´s of the other ones easier, or more painful. And there are much more opportunities, that you have!I started to play this game, since the polish world 1 opened (world 3 would be nice, but please, not only Poland, white Russia, Ukraine, Czech and some other eastern countries would be nice there to) and I can't â¥â¥â¥â¥ing stop playing it, after I give this game a chance, to let it affect me, and it was a good idea! *-*I started to play in h20, and I swear, it makes a lot of fun, in the long nights at this game, but with some time, it started in me with the feeling, that i have not enough power, and I start to want more, till I threaten them, and my name was a short time there famous on the path of polish h20 :)but now, I am only a faithful knight and play on europe3 and swiat1.Seriously, I would recommend this game to everyone, who likes medieval times, castle building and other similar games, and pleas. Try it out a bit, don't throw it away after some minutes, and really listen on me, and spend at least an hour :) you will not regret it ;)Conclusion:Fun: 10/10Atmosphere: 10/10Politics: 10/10 (if you have a good house)War: 10/10Community: 7/10 (from world to world different)Farming: 8/10 (better weather system would be awesome)Pay2win? If you pay, things are easier, but there are treasure castles, that help you out on a good way too, and you can farm premium and cards on other worlds ;)Hope I will find some new people there on the battlefields :DGreetings from: TheodinManus

Cheak it out on the main site under the faction name CY HAWKS in the USA1 Age 1 list, Killwize is there. I really wish they would have published the scores on there also so I could prove to you our teams awesomeness but I guess you'll just have to take my word for it.

number of helpful: 14 of 32 people (44%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Stronghold kingdoms is a difficult game to explain at the outset, so I'll just go over the basics without going past a few paragraphs. It's a good game, though it requires a lot of patience, for reasons you can read below if you want. In sum, it's for a patient, deliberate type of gamer, and is certainly a rewarding experience. Onto the real meat:You'll see pretty much every negative review on this game say it's "pay to win", which shows that they took one look at the game, saw that they had to pay, and then quit. It's essentially a subscription-based model, where you pay for premium either by the week or the month, which makes progressing through the game much faster than if you were a free player. It rounds out to about $8 a month, plus some spare change left over to buy card packs. At the cost of a Netflix subscription (or a large case of soda), it's worth the money to spend just for the benefits that you get as a premium member. The only way for money to become a serious problem is if you're spending thousands of dollars on the game to progress at ludicrously fast speeds, at which point the player is a bigger problem that the game can handle.So now onto the review. The game is a medieval, strategy-based, simulation MMO where you build a kingdom, interact with other kingdoms, and do your best to balance the two without going overboard. It doesn't sum up the tense and thoughtful experience that you get with the game, nor will most of the promotional materials. It's a game about tactics, waiting, thinking, and looking into the future to see what you best actions will be a day or two from now. It's an accurate simulation of the politics and world-building of the middle ages all bottled up into a deliberately paced experience, one that's definitely worth trying out just to feel the experience.Naturally, time is an important factor in this game. To get anything done, you need to produce raw materials with your buildings. This includes resources, weapons, and gold - all of which you have to wait a while to get in large amounts. By "a while", it's more like hours until you have the opportunity to expand on a larger scale - waiting for your village to populate, your buildings to produce, and your merchants to trade with others. Much like an idle game, it's best to wait a long time between play sessions to get the most out of your game. Otherwise you'll be checking it all the time, obsessed over when you have the opportunity to start developing. Unlike an idle game, it's not just a matter of upgrading the most expensive thing you can afford and waiting for another day. Indeed, you spend a long time looking over all the options you have at your disposal until you realise you don't have anything left to do at the time.There is a level of depth and strategy in this game that is completely unique from most games that I've played. The game is simply about optimisation - you have to optimise your buildings, your research, your village placement, your military, and the production of materials to create all these. You also have to optimise the timeframe of when you create these events. This means you have to decide what to create, when to create it, how it will affect your village, your military, and your production, and you have to know if it'll create any difference in the short term to realise your long-term plans. It is a deep experience to go into, with the possibilities rolling in your mind the entire time you're looking at your village statistics. It's like upgrading your character in an RPG, feeling the same amount of pride you do in yourself as you do with your kingdom.Also, you don't need to worry too much about the community. Pretty much all of the players are friendly, looking out for their best interests instead of trying to ruin your day. Most battles are petty, with a small-time raider taking the resources of another village far away - even then only if they're an incredibly weak and defenseless target. If you're at the point where you can let anybody walk in and take your resources, then you let that happen to yourself. The only way for a decent player to have all their villages destroyed is toâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥off a large vassal without making any diplomacy, which is how all my villages were destroyed two years ago.In essence, it's a good game, whether or not you can pay the subscription fee. It gets much better and much faster if you can pay for it, and it is an investment I recommend. It isn't at all a distilled experience like you get with almost every other kingdom-building game on the market, and is a worthy video game in it's own right. It's a unique and engrossing game for sure, and it's one you can download in a few minutes and try out. You do get a two-day subscription to see if you like it, which is a nice feature, if a bit like bait. I really do like this game, even if all my playtime is off the Steam client.P.S. if you're curious, my handle is "Enthers". Please don't raid my apple farms.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I can't explain why, but this seems to be my most played game. The game is all about patience, being smart with resources and technology and focusing on what's important first. After you've built the first couple of buildings you have to be extremely patient. I play a few times a day, doing different things to make sure my castle is the best it can be for the parish I'm in. I hardly know anyone but I could do, I got into a faction by asking around. They help you and you can help them. The good things about this game is that it's pretty much a free version of stronghold. While you can't do as much as the games, it is an amazing version of it. While it may seem daunting at first, it takes some time to learn how to be the most efficient, but it pays off.

number of helpful: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Been playing for over 2 yrs now. If you want to play casually or more involved I recommend it for either. Despite many reviews you don't have to "pay to win" it just takes some patience, and although if you spend money you get more or faster results, it is definitely not a requirement. This game is best when you actually get involved with people in the world and once you're involved in a faction or house there is a lot more to do and it becomes more about planning amd strategy. If you don't have patience this game isn't for you...there is literally over a year of real-time research without paying to speed it up, so you're note going to be a powerhouse for a while, especially on a veteran world. The most annoying thing can be the in game politics with players who try to boss everyone around, or when you spend weeks building a village and it gets razed overnight.

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Great game. Interface is intuitive and friendly as are most players. If you land in an unfriendly parish, it's just a matter of abandoning your first village and starting over until you find a parish that you like. I definitely wouldn't recommend this game for folks who don't enjoy being part of a larger community and working with others. This game is specifically designed to require interactivity between players to reach higher levels.Some tiny DirectX bugs that are usually resolved by making sure that your computer is up to date...As for any 'freemium' complaints, money will only get you so far in this game if you play solo. There are actually only two $5 USD purchases that are needed to ramp up the free cards (that's right, free) bonus to maximum which is one free card every twelve hours. The rest of the game is about joining a team (faction) and working together.So, yes, if you're a self involved gimp who is certain that you are the centre of the universe don't play this game. I would hate to run into you in world.

												It;s a great game for leaders and tacticians. It really is a long process game of politics, war and money. It will have you playing for days if not months before it ends. If not it's fun for a little while, but will eventually leave you upset, cold, and lonely as you watch as someone who spent a few dollars rolls over you and destroys everything without taking prisoners. It is a VERY good game. Horrible business model. So yes, I still "recommend" it.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												I think this game is clever.  I like the ranking, even with the levels increasing for each rank.  I like the way, 2 months later, I'm still learning.  There is a lot to learn, but it's fun while you're learning.  The fact that one can choose different paths is cool.  I thought I wanted to be a monker, but I like providing also, and I like fighting too, so I do all of it.  The best part is that you're not alone.  Belonging to a House and Faction is cool, and you get so much help.  I like the elections.  Stronghold is a multi-faceted game, very addictive.  I highly recommend it.I see a lot of people saying it's a pay to win game, but so far, I have not found that to be true.  Sure, some people pay and get things done faster, but they don't bother me.  Like they say in my faction, "Stronghold is a marathon, not a sprint."

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I am slowly starting to fall in love with this game. At first I was wary due to alot of comments and reviews claiming it to be a pay-to-win. I have found that although if you do decide to buy card packs and such it can be a little Overpowered, in reality almost nobody actually goes all in on the cards. It just isn't a day to day issue except in times of war. The overall mechanics and game design are thoroughly rewarding. The game scales better than almost anything I've seen so far. Also it is a very social game, bringing in a couple of friends brought a whole new level of satisfaction and cooperation to the game. I only have one request and it may prove too tall of an order for the devs: Is it possible to change the peasant mechanic to be finite and spawn in hovels based on ration rate? Then I would love to see the peasants moving from village to village based on happiness. So it would show migration in real time. I often log on and only see a few trade carts and scouts on the map from only one players village showing that this is the only other active player on right now...It would be server intensive, but it would bring an organic feel and map richness as well as making the game more realistic with a somewhat limited population based on regional development level. All in all, great game so far. I look forward to new content and getting to Crown Prince! Username-Brian of York

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Stronghold kingdoms is a difficult game to explain, but if you have ever played a village building game, it is similar to that except on steroids. It is similar to tribal wars, and other games like this but every aspect of the game is simply better. For some reason everyone thinks that the game is pay to win, but this game is not single player so as long as you have those who are contributing to keeping the game aloft by donating on your side you will be fine. Even then there are ways to beat those who buy lots of crowns without anybody in your house using crowns if you have a good enough strategy, but it will involve a lot of waiting and bleeding the enemy dry. Also, you can get cards even if you don't pay, especially now that there is an AI world which allows you to farm cards if you are dedicated enough. This game is not for those who like to be spoon fed results, but if you are patient and enjoy talking to other people and strategizing then this game is for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Stronghold Kingdoms is a good mix of top-down economic strategy with a medieval feel. Start off as a lowly peasant and work your way up to being master of a group of villages or even the King or Queen.Cross swords with your enemies, send wine to your friends so they can feast. Use the trade system to generate the gold to build an empire, it's all here.A game that is simple to begin but also requires good diplomacy and resource management, it's been a really good game to play when having a very changeable job.A really mature player-base makes for a thoroughly enjoyable game with good lasting power. It's free to play, so what are you waiting for?Download it already!

												endrsgm -stronghold kingdoms is a nuanced game. anyone can jump in and play it without having any previous experience in either this game or even this genre of games. however, there is a steep learning curve to master this game.likes: the game is very social. you must develop and maintain alliances.the ability to focus build villages towards specific tasks is very cool. dislikes: the AI castles. way too much of the game time is spent worrying about the appearance of AI castles. a strictly player vs AI version of the game has been made and many players find it enjoyable. why not create a world that has NO AI enemies. it would be purely player vs player. honestly, i would be much more interested in this than playing against a computer. likes and dislikes aside, i find this to be one of the greatest games ive played and i recommend it highly to everyone.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												EASILY THE BEST MMORTS I HAVE EVER PLAYED! I have been hooked onto this game since I started the USA world, and let me tell you, I have made many friends among many kingdoms. I started out looking at the game not expecting much, but when you open your first village, you barely scratch the surface of this hidden gem. There are so many things to keep you busy, instead of just staring at the world map. It's not like one of those facebook games where you just sit there and be bored for the next 12 hours while something builds, there is always something going on that needs your attention. Whether it be scouting for resource stashes, sending mail to factions for diplomacy between other players, or even managing your parish, you will never be let down. It is a little slow to start, but once you get going, I guarantee you, you will not stop. On a side note, you really dont need to pay any money in order to do well in this game, and thats coming from someone who never bought the firefly crowns before. You can earn cards simply by playing and the game rewards you for the more hours you put in. Truly a diamond in the rough as the gameplay shines through being so complex but simple at the same time.IGN: LionhartPrideWorld: Europe 3

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Stronghold Kingdoms is a good mix of top-down economic strategy with a medieval feel. Start off as a lowly peasant and work your way up to being master of a group of villages or even the King or Queen.Cross swords with your enemies, send wine to your friends so they can feast. Use the trade system to generate the gold to build an empire, it's all here.A game that is simple to begin but also requires good diplomacy and resource management, it's been a really good game to play when having a very changeable job.A really mature player-base makes for a thoroughly enjoyable game with good lasting power. It's free to play, so what are you waiting for?Download it already!

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												This game is addictive, if you are not looking to invest solid time into a game then look elsewhere.  If you play the game right and honestly you will at some point be destroyed. At the point when you are destroyed do not quit, destruction is inevitable I was completely defeated along with the group I was in multiple times when I started the game and later on as well and honestly they were some great times.  Ever fought 200 vs 10? I have on stronghold kingdoms and it was great.  If you are looking to enjoy the game and get honest people to fight alongside you youâre going to need to get crushed a few times first as a noob and eventually, after you have learned the mechanics, as a veritable juggernaut.  You will wade through the masses together with your group and if you stay true to your group you will come out of it reset but stronger than ever before knowing exactly who your friends are, at any time you will have traitors and you will need to hunt them mercilessly, you will have lingering adversaries and you will need to carefully manage the political arena to turn people against them, rivalries will at points have to be cast aside for mutual survival, hold your vengeances deep but your common sense and your tactics deeper.For me winning is the most boring part, if your new join a small group donât head for a big house where you will be coddled or bored, in a small fighting group you may get stomped a few times but your skills and your airtight group will be worth it in the endshk username: nomatophobia

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Played this game only for six months, did sink a few quid on it, but I really didn't need to. You get some decent free cards but really wasn't a pay to win game unless you were fighting really big wars. Me and my friend gradually took over two parishes in southern England after a few weeks of vote point building and collaborating with other non house/hight ranking people. We got the parishes under our control without even really being noticed by this guy. It was only after we tried to muscle in on a third parish; I received a message from him only saying "bye". I then noticed 3 icons moving towards my villages, and four over to my friends. He destroyed everything. We tried to send our troops to attack his villages in a pathetic attempt attempt to save ourselves. Or at least take a bit of him with us. Our troops were slaughtered in a tower grid of a village. His troops marched right through our 1 stone block walls and that was that really. We both stopped playing after that. I felt 1000 hours was enough.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

												fantastic game! Well, thats what i think anyway. Here are a few questions: do you like having fun? would you want to rule a town? would you like to build YOUR VERY OWN village and castle? If you answered yes to all of these, GET THIS GAME as it is perfect for you. If you answered no, give it a go, it might even become your new favourite game! I can tell you how much i like this game: I have played 19.5 hours of it and is the game ive played on second most!!!2 months later... Ok, i havent played this game for a month, and my village has been obliterated, it is actually not there any more, so i have to start again. This happened because of invaders that attacked my village. I got mad when this happened... very mad. I still think this is a really good game, but if you are going to hardly ever play this game ( by that i mean once a month or so ), then don't get it.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												I played all the strongholds growing up.  Im surprised i stayed away from this for so long.  Its oddly addicting to build up your village and level up.  It reminds me of the web browser text based games mixed with regular stronghold.  I honestly would of stayed away if it wasn't for the USA map.  Its a fun setting to be a medevil lord in the usa.   It has me pretty hooked to the point where i check in regulary, but its the type of game where if you can't get on for a few hours it won't hurt to bad. My only complaint is you don't get to have an actual "lord" on the map.  You get to make an avatar, but thats it.  I would love to see my lord be able to lead troops like a captain.  Other than that its worth checking out, its free after all.   Names Ethabrowne on usa2 if anyone needs help!Had to add some extra after playing for a bit.  Before i started playing i was worried because people said it was pay to win.  While cards can give you an advantage being active and building right, and getting to npc targets can make you accel over card users..  So being active rewards you.  Its addictive watching myself get stronger and outrank the vet players.  Even captured my first village from some menace, made the guy quit.  I won that day.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I guess since I've put in so many hours to this game, It is worth giving it a review. These kinds of games are kinda niche-y in play style. You either like it or you don't. However, if you are into this genre of strategy game then I think you should get this game. Something about being able to control building placement to optimize resource output is more fun than just clicking a static tile and telling it to upgrade. It opens up a lot more possibility for optimization and higher level gameplay than other similar titles where high level play simply involves having all of your city's buildings fully upgraded. Give it a try. Its Free after all, whats the worst that could happen? (And before you say, "well a waste of download time" the game is a pretty small download. Its really easy to set up and get going pretty quickly...so yea ...there is that.)

content:
Posted: May 27, 2013
												The objective of Stronghold Kingdoms is to build your own town and castle, commerce and defence. At the beginning you choose your real-world country, county and town - the game takes place on a map of the real world, and you can defend the honor of your real-life hometown if you wish.The game starts off slowly as many strategy games do, with woodcutters bringing in wood and quarries bringing in stone. Soon you will be farming animals, trading with nearby towns and going to war with neighboring counties, with the aim to make your parish the greatest and also to make your city to the capital of the entire country.What makes Stronghold Kingdoms different to other strategy games, is that every action you do takes real time to complete. So you have to spend some money or it will take much time until you have built a town.The engine of Stronghold Kingdoms is old and the game starts very slowly, especially for those who are not going to open their wallet. But it deserves a try if you got patience and prefer management over real time strategy, or if you are just a fan of the Stronghold series.Sounds 6/10Graphics 5/10Gameplay 6/10Atmosphere 6/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												TLDR: Stronghold Kingdoms is a fun and addicting Free 2 Play RTS that is as punishing as it is rewarding.Be warned, this game is really complicated and hard to learn so don't be afraid to ask for help, there is a starters tutorial in there that explains the very basics and i mean the VERY basics, all it tells you is how to build things in your village and castle and maybie a few other small things, there are a few quests that help you get the hang of the game though.In my opinion this game isn't all that P2W, at least from what i've seen. When you spend money on this game you can get either one of seven random card packs that gives you random cards five cards as the name suggests or premium which allows you to que up five buildings in your villages, aswell as five researches, when selling your goods it gives you the option to find the highest and lowest prices and the ability to add protection to your village up to 15 days, the last one I haven't figured out how to use. Aswell as a few automated things that IMO aren't too useful.When starting off I reccomend starting near a friend that knows how to play that can teach you some of the basics that the tutorial doesn't cover and help you get started.You start off with one village and some stone and wood and as you rank up you earn 3 research points for every rank, until a few classes up you have to go through sub-ranks, which are basically the same thing only not as special, and as you get stronger you can control more villages that you either steal from other players at a massive honour penalty or you buy a village from charters which are rare, especially when the server is in the later stages, the more villages you have the higher the penalty or cost, charters are also more expensive the further they are away from the village you have selected.When building structures in your village each structure type is more expensive than the last and each structure takes longer to build oh and research, oh the research. Researching things imo is the most unforgiving part of this game, once you research something once it's complete you've got it, you can't get it back or anything. In addition to earning three points each time you rank up you can buy research points for gold which, again gets more expensive the more points you buy but there are researches that reduces the time it takes to build things and research tasks and researches that make buying points cheaper but you get the cheaper points later in the game, there are also cards that complete researches and buildings, make buildings and researches complete faster and give free research points.Armies probably should of been explained better imo, you start off with armed peasants which cost just about nothing to create, archers which are the only general use ranged unit, pikemen which try to clean out castles, swordsmen which rush straight for the center and catapults which sit there and hit the target you order them to, although catapults do deal out some nasty friendly fire. One tip i have when deploying armies is upgrade the troops you're using as much as you can since every upgrade exept captains and catapults upgrades their health, the catapult upgrade makes them fire faster and the captain upgrades make captain armies move faster and let you have more captains per village, i also reccomend getting the speed upgrade and as you expand get the army allowance upgrade.There are four currencies, gold which is generally used for creating troops and some structures, faith which is used with monks, honour which is used to rank up and crowns which are the paycash. On top of the four currencies there are four raw resource types, eight banquet resource types, six food types and five weapon types which are required to build every troop but captains and armed peasants.In addition to your army you have three non-combat units that you can use, scouts, monks and traders. Scouts can be used to scout enemy AI places and player villages and forage for resources which can be useful when you need resources and are running low, traders as the name suggests trade with parish capitals or they can be used to give resources to other players, while i haven't used monks myself they can be used to change votes, cure disease, increasing and decreasing popularity of villages in the parish and preventing attacks, aswell as of course removing these powers and removes the powers of churches. Although when training these units be warned, they run off the same population limit as your army and aswell as your troops they require peasants to train, unlike captains and villages though the more monks you have the cheaper they are. You increase the amount of each unit by research although unlike scouts and monks, the traders cap get increased based on how many markets you have, the limit of which is 10, each market will allow up to 5 traders.If you start you can't stop, in alot of cases you won't want to stop. The game runs in real time so you might get attacked by either an AI or a random player while you're off. Don't say off for too long though because you will get booted from the server from *ahem* idleness. The idle threshold goes up the higher your rank is, up to 2 months or if you have a premium token that lasts longer than your rank's idle time then the game will wait for that to expire before you get booted.Again, if you need help or advice don't be afraid to go on the Steam community hub, the SK offical forums, the guides or if you're lucky ask a player via the in-game chat.If anyone's interested in teaming up, my name is Hinsonator in game.
